title: Vibrio vulnificus
noteText:
Vibrio vulnificus

Epidemiology
  • Gram-negative, free-living in marine environments
  • Ingestion (oysters) or wound infection
  • â Risk in those with liver disease* (cirrhosis, hepatitis)

Manifestations
  • Rapidly progressive (often <12 hr)
  • Septicemia: septic shock, bullous lesions
  • Cellulitis: hemorrhagic bullae, necrotizing fasciitis

Diagnosis
  • Blood & wound cultures

Treatment
  • Empiric in those with likely illness as highly fatal
  • Intravenous ceftriaxone + doxycycline

*Hereditary hemochromatosis is particularly high risk because iron acts as a growth catalyst.

title: Mx of cardiovascular risk in type 2 diabetes
noteText:
Pharmacologic management of cardiovascular risk in type 2 diabetes mellitus

Antiplatelet therapy
  • Known ASCVD or high ASCVD risk
  • Low-dose (75-182 mg) aspirin

Blood pressure management
  • Target <130/80 mm Hg
  • ACE inhibitors, ARBs preferred

Statin therapy
  • Known ASCVD
  • Age 40-75
  • Age 20-39 with increased ASCVD risk

Glucose-lowering
therapy
  • Known ASCVD or age â¥55 with 2 or more additional risk factors: SGLT2i or GLP-1 agonist
  • Heart failure: SGLT2i
ARB = angiotensin II receptor blocker; ASCVD = atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease; GLP-1 = glucagon-like peptide-1; SGLT2i = sodium-glucose cotransporter-2 inhibitor.

title: Infective endocarditis
noteText:
Vascular & immunologic manifestations of infective endocarditis

Vascular
phenomena
  • Systemic emboli (cerebral, pulmonary, or splenic infarcts)
  • Mycotic aneurysm
  • Janeway lesions: macular, erythematous, nontender lesions on the palms & soles

Immunologic
phenomena
  • Osler nodes: painful, violaceous nodules seen on the fingertips & toes
  • Roth spots: edematous & hemorrhagic lesions of the retina

Infective endocarditis: modified Duke criteria

Diagnostic criteria
for IE

Major criteria

  • Blood culture positive for typical microorganism (eg, Staphylococcus aureus, Enterococcus, viridans streptococci)
  • Echocardiography showing valvular vegetation

Minor criteria

  • Predisposing cardiac lesion
  • Intravenous drug use
  • Temperature >38 C (100.4 F)
  • Embolic phenomena
  • Immunologic phenomena (eg, glomerulonephritis)
  • Positive blood culture not meeting above criteria

Definite IE

  • 2 major OR 1 major + 3 minor criteria

Possible IE

  • 1 major + 1 minor OR 3 minor criteria

Clinical findings
(frequency)
  • Fever (>90%)
  • Heart murmur (85%)
  • Petechiae (â¤50%)
  • Subungual splinter hemorrhages (<50%)
  • Osler nodes, Janeway lesions (<50%)
  • Neurologic phenomena (embolic) (â¤40%)
  • Splenomegaly (â¤30%)
  • Roth spots (retinal hemorrhage) (<5%)

IE = infective endocarditis.

title: Constitutional growth delay
noteText:
Constitutional delay of growth and puberty

Clinical features
  • Family history of âlate bloomersâ
  • Delayed puberty
  • Short stature; normal growth velocity
  • Delayed bone age

Management
  • Reassurance; watchful waiting
  • Â± Hormone therapy

Prognosis
  • Puberty onset correlates with family members
  • Normal expected adult height

title: Cat scratch disease
noteText:
Cat scratch disease

Etiology

  • Bartonella henselae, fastidious gram-negative bacilli
  • Can be transmitted by cat scratch/bite

Clinical
manifestations

  • Papule at scratch/bite site
  • Regional adenopathy
  • Â± Fever of unknown origin (â¥14 days)

Diagnosis

  • Usually clinical
  • Â± Serology

Treatment

  • Generally self-limiting
  • Azithromycin

title: Galactosemia
noteText:
Galactosemia

Etiology
  • GALT deficiency
  • Autosomal recessive
  • Galactose accumulation after lactose or galactose ingestion

Clinical findings
  • Jaundice & hepatomegaly
  • Vomiting & poor feeding/failure to thrive
  • Cataracts
  • Increased risk for Escherichia coli sepsis

Laboratory findings
  • â Bilirubin, AST, ALT
  • â Glucose
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • + Urine reducing substance

Diagnosis
  • May be identified on newborn screening
  • Absent red blood cell GALT activity

Treatment
  • Galactose-free diet (eg, soy-based formula)

ALT = alanine aminotransferase; AST = aspartate aminotransferase; GALT = galactose 1-phosphate uridylyltransferase.

title: DKA and HUS
noteText:
Diabetic ketoacidosis

Patient characteristics
  • Young age
  • Brittle type 1 diabetes mellitus
  • May be initial manifestation of diabetes

Clinical symptoms
  • Acute to subacute onset
    • Initial: polydipsia/polyuria, blurred vision, weight loss
    • Later: altered mentation, hyperventilation, abdominal pain

Diagnosis
  • âGlucose (typically 300-800 mg/dL)
  • Metabolic acidosis (bicarbonate <18 mEq/L)
  • â Anion gap
  • Positive serum ketones

Treatment
  • High-flow IV fluids (normal saline)
  • IV insulin
  • Follow & replace potassium

IV = intravenous.

Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state

Patient
characteristics
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Older age

Inciting
factors
  • Acute illness, trauma, infection
  • Insulin nonadherence
  • Medications: glucocorticoids, diuretics, atypical antipsychotics

Clinical
features

Subacute or acute onset of:

  • Altered mentation
  • Hyperglycemic symptoms (eg, polyuria)
  • Volume depletion

Laboratory
studies
  • Glucose >600 mg/dL (33.3 mmol/L)
  • Bicarbonate >18 mEq/L (18 mmol/L)
  • Normal anion gap
  • Negative or small serum ketones
  • Serum osmolality >320 mOsm/kg (320 mmol/kg)

Hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state

Diagnostic criteria
  • Severe hyperglycemia (eg, >600 mg/dL)
  • Hyperosmolality (eg, calculated serum osmolality >320 mOsm/kg)
  • No significant ketosis (serum Î²-hydroxybutyrate <3.0 mmol/L, urine ketones â¤1+)
  • No significant metabolic acidosis (pH â¥7.3, serum bicarbonate â¥15 mEq/L, normal anion gap)

Patient
characteristics
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Older age

Clinical
symptoms
  • Gradual hyperglycemic symptoms (eg, polyuria, polydipsia)
  • Altered mentation (eg, obtundation, focal deficits, seizures)

Initial
management
  • Aggressive hydration (balanced crystalloid solution, normal saline)
  • Intravenous insulin
  • Replace potassium if <5.3 mEq/L (normal measured K+ may mask actual total body deficit)

Differentiating type 1 from type 2 diabetes mellitus
 

Type 1

Type 2

Pathophysiology
  • Insulin deficiency
  • Insulin resistance with relative insulin deficiency

Epidemiology
  • Children; less frequently, young adults
  • Family history less common
  • Often thin habitus
  • Adults; less frequently, adolescents
  • Family history common
  • Often obese

Presentation
  • Acute/severe (eg, polyuria, polydipsia, weight loss)
  • Ketoacidosis common
  • Usually asymptomatic/insidious
  • Ketoacidosis uncommon

Associated
conditions
  • Other autoimmune disorders (eg, thyroiditis, celiac disease)
  • Dyslipidemia, hypertension, acanthosis nigricans

C-peptide levels
  • Low
  • Usually elevated

Autoantibodies*
  • Usually present
  • Usually absent

*For example, glutamic acid decarboxylase.

title: Diabetic foot ulcer
noteText:
Diabetic foot ulcers

Risk factors
  • Chronically uncontrolled diabetes
  • Diabetic neuropathy (decreased protective sensation)
  • Foot deformity & small muscle atrophy
  • End-stage renal disease/dialysis

Presentation
  • Plantar surface under pressure points (eg, bony prominences)
  • Painless ulcer
  • "Punched out" appearance with necrotic base
  • Often with adjacent callus

title: Effect of excercise on insulin and glucose
Drugs for neuropathic pain
noteText:
Drugs for neuropathic pain

Drug

Mechanism of action

Tricyclic antidepressants
(eg, amitriptyline, nortriptyline)

 

SNRIs (eg, duloxetine)
  • â Reuptake of serotonin & norepinephrine
  • Inhibition of pain signals

Anticonvulsants
(eg, gabapentin, pregabalin)
  • Decreased depolarization of neurons in the CNS

Opioids
  • Activation of central opioid receptors

Capsaicin (topical)
  • Loss of membrane potential in nociceptive fibers

Lidocaine (topical)
  • Decreased depolarization of neurons in peripheral nerves

SNRIs = serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors.

title: Laboratory evaluation of HTN
noteText:
Laboratory evaluation of hypertension

Renal function tests
  • Serum electrolytes (Na, K, Ca)
  • Serum creatinine
  • Urinalysis
  • Urine albumin/creatinine ratio (optional)

Endocrine tests
  • Fasting glucose or hemoglobin A1c
  • Lipid profile
  • TSH

Cardiac tests
  • ECG
  • Echocardiography (optional)

Other tests
  • Complete blood count
  • Uric acid (optional)

title: Rx of Graves disease
noteText:
Choice of treatment in Graves disease

Antithyroid drugs
  • Preferred in patients with limited life expectancy
  • May induce remission in mild hyperthyroidism
  • May be used as pretreatment prior to radioactive iodine or thyroidectomy (eg, high-risk patient, severe hyperthyroidism)

Radioactive iodine
  • Acceptable option for moderate hyperthyroidism
  • May initially worsen ophthalmopathy & hyperthyroid symptoms (increases TRAb)
  • Leads to permanent hypothyroidism over time

Thyroidectomy
  • Preferred in patients with very large goiter, obstructive symptoms, or ophthalmopathy
  • Potential complications from injury to parathyroids (eg, hypocalcemia, hypoparathyroidism) &/or laryngeal or vagus nerve (eg, hoarseness)

TRAb = thyrotropin receptor antibodies.

title: CVS effect of thyrotoxicosis
noteText:
Cardiovascular effects of thyrotoxicosis

Rhythm
  • Sinus tachycardia
  • Premature atrial & ventricular complexes
  • Atrial fibrillation/flutter

Hemodynamic effects
  • Systolic hypertension & â pulse pressure
  • â Contractility & cardiac output
  • â Systemic vascular resistance
  • â Myocardial oxygen demand

Heart failure
  • High-output failure
  • Exacerbation of preexisting low-output failure

Angina symptoms
  • Coronary vasospasm
  • Preexisting coronary atherosclerosis

title: Hyperthyroid bone disease
Craniopharyngioma
noteText:
Craniopharyngioma

Epidemiology
  • Benign, slow growing
  • Derived from remnants of Rathke pouch
  • Bimodal age distribution (age 5-14 & 50-75)

Clinical features
  • Optic chiasm compression â bitemporal hemianopsia
  • Pituitary stalk compression â endocrinopathies
    • Growth failure in children (â TSH or â GH)
    • Pubertal delay in children or sexual dysfunction in adults (â LH & FSH)
    • Diabetes insipidus (â ADH)

Diagnosis
  • MRI/CT scan: calcified &/or cystic suprasellar mass

Treatment
  • Surgical resection Â± radiation therapy

ADH = antidiuretic hormone; GH = growth hormone.

title: Thyroid storm
noteText:
Clinical features of thyroid storm

Precipitating factors
  • Thyroid or nonthyroidal surgery
  • Acute illness (eg, trauma, infection), childbirth
  • Acute iodine load (eg, iodine contrast)

Clinical presentation
  • Fever as high as 40-41.1 C (104-106 F)
  • Tachycardia, hypertension, congestive heart failure, cardiac arrhythmias (eg, atrial fibrillation)
  • Agitation, delirium, seizure, coma
  • Goiter, lid lag, tremor, warm & moist skin
  • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, jaundice

Treatment
  • Î² Blocker (eg, propranolol) to â adrenergic manifestations
  • PTU followed by iodine solution (SSKI) to â hormone synthesis & release
  • Glucocorticoids (eg, hydrocortisone) to â peripheral T4 to T3 conversion & improve vasomotor stability
  • Identify trigger & treat, provide supportive care

PTU = propylthiouracil; SSKI = potassium iodide.

title: Adrenal crisis
noteText:
Acute adrenal insufficiency (adrenal crisis)

Risk factors
  • Adrenal hemorrhage/infarction
  • Acute illness, injury, or surgery in patients with:
    • Chronic adrenal insufficiency
    • Long-term glucocorticoid use
    • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

Clinical features
  • Hypotension/shock
  • Nausea/vomiting, abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Fever
  • Acute kidney injury

Diagnostic testing
  • Cortisol
  • Electrolytes, BUN, creatinine, glucose
  • ACTH
  • Renin
  • ACTH stimulation test when stable

Treatment
  • Hydrocortisone or dexamethasone
  • High-flow intravenous fluids
  • Serum electrolyte monitoring

BUN = blood urea nitrogen.

Toxic adenoma

Treatment

ablation

Surgery

  • Risk for hypoparathyroidism

ANCA = antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibodies.

title: Evaluation of hyperthyroidism

noteText:
Euthyroid sick syndrome (low T3 syndrome)

Risk factors

Pathophysiology
  • High circulating levels of glucocorticoids and inflammatory cytokines (eg, tumor necrosis factor, interferon alpha)
  • Decreased peripheral conversion of T4 to T3

Diagnostic testing
  • Early:  Low T3, normal TSH & T4
  • Late:  Low T3, TSH & T4

Management
  • Observe without treatment
  • Follow-up testing when patient has returned to baseline health

ICU = intensive care unit.

SGT = subacute granulomatous (de Quervain) thyroiditis; TPO = thyroid peroxidase antibody; TRAb = thyrotropin receptor antibody; TSI = thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulin.

title: MEN 1
noteText:
Classification of multiple endocrine neoplasia

Type 1
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism (parathyroid adenomas or hyperplasia)
  • Pituitary tumors (prolactin, visual defects)
  • Pancreatic tumors (especially gastrinomas)

Type 2A
  • Medullary thyroid cancer (calcitonin)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Primary hyperparathyroidism (parathyroid hyperplasia)

Type 2B
  • Medullary thyroid cancer (calcitonin)
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Mucosal neuromas/marfanoid habitus

Multiple endocrine neoplasia syndrome type 1

Manifestation

Clinical features

Pituitary adenomas
(10%-20%)
  • Secretion of prolactin, growth hormone, ACTH (or nonfunctioning tumors)
  • Mass effects (eg, headache, visual field defects)

Primary hyperparathyroidism
(>90%)
  • Multiple parathyroid adenomas or parathyroid hyperplasia
  • Hypercalcemia (eg, polyuria, kidney stones, decreased bone density)

Pancreatic/gastrointestinal neuroendocrine tumors
(60%-70%)
  • Gastrinoma: recurrent peptic ulcers
  • Insulinoma: hypoglycemia
  • VIPoma: secretory diarrhea, hypokalemia, hypochlorhydria
  • Glucagonoma: weight loss, necrolytic migratory erythema, hyperglycemia

Clinical features of glucagonoma

Clinical presentation
  • Necrolytic migratory erythema
    • Erythematous papules/plaques on face, perineum, extremities
    • Lesions enlarge & coalesce over 7-14 days with central clearing & blistering, crusting & scaling at borders
  • Diabetes mellitus
    • Mild hyperglycemia easily controlled with oral agents & diet
    • Usually does not require insulin
  • Gastrointestinal: diarrhea, anorexia, abdominal pain, or occasional constipation
  • Other findings
    • Weight loss
    • Neuropsychiatric: ataxia, dementia, proximal muscle weakness
    • Association with venous thrombosis

Diagnosis
  • Hyperglycemia with elevated glucagon >500 pg/mL
  • Normocytic, normochromic anemia due to likely anemia of chronic disease or direct effect of glucagon on erythropoiesis
  • Abdominal imaging: CT scan or MRI to localize tumor &/or metastases

title: Pheochromocytoma
noteText:
Pheochromocytoma

Indications for testing
  • Classic triad: episodic headache, sweating & tachycardia
  • Resistant HTN or HTN accompanied by unexplained â glucose
  • Family history or familial syndrome (eg, MEN2, NF1, VHL)

Diagnostic approach
  • Urine or plasma metanephrine levels
  • Confirmatory abdominal imaging for â metanephrines

Notable features
  • 10% bilateral, 10% extraadrenal, 10% malignant

Management
  • Preoperative alpha blockade prior to beta blockade
  • Laparoscopic or open surgical resection

HTN = hypertension; MEN2 = multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2; NF1 = neurofibromatosis type 1; VHL = von Hippel-Lindau syndrome.

title: Myopathy causes
noteText:
Common causes of myopathy

Connective tissue diseases

  • Polymyositis/dermatomyositis
  • Inclusion body myositis
  • Vasculitis
  • Overlap syndrome (mixed connective tissue disease)

Endocrine/

metabolic

title: Indication of thyroid testing
noteText:
Indications to test for hypothyroidism in asymptomatic patients

Clinical findings
& history
  • Bradycardia, diastolic hypertension
  • Pleural/pericardial effusion
  • Autoimmune disease (eg, vitiligo, type 1 diabetes mellitus)

Laboratory
abnormalities
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Hyponatremia
  • Macrocytic anemia
  • Hyperprolactinemia

Pituitary/hypothalamic
disorders
  • Sellar/parasellar mass
  • Pituitary surgery or radiation
  • Acute or chronic hypopituitarism

title: Congenital hypothyroidism
noteText:
Congenital hypothyroidism

Pathophysiology
  • Thyroid dysgenesis most common (eg, agenesis, hypoplasia, ectopy)

Clinical
manifestations
  • Asymptomatic at birth*
  • Symptomatic weeks to months after birth (as maternal T4 wanes)
    • Hypometabolism: â HR & temperature, lethargy/poor feeding, hypotonia, constipation, jaundice
    • Mucopolysaccharide accumulation: macroglossia, umbilical hernia
    • Delayed bone maturation: enlarged fontanelles

Diagnosis
  • Newborn screening
  • â TSH & â T4

Treatment
  • Levothyroxine

Prognosis
  • No deficits if treatment started in neonatal period
  • Untreated disease leads to intellectual disability, developmental delay & poor growth

*Can rarely present with delayed passage of meconium.

HR = heart rate.

title: Maternal thyroid testing inpregnancy 1st trimester
noteText:
Maternal thyroid testing in pregnancy, 1st trimester

Hormone

Change

Mechanism

Total T4

Increased
  • Î²-hCG stimulates thyroid hormone production in 1st trimester
  • Estrogen stimulates TBG; thyroid increases hormone production to maintain steady free T4 level

Free T4

Unchanged or mildly increased

TSH

Decreased
  • Increased Î²-hCG & thyroid hormone suppress TSH secretion

TBG = thyroxine-binding globulin.

title: Mx of hyperprolactinemia in premenopausal women
Hypothyroidism features
noteText:
Clinical features of hypothyroidism

Mood symptoms
  • Depression
  • Apathy
  • Social withdrawal

Cognitive symptoms
  • Impaired concentration & memory
  • Psychomotor slowing
  • Executive dysfunction

Severe symptoms
  • Delirium
  • Psychosis (myxedema madness)

Physical symptoms
  • Bradycardia
  • Cold intolerance
  • Fatigue
  • Muscle weakness & myalgia
  • Hyporeflexia

title: Graves disease Rx
noteText:
Treatment of Graves disease

Î²-Blockers
  • Initiated at diagnosis to mitigate hyperadrenergic complications

Antithyroid
drugs
  • Can induce remission in many patients
  • May be used as pretreatment prior to radioactive iodine or thyroidectomy (eg, high-risk patient, severe hyperthyroidism)

Radioactive
iodine
  • Acceptable option for moderate hyperthyroidism
  • May initially worsen ophthalmopathy and hyperthyroid symptoms
  • Leads to permanent hypothyroidism over time

Thyroidectomy
  • Preferred in patients with very large goiter, obstructive symptoms, or ophthalmopathy

title: Glucagonoma
noteText:
Features of glucagonoma

Clinical presentation
  • Weight loss
  • Necrolytic migratory erythema: erythematous papules that coalesce to form large, indurated plaques with central clearing
  • Diabetes mellitus/hyperglycemia
  • Gastrointestinal symptoms (eg, diarrhea, anorexia, abdominal pain)

Diagnosis
  • Markedly elevated glucagon level
  • Abdominal imaging (MRI or CT scan)

title: Carcinoid syndrome
noteText:
Features of carcinoid syndrome

Clinical manifestations
  • Skin: flushing, telangiectasias, cyanosis
  • Gastrointestinal: diarrhea, cramping
  • Cardiac: valvular lesions (right > left side)
  • Pulmonary: bronchospasm
  • Miscellaneous: niacin deficiency (dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia)

Diagnosis
  • Elevated 24-hr urinary excretion of 5-HIAA
  • CT scan/MRI of abdomen & pelvis to localize tumor
  • OctreoScan to detect metastases
  • Echocardiogram (if symptoms of carcinoid heart disease are present)

Treatment
  • Octreotide for symptomatic patients & prior to surgery/anesthesia
  • Surgery for liver metastases

title: Neonatal graves disease
noteText:
Neonatal Graves disease

Pathophysiology
  • Transplacental passage of maternal TSH receptorâstimulating antibodies (due to maternal Graves disease)
  • Antibodies bind to infant's TSH receptors & cause excessive thyroid hormone release â neonatal thyrotoxicosis

Clinical features
  • Tachycardia & irritability
  • Warm, moist skin
  • Low birth weight or preterm birth
  • Â± Goiter, stare

Diagnosis
  • Maternal & neonatal TSH receptorâstimulating antibodies
  • â TSH, â free thyroxine

Treatment & outcome
  • Methimazole plus Î² blocker
  • Usually self-resolves within months (due to clearance of maternal antibodies)

noteText:
pyoderma gagrinosum

title: Pediatric septic arthritis
noteText:
Pediatric septic arthritis

Pathogenesis
  • Age <3 months: Staphylococcus aureus, group B Streptococcus, gram-negative bacilli
  • Age â¥3 months: Staphylococcus aureus, group A Streptococcus

Clinical features
  • Acute-onset joint pain, swelling, limited motion
  • Refusal to bear weight
  • Fever â¥38.5 C (101.3 F)

Diagnosis
  • â WBC, ESR, CRP
  • Blood culture
  • Joint aspiration (synovial WBC count of >50,000/mm3)
  • Effusion on ultrasound/MRI

Treatment
  • Joint drainage & dÃ©bridement
  • IV antibiotics

CRP = C-reactive protein; ESR = erythrocyte sedimentation rate; IV = intravenous; WBC = white blood cell.

title: Common causes of foodborne disease
Right lower lobe pneumonia
Pulmonary HTN
noteText:
Clinical features of pulmonary hypertension

Classification
  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension (WHO group 1)
  • Due to left heart disease (group 2)
  • Due to chronic lung disease or hypoxemia (eg, COPD, OSA) (group 3)
  • Due to chronic thromboembolic disease (group 4)
  • Due to other causes (eg, sarcoidosis) (group 5)

Symptoms
  • â Cardiac output: exertional syncope/presyncope, fatigue, weakness
  • â PA pressure: chest tightness, hemoptysis (rare)
  • RV demand ischemia: exertional angina/tightness
  • Venous congestion: abdominal distension (bowel edema), early satiety

Signs
  • Precordial heave due to RV hypertrophy
  • Loud P2, right-sided S3 &/or S4
  • Holosystolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation
  • JVD, ascites, peripheral edema, hepatomegaly
COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; JVD = jugular venous distension; OSA = obstructive sleep apnea; PA = pulmonary artery; RV = right ventricular.

title: Von Hippel Lindau disease
noteText:
Von Hippel-Lindau disease

Etiology
  • Mutation in the VHL tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance

Manifestations
  • Cerebellar & retinal hemangioblastomas
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma (clear cell subtype)

Management

  • Surveillance for associated malignancies
    • Eye/retinal examination
    • Plasma or urine metanephrines
    • MRI of the brain & spine
    • MRI of the abdomen
  • Tumor resection

title: Transfusion associated circulatory overload
noteText:
Transfusion-associated circulatory overload

Risk factors
  • Age <3 and >60
  • Underlying cardiac or renal condition
  • Large transfusion volume or fast infusion rate

Clinical features
(<6 hr following
transfusion initiation)
  • Respiratory distress
  • â Heart rate
  • â Blood pressure
  • Pulmonary edema (eg, rales)

Management
  • Respiratory support (eg, oxygen)
  • Diuresis (eg, furosemide)

title: Thyroiditis
noteText:
Thyroiditis
 

Clinical features

Diagnostic testing

Chronic autoimmune thyroiditis
(Hashimoto thyroiditis)
  • Predominant hypothyroid features
  • Diffuse goiter
  • Positive TPO antibody
  • Variable radioiodine uptake

Painless thyroiditis
(silent thyroiditis)
  • Variant of chronic autoimmune thyroiditis
  • Mild, brief hyperthyroid phase
  • Small, nontender goiter
  • Spontaneous recovery
  • Positive TPO antibody
  • Low radioiodine uptake

Subacute (granulomatous) thyroiditis
(de Quervain thyroiditis)
  • Likely postviral inflammatory process
  • Prominent fever & hyperthyroid symptoms
  • Painful/tender goiter
  • Elevated ESR & CRP
  • Low radioiodine uptake

CRP = C-reactive protein; ESR = erythrocyte sedimentation rate; TPO = thyroid peroxidase.

RAIU findings in thyrotoxicosis

Normal or increased
  • Graves disease
  • Toxic multinodular goiter
  • Toxic nodule

Decreased
  • Painless (silent) thyroiditis
  • Subacute (de Quervain) thyroiditis
  • Amiodarone-induced thyroiditis
  • Surreptitious or excessive levothyroxine intake
  • Struma ovarii
  • Iodine induced
  • Metastatic thyroid cancer

RAIU = radioactive iodine uptake.

title: Chronic dyspnea in SCD
noteText:
Chronic dyspnea in sickle cell disease

Cause

Symptoms

Diagnostic findings

Asthma
  • Intermittent/chronic wheezing
  • May be worse at night or with exercise or upper respiratory infection
  • Pulmonary function testing showing reversible airway obstruction

Pulmonary
hypertension
  • Exertional dyspnea
  • Signs of right-sided heart failure (eg, jugular venous distension, edema)
  • Tricuspid regurgitation on echocardiography
  • â Pulmonary arterial pressure on right-sided heart catheterization

Pulmonary
fibrosis
  • Exertional dyspnea
  • Progressive
  • Honeycomb pattern on CT scan of the chest
  • Pulmonary function testing showing restrictive pattern

title: Granulomatosis with polyangitis
noteText:
Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

Clinical manifestations
  • Upper respiratory: sinusitis/otitis, saddle nose
  • Lower respiratory: lung nodules/cavitation, interstitial lung disease, diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
  • Renal: rapidly progressive GN
  • Skin: livedo reticularis, nonhealing ulcers

Diagnosis
  • ANCA: PR3 (~70%), MPO (~20%)
  • Biopsy:
    • Skin (leukocytoclastic vasculitis)
    • Kidney (pauci-immune GN)
    • Lung (granulomatous vasculitis)

Management
  • Corticosteroids & immunomodulators (eg, cyclophosphamide)

ANCA = antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody; GN = glomerulonephritis; MPO = myeloperoxidase; PR3 = proteinase-3.

title: Multifocal atrial tachycardia
noteText:
Multifocal atrial tachycardia

Etiology
  • Exacerbation of pulmonary disease (eg, COPD)
  • Electrolyte disturbance (eg, hypokalemia)
  • Catecholamine surge (eg, sepsis)

Clinical findings
  • Typically asymptomatic
  • Rapid, irregular pulse
  • ECG: â¥3 P-wave forms & atrial rate >100/min

Treatment
  • Correct underlying disturbance
  • AV nodal blockade (eg, verapamil) if persistent

AV = atrioventricular; COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

title: Pulmonary infarct
Approach to patients with suspected PE
Venous air embolism
noteText:
Venous air embolism

Etiologies
  • Trauma, certain surgeries (eg, neurosurgical)
  • Central venous catheter manipulation
  • Barotrauma (eg, positive-pressure ventilation)

Clinical manifestations
  • Sudden-onset respiratory distress
  • Hypoxemia, obstructive shock, cardiac arrest

Management
  • Left lateral decubitus positioning
  • High-flow or hyperbaric oxygen

title: Recurrent pregnancy loss causes
noteText:
Causes of recurrent pregnancy loss

Structural
  • Uterine: fibroids, adhesions, polyps
  • Cervical insufficiency

Chromosomal
  • Aneuploidy
  • Translocations/rearrangements
  • Mosaicism

Immunologic/
hematologic
  • Hypercoagulable disorders (eg, antiphospholipid syndrome)
  • Alloimmune intolerance

Endocrine
  • Thyroid disease
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Hyperprolactinemia

Other
  • Advancing maternal age
  • Defective endometrial receptivity
  • Decreased ovarian reserve
  • Celiac disease

title: Corpulmonale
noteText:
Cor pulmonale

Etiology
  • RV failure due to pulmonary disease & resulting pulmonary HTN:
    • Chronic hypoxic vasoconstriction (eg, COPD, ILD, OHS)
    • Pulmonary thromboembolic disease
  • Absence of left-sided heart failure

Symptoms
  • Exertional fatigue, weakness, syncope (â cardiac output)
  • Exertional angina (â RV oxygen demand)
  • Venous congestion: abdominal distension, early satiety

Signs
  • Precordial heave due to RV hypertrophy
  • Loud P2 due to pulmonary HTN
  • Right-sided S3 &/or S4
  • Holosystolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation
  • JVD with HJR, ascites, peripheral edema, hepatomegaly

COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; HJR = hepatojugular reflux; HTN = hypertension; ILD = interstitial lung disease; JVD = jugular venous distension; OHS = obesity hypoventilation syndrome; RV = right ventricular.

title: Dx of suspected PE
noteText:
Modified Wells criteria for pretest probability
of pulmonary embolism

+3 points
  • Clinical signs of DVT
  • Alternate diagnosis less likely than PE

+1.5 points
  • Previous PE or DVT
  • Heart rate >100/min
  • Recent surgery or immobilization

+1 point
  • Hemoptysis
  • Cancer

Total score
  • â¤4 = PE unlikely
  • >4 = PE likely

DVT = deep vein thrombosis; PE = pulmonary embolism.

title: Evaluation of thyroid nodule
noteText: Certain sonographic features (microcalcifications, irregular margins, internal vascularity) carry a much higher risk of malignancy than others (cystic or spongiform lesions).  Thyroid nodules >1 cm with these high-risk sonographic featuresâand all noncystic thyroid nodules >2 cmâshould undergo fine-needle aspiration (FNA) biopsy.

title: Acute chest syndrome
noteText:
Acute chest syndrome

Pathogenesis
  • Vasoocclusion of pulmonary vasculature
  • Most commonly triggered by fat embolus (usually adults) or infection (usually children)

Diagnostic criteria
  • New pulmonary infiltrate on chest x-ray PLUS â¥1 of the following:
    • Increased work of breathing, cough, tachypnea, or wheezing
    • Temperature >38.5 C (101.3 F)
    • Hypoxemia
    • Chest pain

Initial treatment
  • Ceftriaxone & azithromycin
  • Intravenous fluids
  • Pain control

title: Mitral stenosis
noteText:
Mitral stenosis in adults

Etiology/epidemiology
  • Rheumatic heart disease (vast majority of cases)
  • Radiation induced (eg, previous lymphoma treatment)
  • More common in women (~80% of cases)

Clinical presentation
  • Exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, PND, hemoptysis
  • Pulmonary edema Â± right-sided heart failure (eg, LE edema)
  • Atrial fibrillation, â risk for systemic embolization

Diagnosis
  • Opening snap with middiastolic rumble at cardiac apex
  • Echocardiography: â LA size with normal LV size, â transmitral flow velocity

Treatment
  • Percutaneous valvotomy or surgical repair/replacement

LA = left atrial; LE = lower extremity; LV = left ventricular; PND = paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.

title: Interstitial lung disease
HHT
noteText:
Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (Osler-Weber-Rendu)

Vascular bed

Sequelae

CNS
  • Hemorrhagic CVA
  • Brain abscess: paradoxical bacterial embolization across pulmonary AVM

Mucocutaneous
  • Oral & cutaneous telangiectasia
  • Recurrent epistaxis

Lung
  • Pulmonary AVM: hemoptysis
  • PAH: right-sided heart failure

GI
  • Chronic GI bleed
  • Liver: portal hypertension, high-output heart failure

AVM =arteriovenous malformation; CVA = cerebrovascular accident; GI = gastrointestinal; PAH = pulmonary arterial hypertension.

title: Thyroid metabolism
noteText:
Major drug interactions of levothyroxine

â Levothyroxine
absorption
  • Bile acidâbinding agents (eg, cholestyramine)
  • Iron, calcium, aluminum hydroxide
  • Proton pump inhibitors, sucralfate

â TBG
concentration
  • Estrogen replacement, oral contraceptives
  • Tamoxifen

â TBG
concentration
  • Androgens, glucocorticoids
  • Anabolic steroids

â Thyroid hormone
metabolism
  • Rifampin
  • Phenytoin
  • Carbamazepine

TBG = thyroxine-binding globulin.

title: Prepulmonary and post pulmonary obstructive shock
Acute otitis media
noteText:
Acute otitis media

Risk factors
  • Age <2
  • Day care attendance
  • Smoke exposure
  • Lack of breastfeeding

Clinical features
  • Ear pain; may manifest as irritability, poor sleep/feeding in young or nonverbal children
  • Â± Fever

Diagnosis
  • Bulging TM
    AND/OR
  • Middle ear effusion (eg, air-fluid level, impaired mobility) plus TM erythema

TM = tympanic membrane.

title: Splenic abscess
noteText:
Clinical features of splenic abscess

Risk factors
  • Infection (eg, infective endocarditis) with hematogenous spread
  • Hemoglobinopathy (eg, sickle cell disease)
  • Immunosuppression (eg, HIV)
  • Intravenous drug use
  • Trauma

Clinical presentation
  • Classic triad of fever, leukocytosis & left upper-quadrant abdominal pain
  • Left-sided pleuritic chest pain with left pleural effusion commonly seen
  • Possible splenomegaly
  • Most commonly due to Staphylococcus, Streptococcus & Salmonella
  • Usually diagnosed by abdominal computed tomography scan

Treatment
  • Combination of broad-spectrum antibiotics & splenectomy
  • Possible percutaneous drainage in poor surgical candidates

title: Neonatal sepsis
noteText:
Neonatal sepsis

Etiology
  • Group B Streptococcus
  • Escherichia coli
  • Listeria monocytogenes (age <7 days)

Clinical features

  • Temperature instability (eg, fever, hypothermia)
  • CNS signs (eg, lethargy, irritability, apnea)
  • Poor feeding
  • Respiratory distress (eg, tachypnea, grunting)
  • Jaundice

Evaluation

  • Inflammatory markers (ie, CRP, ANC, procalcitonin)
  • Blood, urine, CSF cultures*

Treatment

  • Parenteral antibiotics (ampicillin & gentamicin)

* Limited evaluation (without CSF studies) & outpatient management may be considered in well-appearing, febrile neonates age >21 days.

ANC = absolute neutrophil count; CRP = c-reactive protein, CSF = cerebrospinal fluid.

title: Human bite injury
noteText:
Clenched-fist bite injury (fight bite)

Mechanism
  • Puncture through thin soft tissue overlying MCP joint
  • Enclosed bacterial proliferation under extensor tendon & within joint capsule

Pathogens
  • Oral flora (eg, Eikenella corrodens, beta-lactamaseâproducing anaerobes)
  • Skin flora (eg, streptococci, Staphylococcus aureus)

Clinical features
  • Small puncture wound appears minor initially; delay in care common
  • Septic arthritis: joint pain, swelling, erythema/warmth, restricted/painful ROM

Management
  • Urgent surgical irrigation & debridement
  • Antibiotics (eg, ampicillin-sulbactam [IV], amoxicillin-clavulanate [PO])

IV = intravenous; MCP = metacarpophalangeal; PO = orally; ROM = range of motion.

title: Outpatient Rx of CAP
noteText:
Bacterial aspiration pneumonia

Pathophysiology
  • Oropharyngeal/gastric microbes aspirated into lungs â host defenses overwhelmed due to large inoculum size

Major risk factors
  • Reduced consciousness (eg, anesthesia)
  • Dysphagia (eg, neuromuscular disorder)
  • Impaired glottic closure (eg, intubation)
  • Protracted vomiting
  • Poor dental hygiene

Clinical features
  • Fever & cough Â± foul-smelling sputum
  • Infiltrate in dependent portions of lung
  • Aerobic + anaerobic pathogens on sputum studies

Management
  • No empyema or lung abscess: treat for community-acquired pneumonia
  • Empyema or lung abscess present: extend coverage to include anaerobes (eg, ampicillin-sulbactam)

title: Mx of mammalian bite
noteText:
Management of mammalian bites

Wound care
  • Copious irrigation with saline
  • Debridement of dead tissue
  • Secondary intention healing*

Imaging
  • Radiographs if fracture or foreign body is suspected

Infection management
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanate if wound is infected or high risk for infection:
    • Puncture wound (eg, cat bite)
    • Involvement of face, hand/foot, joint, genitalia
    • Immunocompromised patient
    • Primary closure*
  • Tetanus prophylaxis if incompletely vaccinated or last dose â¥5 years ago
  • Rabies prophylaxis if high-risk animal cannot be quarantined/observed

*Primary closure may be considered for cosmetic reasons (eg, facial laceration) or involvement of deep musculoskeletal or vascular structures.

title: VIPoma
noteText:
Clinical features of VIPoma

Clinical presentation
  • Watery diarrhea
  • Hypo- or achlorhydria due to â gastric acid secretion
  • Associated flushing, lethargy, nausea, vomiting, muscle weakness/cramps

Laboratory findings
  • Hypokalemia (â intestinal potassium secretion)
  • Hypercalcemia (increased bone resorption)
  • Hyperglycemia due to increased glycogenolysis
  • Stool studies show secretory diarrhea with â sodium & osmolal gap <50 mOsm/kg

Diagnosis
  • Watery diarrhea with VIP level >75 pg/mL
  • CT or MRI scan of the abdomen to localize tumor in pancreas (usually in pancreatic tail)

VIP = vasoactive intestinal peptide.

title: Fat embolism syndrome
noteText:
Fat embolism syndrome

Etiology
  • Fractures of marrow-containing bones (eg, femur, pelvis)
  • Orthopedic procedures
  • Pancreatitis
  • Sickle cell disease

Clinical presentation
  • Onset usually 24-72 hr following inciting event
  • Classic triad:
    • Respiratory distress (>90%): hypoxemia, dyspnea, tachypnea
    • Neurologic dysfunction (>50%): altered mentation, seizures
    • Petechial rash (<50%): head, trunk, subconjunctiva

Diagnosis
  • Based on clinical presentation

Prevention & treatment
  • Early fracture immobilization & fixation
  • Supportive care

title: TRALI vs TACO
noteText:
Acute respiratory failure due to transfusion

Feature

TRALI

TACO

Pulmonary symptoms

Acute dyspnea

Acute dyspnea

Auscultation

Crackles/rales

Crackles/rales Â± S3

Chest x-ray

Diffuse bilateral infiltrates

Diffuse bilateral infiltrates

Blood pressure

â To normal

Normal to â

Jugular venous distension

Absent

Present

Ejection fraction

Normal

Decreased

BNP

Normal

High

BNP = brain natriuretic peptide; TACO = transfusion-associated circulatory overload; TRALI = transfusion-related acute lung injury.

title: Conditions that alter TBG concentration
noteText:
Conditions that alter TBG concentration

Increased TBG

Decreased TBG
  • Estrogens (eg, pregnancy, OCs, HRT) & estrogenic medications (eg, tamoxifen)
  • Acute hepatitis
  • Androgenic hormones
  • High-dose glucocorticoids/hypercortisolism
  • Hypoproteinemia (eg, nephrotic syndrome, starvation)
  • Chronic liver disease

HRT = hormone replacement therapy; OCs = oral contraceptives; TBG = thyroxine-binding globulin.

title: Conditions associated with aspiration pneumonia
noteText:
Conditions associated with aspiration pneumonia

Trigger

Related conditions

Reduced
consciousness
  • Sedatives or antipsychotics
  • Illicit drugs or alcohol
  • Anesthesia
  • Generalized seizure

Dysphagia
  • Neurologic disorders
  • Esophageal motility defects
  • Protracted vomiting
  • Gastroesophageal reflux

Pharyngeal or
glottal dysfunction
  • Tracheostomy
  • Intubation
  • Nasogastric feeding

Dental issues
  • Gingivitis
  • Poor dental hygiene

title: OSA
noteText:
Obstructive sleep apnea

Pathophysiology
  • Relaxation of pharyngeal muscles, leading to closure of airway
  • Loud snoring with periods of apnea

Symptoms
  • Daytime somnolence
  • Nonrestorative sleep with frequent awakenings
  • Morning headaches
  • Affective & cognitive symptoms

Sequelae
  • Systemic hypertension
  • Pulmonary hypertension & right-sided heart failure

title: High altitude illness
Ankylosing spondylitis
noteText:
Symptoms/signs of ankylosing spondylitis
  • Low back pain (onset age <40, insidious onset, improves with exercise but not with rest, pain at night)
  • Hip & buttock pain
  • Limited chest expansion & spinal mobility
  • Enthesitis (inflammation at the site of insertion of a tendon to the bone)
  • Systemic symptoms (eg, fever, chills, fatigue, weight loss)
  • Acute anterior uveitis (unilateral pain, photophobia, blurry vision)

title: Cocaine induced diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
noteText:
Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage

Etiology & pathogenesis
  • Pulmonary capillaritis: ANCA vasculitis, SLE, antiphospholipid antibodies
  • Bland hemorrhage: mitral stenosis, anticoagulation
  • Alveolar damage: viral pneumonitis, ARDS, drug-induced (eg, cocaine, amiodarone)

Clinical presentation & diagnosis
  • Dyspnea, hypoxemia, hemoptysis (absent in ~50%) & blood loss anemia
  • CXR or CT: diffuse ground-glass opacities
  • Bronchoscopy: progressive blood on serial lavage

Management
  • Treat underlying (eg, rheumatologic, infectious) cause
  • Supportive care: oxygen, mechanical ventilation; avoid anticoagulation

ANCA = antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody; ARDS = acute respiratory distress syndrome; CXR = chest x-ray; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus.

Diffuse airspace opacification

Definition: Alveolar filling processes that can involve multiple lobes

Fluid
  • Transudative edema: cardiogenic
  • Exudative edema: noncardiogenic (ARDS)

Cells
  • Neutrophils (pus): infectious pneumonia
  • Lymphocytes & macrophages: hypersensitivity pneumonitis
  • Eosinophils: acute eosinophilic pneumonia
  • Malignant cells: carcinomatosis

Blood
  • Diffuse alveolar hemorrhage
  • Aspirated nonalveolar hemorrhage

Others
  • Fat: lipoid pneumonia (eg, vaping oils)
  • Protein: pulmonary alveolar proteinosis

ARDS = acute respiratory distress syndrome.

title: Tension pneumothorax
GERD
noteText:
Gastroesophageal reflux disease

Pathophysiology

  • Decreased tone or excessive transient relaxations of LES
  • Anatomic disruption to gastroesophageal junction (eg, hiatal hernia)
  • â Risk with obesity, pregnancy, smoking, alcohol intake

Manifestations

  • Regurgitation of acidic material in mouth
  • Heartburn
  • Odynophagia (often indicates reflux esophagitis)
  • Extraesophageal manifestations: cough, hoarseness, wheezing

Complications
  • Esophageal: erosive esophagitis, Barrett esophagus, strictures
  • Extraesophageal: asthma exacerbation, laryngitis

Initial treatment

  • Lifestyle (eg, weight loss) & dietary changes
  • H2R blocker or PPI

H2R = histamine 2 receptor; LES = lower esophageal sphincter; PPI = proton pump inhibitor.

title: Foreign body aspiration
noteText:
Foreign body aspiration

Clinical features

  • Â± History of choking event with sudden-onset cough
  • Symptoms depend on location
    • Trachea/main bronchus: acute respiratory distress, cyanosis, stridor (trachea), hemoptysis (bronchial)
    • Lower airway: chronic/recurrent cough

Examination findings
  • Focal, unilateral &/or monophonic wheeze
  • Focal area of diminished breath sounds

X-ray findings

  • Hyperinflation of affected side Â± mediastinal shift toward unaffected side
  • Atelectasis if complete obstruction
  • Â± Foreign body

Complications
  • Recurrent pneumonia
  • Bronchiectasis

Management
  • Bronchoscopic removal

title: Bronchiectasis
noteText:
Bronchiectasis

Clinical features
  • Pathophysiology: airway insult (eg, infection, inhalation) with impaired clearance (eg, mucostasis, immunodeficiency)
  • Chronic: daily production of voluminous, thick Â± blood-tinged mucus
  • Acute exacerbations: recurrent infections with mucopurulent sputum Â± frank hemoptysis

Etiologies/contributory conditions
  • Airway obstruction (eg, cancer, foreign body) & mucostasis (eg, CF, ABPA)
  • Immunodeficiency (eg, âIg) & autoinflammatory disease (eg, SjÃ¶gren syndrome)
  • Chronic/past infection (eg, mycobacteria) or toxic inhalation

Evaluation
  • High-resolution CT scan of the chest (needed for diagnosis): airway dilation
  • Pulmonary function testing: obstructive pattern
  • Investigation of etiologies (eg, Ig levels, respiratory cultures, bronchial obstruction)

Treatment
  • Address underlying disorders (eg, Ig replacement)
  • Airway clearance (eg, chest physiotherapy), mucolytics
  • Antibiotics to suppress bacterial overgrowth & treat exacerbations

ABPA = allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis; CF = cystic fibrosis; Ig = immunoglobulin; RA = rheumatoid arthritis.

title: Drug induced neutropenia
noteText:
Drug-induced neutropenia

Common triggers
  • Methimazole, propylthiouracil
  • Trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole
  • Clozapine
  • Sulfasalazine

Mechanism
  • Immune mediated: drug or metabolite binds to neutrophils & triggers a cell-mediated or humoral response
  • Bone marrow toxicity: drug or metabolite directly or indirectly damages granulocyte precursors

Manifestations
  • Usually within 3 months of drug exposure
  • Oropharyngeal ulceration Â± fever
  • Other cell lines unaffected

Management
  • Discontinue inciting medication
  • Antibiotics in setting of treatable infection
  • Consider granulocyte colony-stimulating factor

title: Lung transplant rejection
noteText:
Lung transplant rejection
 

Acute

(cell-mediated response)

Chronic

(mixed cell-mediated
& antibody response)

Clinical
presentation
  • â¤6 months after transplant
  • Asymptomatic or fever, cough, dyspnea
  • Months to years after transplant
  • Progressive cough & dyspnea
  • History of acute episodes

Diagnosis
  • BAL to rule out infection
  • Biopsy: submucosal lymphocyticinfiltrate, perivascular inflammation
  • Obstructive pattern on PFT
  • BAL to rule out infection
  • Biopsy: submucosal lymphocytic infiltrate, bronchiolitis obliterans

Management
  • High-dose glucocorticoids
  • Supportive management
  • Possible repeat transplant

BAL = bronchoalveolar lavage; PFT = pulmonary function testing.

title: Risk factors for CAP
noteText:
Risk factors for community-acquired pneumonia

Impaired immunity
  • Age >65
  • HIV
  • Diabetes mellitus

Impaired pulmonary function
  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease
  • Bronchiectasis/cystic fibrosis
  • Recent upper respiratory viral infection
  • Smoking

Increased microaspiration
  • Substance/alcohol use disorder
  • Seizure disorder or stroke
  • Esophageal dysmotility

Medications
  • Acid suppressants
  • Sedatives
  • Immunomodulatory agents

title: Mx of drowning
Ludwig angina
Mx of neutropenic fever
Bacterial meningitis
noteText:
Bacterial meningitis

Risk group

Common organisms

Empiric antibiotics
 

Age 2-50

Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis

Vancomycin + 3rd-generation cephalosporin

Age >50

S pneumoniae, N meningitidis, Listeria

Vancomycin + ampicillin + 3rd-generation cephalosporin
 

Immunocompromised

S pneumoniae, N meningitidis, Listeria, gram-negative rods

Vancomycin + ampicillin + cefepime

Neurosurgery/penetrating skull trauma

Gram-negative rods, MRSA, coagulase-negative staphylococci

Vancomycin + cefepime
  • 3rd-generation cephalosporins: ceftriaxone or cefotaxime
  • Alternatives to cefepime: ceftazidime or meropenem
  • Alternative to ampicillin: trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for Listeria

MRSA = methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus.

title: Lymphangitis
noteText:
Lymphangitis

Epidemiology
  • Cutaneous injury â pathogen invasion of lymphatics in deep dermis
  • Streptococcus pyogenes & MSSA

Manifestations
  • Tender, erythematous streaks proximal to wound
  • Regional tender lymphadenopathy (lymphadenitis)
  • Systemic symptoms (eg, fever, tachycardia)

Treatment
  • Cephalexin

MSSA = methicillin-sensitive Staphylococcus aureus.

title: Asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy
noteText:
Asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy

Definition

  • â¥100,000 CFU/mL bacteria

Risk
factors
  • Pregestational diabetes mellitus
  • History of urinary tract infection
  • Multiparity

Common
pathogens
  • Escherichia coli (most common)
  • Klebsiella
  • Enterobacter
  • Group B Streptococcus

Potential complications
  • Acute pyelonephritis
  • Preterm labor & delivery

Treatment
  • Cefpodoxime
  • Fosfomycin
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanate
  • Nitrofurantoin*

*Avoided in first & third trimesters.

CFU = colony-forming units.

title: D/D of ADHD
noteText:
Conditions mimicking attention deficit hyperactivity disorder*

Diagnosis

Historical clues

Initial evaluation

Learning disability
  • Symptoms predominantly in academic setting
  • Neuropsychological testing

Hearing impairment
  • Delayed speech
  • Audiology evaluation

Mental health conditions

(eg, anxiety, depression, ODD)
  • Excessive worrying (anxiety), pervasive sadness (depression), defiance (ODD)
  • Interview & standardized screening questionnaires

Obstructive sleep apnea
  • Snoring, daytime sleepiness
  • Obesity
  • Sleep study

Absence seizure
  • Discrete episodes unresponsive to stimuli
  • Automatisms
  • EEG

*Symptoms of hyperactivity (eg, inability to sit still, frequent interruptions) &/or inattention (eg, distractibility, difficulty following directions).

EEG = electroencephalogram; ODD = oppositional defiant disorder.

title: Chemical pneumonitis vs aspiration pneumonia
noteText:
Aspiration: pneumonitis vs pneumonia
 

Chemical pneumonitis

Aspiration pneumonia

Cause
  • Inhalation of gastric acid leads to direct chemical injury of bronchial & alveolar epithelial cells
  • Inhalation of large inoculate of oropharyngeal or gastric microbes overwhelms host pulmonary defenses

Onset
  • Sudden: within min or hr
  • Indolent: a few days to weeks

Manifestations
  • Abrupt-onset dyspnea, cough, hypoxemia
  • Low-grade fever
  • Diffuse crackles/wheezes
  • Infiltrate in dependent portion of lung
  • Fever
  • Cough with putrid sputum
  • Infiltrate in dependent portion of lung

Management
  • Supportive care
  • Oropharyngeal suction if event is witnessed
  • Antibiotics (eg, ceftriaxone plus azithromycin) that target community-acquired pneumonia pathogens

title: Acute bronchitis
noteText:
Acute bronchitis

Etiology
  • Preceding respiratory illness (90% viral)

Clinical presentation
  • Cough for >5 days to 3 weeks (Â± purulent sputum)
  • Absent systemic findings (eg, fever, chills)
  • Wheezing or rhonchi, chest wall tenderness

Diagnosis & treatment
  • Clinical diagnosis, CXR only when pneumonia suspected
  • Symptomatic treatment (eg, NSAIDs &/or bronchodilators)
  • Antibiotics not recommended

CXR = chest x-ray; NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

title: Pediatric obstructive sleep apnea
noteText:
Pediatric obstructive sleep apnea

Pathophysiology
  • Adenotonsillar hypertrophy

Clinical manifestations
  • Night symptoms
    • Loud snoring, pauses in breathing, gasping
    • Enuresis, parasomnias (eg, sleepwalking, sleep terrors)
  • Day symptoms
    • Inappropriate naps or falling asleep during school
    • Irritability, inattention, learning problems, behavioral problems
    • Mouth breathing, nasal speech

Complications
  • Poor growth (ie, failure to thrive)
  • Poor school performance
  • Cardiopulmonary (eg, hypertension, structural heart changes)

Management
  • Tonsillectomy & adenoidectomy

title: High altitude pulmonary edema
noteText:
Characteristics of high-altitude pulmonary edema versus multifocal pneumonia

High-altitude pulmonary edema

Multifocal pneumonia
  • Recent arrival at high altitude (<1 week)
  • Absent or mild leukocytosis
  • Procalcitonin normal
  • Marked early improvement with O2
  • Persistent stay at high altitude
  • Leukocytes >15,000 mm3 with bands
  • Procalcitonin elevated
  • Minimal early improvement with O2

title: Mx of parapneumonic effusion in pediatric patient
noteText: Drainage is indicated for moderate or large effusions or if the patient is experiencing respiratory distress (this differs from the adult population, in which the need for drainage is determined mostly by fluid analysis).

title: Pediatric obstructive sleep apnea
noteText:
Pediatric obstructive sleep apnea

Pathophysiology
  • Adenotonsillar hypertrophy

Clinical manifestations
  • Night symptoms
    • Loud snoring, pauses in breathing, gasping
    • Enuresis, parasomnias (eg, sleepwalking, sleep terrors)
  • Day symptoms
    • Inappropriate naps or falling asleep during school
    • Irritability, inattention, learning problems, behavioral problems
    • Mouth breathing, nasal speech

Complications
  • Poor growth (ie, failure to thrive)
  • Poor school performance
  • Cardiopulmonary (eg, hypertension, structural heart changes)

Management
  • Tonsillectomy & adenoidectomy

title: Complication of solid organ transplant
noteText:
Major complications of solid organ transplantation

Infectious
  • Nosocomial infections (eg, hospital-acquired pneumonia)
  • Opportunistic pathogens (eg, CMV, PCP, Aspergillus)

Immunologic
  • Hyperacute rejection: ABO mismatch
  • Acute rejection*: cell or antibody-mediated
  • Chronic rejection: fibrosis of graft structures (eg, bronchiolitis obliterans of airways)

Postoperative
  • Surgical site: anastomotic dehiscence
  • Primary graft dysfunction: ARDS, ATN

Other
  • Drug toxicities: nephrotoxicity (calcineurin inhibitors), osteoporosis (corticosteroids)
  • Malignancy: posttransplant lymphoproliferative disorder (EBV)

*Acute cellular rejection is the most common type in the first 90 days but can occur at any time after transplant.

ARDS = acute respiratory distress syndrome; ATN = acute tubular necrosis; CMV = cytomegalovirus; EBV = Epstein-Barr virus; PCP = Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia.

title: Effects of positioning in patient with pneumonia
Bronchiectasis
noteText:
Bronchiectasis

Clinical features
  • Pathophysiology: airway insult (eg, infection, inhalation) with impaired clearance (eg, mucostasis, immunodeficiency)
  • Chronic: daily production of voluminous, thick Â± blood-tinged mucus
  • Acute exacerbations: recurrent infections with mucopurulent sputum Â± frank hemoptysis

Etiologies/contributory conditions
  • Airway obstruction (eg, cancer, foreign body) & mucostasis (eg, CF, ABPA)
  • Immunodeficiency (eg, âIg) & autoinflammatory disease (eg, SjÃ¶gren syndrome)
  • Chronic/past infection (eg, mycobacteria) or toxic inhalation

Evaluation
  • High-resolution CT scan of the chest (needed for diagnosis): airway dilation
  • Pulmonary function testing: obstructive pattern
  • Investigation of etiologies (eg, Ig levels, respiratory cultures, bronchial obstruction)

Treatment
  • Address underlying disorders (eg, Ig replacement)
  • Airway clearance (eg, chest physiotherapy), mucolytics
  • Antibiotics to suppress bacterial overgrowth & treat exacerbations

ABPA = allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis; CF = cystic fibrosis; Ig = immunoglobulin; RA = rheumatoid arthritis.

title: Empyema
noteText:
Empyema

Etiology
  • Bacterial invasion of pleural space resulting in fibrinopurulent consolidation
  • Usually due to progression of a complicated parapneumonic effusion

Common
organisms
  • Oral anaerobic bacteria (likely most common)
  • Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus

Clinical
features
  • Symptoms of pneumonia (eg, fever, dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain)
  • Insidious presentation (eg, 1-2 weeks or more), weight loss
  • Laboratory evidence of inflammation (eg, leukocytosis, thrombocytosis)

Management*
  • Chest tube drainage when possible (ie, empyema is free flowing)
  • Intrapleural fibrinolytic drugs (eg, tPA/DNase) may assist drainage
  • Surgical decortication for highly fibrotic, loculated effusions

*In addition to antibiotics.

tPA/DNase = tissue plasminogen activator/recombinant deoxyribonuclease.

  • Pooled subglottic secretions
  • Paralysis & excessive sedation
  • Excessive patient movement while intubated
  • Frequent ventilator circuit changes

H2R = histamine-2 receptor; PPI = proton pump inhibitor.

  • Parainfluenza virus most common

  • Clinical*

  • Subacute fever, night sweats, weight loss

  • Cavitary infiltrates with air-fluid levels

title: Empyema
Aspergilloma
noteText:

Chronic pulmonary aspergillosis*

  • Immunocompromise (neutropenia, glucocorticoids, HIV)
  • Lung disease/damage (cavitary tuberculosis)

Manifestations
  • Triad of fever, chest pain, hemoptysis

  • Positive cultures
  • Positive cell wall biomarkers (galactomannan, Î²-D-glucan)
  • >3 months: weight loss (>90%), cough, hemoptysis, fatigue

  • Positive Aspergillus IgG serology

Management
  • Voriconazole Â± caspofungin
  • Resect aspergilloma (if possible)
  • Azole medication (voriconazole)
  • Embolization (if severe hemoptysis)

*Simple aspergilloma (fungus ball in preexisting lung cavity) is a form of chronic pulmonary aspergillosis but is usually quiescent with occasional hemoptysis.

pathogenesis

& diagnosis

title: Bronchiolitis
noteText:
Bronchiolitis

Pathophysiology
  • Viral-induced inflammation of small, distal airways
  • Bronchiolar obstruction from sloughed epithelial cells, leukocytes & mucus
  • RSV most common cause

Clinical presentation
  • Age <2
  • Antecedent nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, cough

  • Bilateral hyperinflation, increased interstitial markings & peribronchial cuffing

Treatment
  • Supportive (eg, nasal suctioning, hydration, supplemental oxygen)

Complications
  • Apnea (age <2 months)
  • Respiratory failure

Prevention
  • Nirsevimab for all children age <8 months

RSV = respiratory syncytial virus.

title: Hypernatremia Mx
Cyanide poisoning
noteText:
Cyanide poisoning

Common etiologies
  • Structure fires (eg, combustion of plastics)
  • Occupational exposure (eg, mining)
  • Cyanide-containing medications (eg, sodium nitroprusside)

Pathophysiology
  • Inhibits oxidative phosphorylation & forces anaerobic metabolism
  • Rapidly lethal if untreated

Clinical features
  • Hypertension, tachycardia, tachypnea â circulatory collapse, death
  • Headache, confusion, anxiety â seizures, coma
  • Cherry-red skin
  • Elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis with â lactic acid

Management
  • Decontamination
  • Supportive care (eg, 100% oxygen, intravenous fluids, vasopressors)
  • Empiric treatment with hydroxocobalamin Â± sodium thiosulfate*

*Sodium nitrite + sodium thiosulfate is an alternate treatment but is contraindicated in carbon monoxide poisoning.

Hypertensive crisis

Hypertensive
urgency
  • Severe hypertension (â¥180/120 mm Hg)
  • No evidence of end-organ damage

Hypertensive
emergency
  • Severe hypertension with end-organ damage:
    • Cardiovascular: angina, myocardial infarction, aortic dissection
    • CNS: encephalopathy, cerebral infarct/hemorrhage
    • Kidney: acute hypertensive nephrosclerosis
    • Lung: pulmonary edema
    • Retina: papilledema, flame-shaped hemorrhages, exudates

Manifestations of cyanide accumulation & toxicity
  • Skin: flushing (cherry-red color), cyanosis (occurs later)
  • CNS: headache, altered mental status, seizures, coma
  • Cardiovascular: arrhythmias
  • Respiratory: tachypnea followed by respiratory depression, pulmonary edema
  • Gastrointestinal: abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
  • Renal: metabolic acidosis (from lactic acidosis), kidney failure

title: Magnesium toxicity
noteText:
Magnesium toxicity

Causes
  • Renal impairment (ie, decreased Mg excretion)
  • Increased Mg intake (eg, IV Mg sulfate, Mg-based laxatives/enemas)

Clinical features
  • Neuromuscular: â reflexes, weakness, paralysis, respiratory failure
  • Cardiovascular: hypotension, bradycardia, conduction defects
  • Electrolyte: hypocalcemia

Management
  • Discontinue Mg-containing medications
  • IV fluids Â± loop diuretics
  • IV calcium for neuromuscular & cardiac symptoms
  • Hemodialysis in severe renal impairment

IV = intravenous; Mg = magnesium.

title: Evaluation of polyuria

Hb A = hemoglobin A; Hb S = hemoglobin S; RBC = red blood cell.

title: Refeeding syndrome
Metabolic alkalosis
noteText:
Hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis

Common etiologies
  • Gastric suction or severe vomiting
  • Loop or thiazide diuretic overuse

Pathophysiology
  • Gastric or renal H+ losses initiate alkalosis
  • Volume depletion activates RAAS
  • â Renal K+ & H+ losses cause hypokalemia & worsen alkalosis
  • Relatively greater loss of Clâ than Na+ â profound Clâ depletion
  • â Clâ impairs renal HCO3â excretion to perpetuate alkalosis

Management
  • Remove or treat initiating factor
  • Clâ replenishment with normal saline corrects alkalosis

RAAS = renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.

Parathyroid hormone

Vitamin D
  • â Intestinal absorption of calcium & phosphate
  • â Renal reabsorption of calcium & phosphate
  • â Parathyroid hormone secretion
  • â Mineralization of bone

Calcitonin
  • â Bone resorption
  • â Renal calcium reabsorption

  • Constitutional symptoms (fever,* malaise)

*Manifestations of LÃ¶fgren syndrome.

AV = atrioventricular; LFT = liver function test.

title: Water deprivation test
Evaluation of suspected polyuria
Physiologic defense against hypoglycemia
Cushing syndrome
noteText:
Features of Cushing syndrome

Clinical manifestations
  • Central obesity
  • Skin atrophy & wide, purplish striae
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Hypertension
  • Glucose intolerance
  • Skin hyperpigmentation (if due to ACTH excess)
  • Depression, anxiety

Diagnosis
  • 24-hr urinary cortisol excretion
  • Late-night salivary cortisol assay
  • Low-dose dexamethasone suppression test
Initial testing for suspected hypercortisolism can include a 24-hour assay for urine free cortisol, a late-night salivary cortisol measurement, or a low-dose dexamethasone suppression test.  Once hypercortisolism is established, an ACTH level can determine whether it is ACTH-dependent (Cushing disease, ectopic ACTH production) or ACTH-independent (adrenal disease, exogenous glucocorticoid intake).  Patients with an elevated ACTH should have a high-dose dexamethasone suppression test to determine whether ACTH production is pituitary (dexamethasone suppresses cortisol) or ectopic (dexamethasone does not suppress cortisol).

title: Dx of adrenal insufficiency
noteText:
The initial evaluation should include an 8 AM serum cortisol and plasma ACTH.

  • A low cortisol level (<5 Âµg/dL) with high ACTH confirms PAI, and a low cortisol level with low ACTH suggests central (pituitary [secondary] or hypothalamic [tertiary]) adrenal insufficiency. 
  • A high or high-normal cortisol level (>15 Âµg/dL) essentially rules out PAI. 
  • Some patients with manifestations strongly suggestive of PAI may have low-normal cortisol levels (5-15 Âµg/dL) that fall within the normal range, as seen here. 

Because of this, and because the ACTH assay can take several days, an ACTH stimulation test (cosyntropin test) is usually performed concurrently to rapidly confirm the diagnosis.  Cosyntropin is a synthetic ACTH analog.

  • Infusion of a 250-Âµg bolus of cosyntropin normally triggers a rapid increase in serum cortisol. 
  • In contrast, patients with PAI will not have a significant rise. 
  • In addition, most patients with central adrenal insufficiency have a blunted (minimal or suboptimal) response due to adrenal atrophy from chronically low ACTH. 
  • If results are indeterminate, further pituitary function testing can be considered.

title: Hypopituitarism
noteText:
Clinical features of hypopituitarism

Etiology

  • Pituitary causes
    • Primary (eg, adenoma) or metastatic mass
    • Infiltration (eg, hemochromatosis, lymphocytic hypophysitis)
    • Hemorrhage (pituitary apoplexy) or infarction (Sheehan syndrome)
  • Hypothalamic causes
    • Mass lesions
    • Radiation therapy
    • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
    • Trauma to skull base
    • Infections (tuberculosis meningitis)

Clinical presentation

  • ACTH deficiency (secondary adrenal insufficiency)
    • Postural hypotension, tachycardia, fatigue, weight loss, hypoglycemia, eosinophilia
  • Hypothyroidism (central)
    • Fatigue, cold intolerance, constipation, dry skin, bradycardia, slowed deep tendon reflexes
  • Gonadotropins
    • Women: Amenorrhea, infertility
    • Men: Infertility, loss of libido

title: Primary hyperaldosteronism
noteText:
Primary hyperaldosteronism (Conn syndrome)

Clinical features
  • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia (~60%) or unilateral adenoma
  • Difficult-to-control hypertension
  • Hypokalemia & metabolic alkalosis*
  • No extravascular volume overload (aldosterone escape)

Diagnosis
  • Elevated plasma aldosterone & low plasma renin (ratio >20)
  • Absence of aldosterone suppression with oral saline load
  • CT scan of adrenal glands to determine bilateral hyperplasia vs adenoma

Treatment
  • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia: MRA (eg, spironolactone)
  • Unilateral adenoma: surgical resection preferred

*In some patients, the characteristic electrolyte abnormalities are apparent only after a thiazide
is initiated for blood pressure management.

MRA = mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist.

title: Adrenal crisis
noteText:

Headache, visual field defects, cranial nerve defects

Colon polyps/cancer, diverticulosis

Galactorrhea, hypogonadism, diabetes mellitus, hypertriglyceridemia

Enlarged tongue, thyroid, salivary glands, liver, spleen, kidney, prostate

title: Risk factors for fatal asthma
noteText:
Fatal asthma: risk factors

Patient history
  • Prior respiratory failure: NIPPV, intubation, ICU admission
  • Poor asthma control: â inhaler use, frequent oral corticosteroids or acute care visits

Clinical status (impending respiratory failure)
  • Examination: respirations >30/min, SaO2 â¤90%, accessory muscle use, AMS, "silent chest"
  • ABG: â or inappropriately normal PaCO2 relative to WOB
  • Peak flow: â¤50% of baseline

ABG = arterial blood gas; AMS = altered mental status; ICU = intensive care unit; NIPPV = noninvasive positive pressure ventilation; SaO2 = arterial saturation of oxygen; WOB = work of breathing.

title: Cryoglobulinemia
noteText:
Systemic small-vessel vasculitides
 

Usual vasculitic patterns & associated findings

Laboratory & biopsy findings

Primary

ANCA-associated vasculitis
  • Palpable purpura, GN, PN
  • 3 types with variable lung, heart & sinus involvement
  • ANCA (PR3 or MPO)
  • Pauci-immune vasculitis (Â± granulomas)

IgA vasculitis (Henoch-SchÃ¶nlein purpura)
  • Palpable purpura, GN, abdominal pain
  • More common in children
  • No serologic test
  • IgA immunofluorescence on
    skin or kidney biopsy

Anti-GBM disease
  • GN Â± pulmonary hemorrhage
  • No palpable purpura or PN
  • Serum anti-GBM antibodies
  • Linear IgG on kidney biopsy

Secondary

Cryoglobulinemic vasculitis (MCS)
  • Palpable purpura, GN, PN
  • Hepatitis C, HIV, autoimmune disease* (SLE, RA)
  • +Cryoglobulins, +rheumatoid factor, low complement
  • +Viral or autoimmune serologies

Drug-induced vasculitis
  • Most common cause, can be seen with most drug classes
  • Often isolated to one organ
  • No specific test
  • Â± Antihistone or ANCA, low complement

*Vasculitis secondary to autoimmune disease can be mediated by either cryoglobulins or other nonprecipitating immune complexes.

ANCA = antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies; GBM = glomerular basement membrane; GN = glomerulonephritis; MCS = mixed cryoglobulinemia syndrome; MPO = myeloperoxidase; PN = peripheral neuropathy; PR3 = proteinase 3; RA = rheumatoid arthritis; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus.

title: Ideal screening programme
noteText:
Ideal screening program

Disease characteristics
  • Common
  • Serious
  • Long asymptomatic phase
  • Correctable if identified early

Patient characteristics
  • High prevalence in screened population
  • Appropriate age range & gender

Test characteristics
  • Low cost relative to disease severity
  • High sensitivity & specificity
  • Acceptable to broad range of patients

Program characteristics
  • Identifies population to be screened
  • Avoids "overdiagnosis" (detects benign/indolent disease)
  • Avoids "lead-time" bias (detects disease early but does not alter ultimate prognosis)
  • Improves outcomes of screened vs nonscreened population

title: WAGR syndrome
noteText:
WAGR syndrome/11p deletion syndrome

Pathogenesis
  • Gene deletion on chromosome 11p13

Clinical
features
  • Wilms tumor
  • Aniridia
  • Genitourinary abnormalities
  • Range of developmental delays

title: Contrast associated AKI
noteText:
Contrast-associated acute kidney injury

Presentation
  • Highest risk with arterial iodinated contrast (eg, coronary angiogram)
  • Creatinine elevation 24-48 hr after contrast exposure, gradually returning to baseline within 3-7 days
  • Clinical diagnosis based on timing & trajectory above (ie, biopsy rarely needed)

Risk factors
  • Preexisting chronic kidney disease (especially diabetic nephropathy)
  • Decreased kidney perfusion (eg, NSAIDs, hypovolemia, venous congestion)
  • High contrast load

Pathophysiology
  • Prerenal vasoconstriction & direct tubular cytotoxicity
  • Prerenal state (eg, FeNa <1%) with concurrent necrosis (eg, muddy brown casts)

Prevention
  • Optimize kidney perfusion (eg, intravenous saline, avoidance of NSAIDs)
  • Minimize contrast load

FeNa = fractional excretion of sodium; NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug.

title: Von Hippel lindau disease
noteText:
Von Hippel-Lindau disease

Etiology
  • Mutation in the VHL tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance

Manifestations
  • Cerebellar & retinal hemangioblastomas
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma (clear cell subtype)

Management

  • Surveillance for associated malignancies
    • Eye/retinal examination
    • Plasma or urine metanephrines
    • MRI of the brain & spine
    • MRI of the abdomen
  • Tumor resection

title: Complication of nephrotic syndrome
noteText:
Complications of nephrotic syndrome*
 

Mechanism

Hypercoagulability
(â thromboembolism risk)
  • Urinary loss of anticoagulant proteins (eg, antithrombin III)
  • Hepatic synthesis of prothrombotic proteins (eg, fibrinogen)

Hyperlipidemia
(â atherosclerosis risk)
  • Hepatic synthesis of lipoproteins

Infection
  • Urinary loss of immunoglobulins & opsonizing factors

Protein malnutrition
  • Negative nitrogen balance

Intravascular volume depletion
  • Low oncotic pressure

*Nephrotic syndrome results from glomerular filtration barrier (eg, podocyte) injury that leads to heavy proteinuria (>3.5 g/day), hypoalbuminemia & peripheral edema.

title: RCC
noteText:
Renal cell carcinoma

Epidemiology
  • Age >50
  • Risk â with smoking, obesity, chemical exposure

Manifestations
  • Hematuria: microscopic or gross Â± clots
  • Abdominal/flank mass
  • Flank pain
  • Left-sided varicocele that does not decompress
  • Paraneoplastic syndrome (eg, EPO production, â calcium)

Diagnosis
  • Abdominal CT scan
  • Partial/complete nephrectomy (for histology)

EPO = erythropoietin.

Renal cell carcinoma
  • Flank pain, hematuria & a palpable abdominal renal mass
  • Scrotal varicoceles (left sided)
  • Paraneoplastic symptoms
    • Anemia or erythrocytosis
    • Thrombocytosis
    • Fever
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Cachexia

title: Bladder cancer
noteText:
Bladder cancer

Epidemiology
  • >90% urothelial carcinoma
  • â Risk with smokers & exposure to industrial carcinogens

Manifestations
  • Painless hematuria throughout micturition
  • Irritative voiding symptoms (eg, frequency, urgency, dysuria)
  • Regional pain

Diagnosis
  • Flexible cystoscopy with biopsy (gold standard)
  • Urine cytology

Staging
  • TURBT
  • Upper urinary tract imaging (eg, IVP, MRI, CT scan)

Treatment
  • No muscle invasion: TURBT & intravesical immunotherapy
  • Muscle invasion: radical cystectomy & systemic chemotherapy
  • Metastatic: systemic chemotherapy & immunotherapy

IVP = intravenous pyelogram; TURBT = transurethral resection of bladder tumor.

title: Wims tumour
noteText:
Wilms tumor (nephroblastoma)

Epidemiology
  • Most common renal malignancy in children
  • Peak age 2-5
  • Usually sporadic but may be associated with:

Clinical
features
  • Unilateral abdominal mass (usually asymptomatic)
  • Â± Abdominal pain, hypertension, hematuria

Treatment
  • Surgical excision
  • Chemotherapy Â± radiation therapy

Prognosis
  • 90% survival rate with treatment

title: Causes of hematuria
noteText:
Indications for cystoscopy

Hematuria*
  • Gross hematuria
  • Microscopic hematuria with risk factors for urothelial malignancy

Infection
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection
  • Infection nonresponsive to antibiotic therapy

Lower urinary tract symptoms
  • Obstructive symptoms with suspicion for stricture, stone
  • Irritative symptoms without infection

Other suspicion for malignancy
  • Abnormal bladder imaging (eg, CT scan)
  • Abnormal urine cytology

*Not needed if evidence for glomerular bleeding (eg, red blood cell casts).

Diagnosis

GBM = glomerular basement membrane.

Nocturnal enuresis in children
 

Primary

Secondary

Definition
  • Nighttime incontinence at age â¥5 without prior prolonged period of continence
  • Nighttime incontinence at age â¥5 after prolonged period of continence

Causes
  • Brain maturation delay
  • Genetics (eg, family history)
  • Underlying medical condition (eg, UTI, type 1 diabetes mellitus)

Initial evaluation
  • Urinalysis*
  • Urinalysis

  • Behavioral modifications (eg, evening fluid restriction)
  • Bedwetting alarm
  • Treatment of underlying condition

*Urinalysis is performed because a developing secondary condition (eg, type 1 diabetes mellitus) may overlap with primary nocturnal enuresis.

UTI = urinary tract infection.

Primary nocturnal enuresis

Definition
  • Nighttime urinary incontinence age â¥5
  • No prior prolonged period of overnight dryness

Pathogenesis
  • Delayed maturation of bladder control
  • â Nocturnal urine output (eg, â evening fluids, â ADH)
  • â Bladder capacity

Risk factors
  • Family history
  • Boys age 5-8

Evaluation
  • Urinalysis (to exclude other causes)
  • Voiding diary

Management

  • Behavioral modifications (eg, restrict evening fluids)
  • Enuresis alarm
  • Desmopressin therapy

ADH = antidiuretic hormone.

title: Beckwith-wiedmann syndrome
noteText:
Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome

Pathogenesis
  • Deregulation of imprinted gene expression on chromosome 11p15

Clinical
findings
  • Unregulated growth:
    • Fetal macrosomia; rapid growth in childhood
    • Macroglossia
    • Hemihyperplasia
  • Midline abdominal wall defects:
    • Omphalocele
    • Umbilical hernia
  • Embryonal tumors in childhood:

surveillance

title: Uric acid stone
noteText:
Uric acid kidney stones

Risk factors
  • Low urine pH: chronic diarrhea (GI bicarbonate loss), metabolic syndrome/
    diabetes mellitus
  • Increased uric acid excretion: gout, myeloproliferative disorders
  • Increased urine concentration: hot, arid climates; dehydration

Pathophysiology
  • Acidic urine favors formation of uric acid (insoluble) over urate (soluble)
  • Supersaturation of urine with uric acid precipitates crystal formation

Clinical
characteristics
  • Radiolucent stones (not visible on x-ray)
  • Uric acid crystals on urine microscopy (diamond/rhomboid shaped)
  • Urine pH usually <5.5

Treatment
  • Alkalinization of urine (eg, potassium citrate)
  • Reduction of uric acid production (eg, low-purine diet, allopurinol)

GI = gastrointestinal.

title: Hypervolemic hyponatremia
noteText:
Hypervolemic hyponatremia

Pathogenesis
  • â EABV* â â renal perfusion (â RAAS) & hypotension (â ADH)
  • Water reabsorption > salt reabsorption

Associated conditions
  • Heart failure
  • Cirrhosis
  • Kidney disease (eg, kidney failure, nephrotic syndrome)

Treatment
  • Hypervolemia: diuretics
  • Hyponatremia: no specific therapy**
    • Minimize hypotension to â ADH

*Kidneys & baroreceptors incorrectly sense that hypovolemia is present.

**Management should focus on minimizing hypotension to decrease ADH.  Treatment can be considered in severe hyponatremia (<120 mEq/L) or if the patient is significantly symptomatic (eg, seizures).

ADH = antidiuretic hormone; EABV = effective arterial blood volume; RAAS = renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.

title: Diabetic autonomic neuropathy
noteText:
Clinical features of diabetic autonomic neuropathy

Cardiovascular
  • Tachycardia, impaired exercise tolerance
  • Postural hypotension with loss of diurnal blood pressure variation

Peripheral nerves
  • Dry skin, pruritus, callus formation
  • Foot ulcers & poor wound healing
  • Charcot arthropathy (increased fracture risk with resultant secondary ulceration)

Gastrointestinal
  • Gastroparesis with delayed gastric emptying
  • Esophageal dysmotility with possible dyspepsia
  • Intestinal involvement with possible diarrhea, constipation, or fecal incontinence

Genitourinary
  • Erectile dysfunction & retrograde ejaculation in men, decreased libido & dyspareunia in women
  • Decreased ability to sense full bladder leading to incomplete emptying & decreased urination
  • Eventual recurrent urinary tract infections &/or overflow incontinence (eg, dribbling, poor urinary stream)

title: UTI
noteText:
Urinary tract infection

Pathogenesis
  • Escherichia coli (most common)
  • Ascending infection

Clinical features
  • Dysuria
  • Urinary urgency & frequency
  • Hematuria
  • Suprapubic/flank pain

Diagnosis
  • Pyuria
  • Bacteriuria on urine culture

Treatment
  • Antibiotics

title: Stress incontinence
noteText:
Stress urinary incontinence

Physiology
  • Urethral hypermobility
  • Intrinsic sphincteric deficiency

Symptoms
  • Leakage with Valsalva maneuver (eg, coughing, sneezing, laughing, intercourse)

Risk factors
  • Pregnancy (especially vaginal delivery)
  • Obesity
  • Chronic high-impact exercise

Treatment
  • Pelvic floor muscle (Kegel) exercises
  • Lifestyle modifications (weight loss)
  • Continence pessary
  • Midurethral sling procedure

Urinary incontinence

Type

Symptoms

Treatment

Stress
  • Leaking with Valsalva maneuver (coughing, sneezing, laughing)
  • Lifestyle modification
  • Pelvic floor exercises
  • Pessary
  • Pelvic floor surgery

Urgency
  • Sudden, overwhelming, or frequent need to void
  • Lifestyle modification
  • Bladder training
  • Antimuscarinic drugs

Mixed
  • Features of stress & urgency incontinence
  • Variable treatment depending on predominant symptoms

Overflow
  • Constant involuntary dribbling & incomplete emptying
  • Identification and correction of underlying cause
  • Cholinergic agonists
  • Intermittent self-catheterization

Uncomplicated
