title: Pncreatic leak
noteText:
Metabolic acidosis
 

Normal anion gap

Elevated anion gap

Mechanism
  • Loss of bicarbonate
  • Accumulation of unmeasured acidic compounds

Etiologies
  • Severe diarrhea
  • Renal tubular acidosis
  • Excess saline infusion
  • Intestinal or pancreatic fistula
  • CAI & MRA diuretics
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Kidney failure (uremia)
  • Methanol, ethylene glycol
  • Salicylate toxicity

CAI = carbonic anhydrase inhibitor; MRA = mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist.

title: Urinary stasis due to chronic constipation
Hypercalcemia Mx
noteText:
Management of hypercalcemia

Severe
(calcium >14 mg/dL)
or symptomatic

Short-term (immediate) treatment

  • Normal saline hydration plus calcitonin
  • Avoid loop diuretics unless volume overload (heart failure) exists

Long-term treatment

  • Bisphosphonate (zoledronic acid)

Moderate
(calcium 12-14 mg/dL)

  • Usually no immediate treatment required unless symptomatic
  • Treatment is similar to that for severe hypercalcemia

Asymptomatic or mild
(calcium <12 mg/dL)

  • No immediate treatment required
  • Avoid thiazide diuretics, lithium, volume depletion & prolonged bed rest

title: Type 1 DM
noteText:
Type 1 diabetes mellitus

Pathophysiology
  • Autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells â low/absent insulin â hyperglycemia

Epidemiology
  • Peak onset at ages 4-6 & 10-14
  • Often thin habitus but up to 25% are overweight

Clinical
manifestations
  • Polyuria, enuresis (osmotic diuresis)
  • Polydipsia (hypovolemia & hyperosmolality)
  • Weight loss & fatigue (ketosis from impaired glucose use)
  • DKA: severe symptoms + abdominal pain, vomiting, fruity-smelling breath

Diagnosis
  • Fasting glucose â¥126 mg/dL
  • Oral glucose tolerance test or random glucose â¥200 mg/dL
  • Hemoglobin A1c â¥6.5%

DKA = diabetic ketoacidosis.

title: Mechanism of hypovolemic hyponatremia
Vesicoureteral reflux
noteText:
Primary vesicoureteral reflux in children

Pathogenesis
  • Retrograde urine flow through a short intravesical ureter

Presentation
  • Febrile urinary tract infection

Diagnosis
  • Renal ultrasonography: hydronephrosis
  • Voiding cystourethrography: ureteral filling Â± dilated collecting system

Management
  • Mild (grade I-II)*: observation Â± prophylactic antibiotics
  • Severe (grade III-IV)*: prophylactic antibiotics Â± surgery

Prognosis
  • Mild: spontaneous resolution with growth
  • Severe (without intervention): renal scarring and chronic kidney disease

*Plus screening/treatment of concomitant bladder & bowel dysfunction (eg, stool softeners/laxatives).

title: Urethral stricture
noteText:
Urethral stricture

Etiology
  • Male > female
  • Urethral trauma (eg, catheterization)
  • Urethritis
  • Radiotherapy

Symptoms
  • Weak or spraying stream
  • Incomplete emptying
  • Irritative voiding (eg, dysuria, frequency)

Complications
  • Acute urine retention
  • Recurrent urinary tract infection
  • Bladder stones

Diagnosis
  • Postvoid residual, uroflowmetry
  • Urethrography
  • Cystourethroscopy

Management
  • Dilation
  • Urethroplasty

title: Asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy
noteText:
Asymptomatic bacteriuria in pregnancy

Definition
  • â¥100,000 CFU/mL bacteria

Risk
factors
  • Pregestational diabetes mellitus
  • History of urinary tract infection
  • Multiparity

Common
pathogens
  • Escherichia coli (most common)
  • Klebsiella
  • Enterobacter
  • Group B Streptococcus

Potential complications
  • Acute pyelonephritis
  • Preterm labor & delivery

Treatment
  • Cefpodoxime
  • Fosfomycin
  • Amoxicillin-clavulanate
  • Nitrofurantoin*

*Avoided in first & third trimesters.

CFU = colony-forming units.

title: Drug causing hyperkalemia
noteText:
Medication-induced hyperkalemia

Medication

Mechanism

ACE inhibitors & ARBs

â Aldosterone secretion (â AT II production; block AT II receptor)

NSAIDs

â Renin secretion â â aldosterone

â Renal perfusion â â distal Na+ delivery â  â ENaC activity

Potassium-sparing
diuretics

Inhibit ENaC (eg, amiloride) or aldosterone receptor (eg, spironolactone)

Heparin

â Aldosterone production

Trimethoprim

Inhibits ENaC (similar to amiloride)

Cyclosporine

Blocks aldosterone activity

Nonselective
Î²-blockers

Interfere with Î²2-mediated intracellular K+ uptake

Digoxin

Inhibits Na+/K+-ATPase

Succinylcholine

Causes extracellular leakage of K+ through acetylcholine receptors

ARBs = angiotensin II receptor blockers; AT = angiotensin; ENaC = epithelial sodium channel; NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

title: Renal cyst
noteText:
Characteristics of renal cysts

Simple renal cyst

Malignant cystic mass

Thin, smooth, regular wall

Thick, irregular wall

Unilocular

Multilocular

No septae

Multiple septae, occasionally thick & calcified

Homogeneous content

Heterogeneous content (solid & cystic)

Absence of contrast enhancement on CT/MRI

Presence of contrast enhancement on CT/MRI

Usually asymptomatic

May cause pain, hematuria, or hypertension

No follow-up needed

Requires follow-up imaging & urological evaluation for malignancy

title: Lab abnormalities in persistent vomiting
ADPKD
noteText:
Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

Clinical
presentation
  • Most patients asymptomatic until age 30-40
  • Flank pain, hematuria
  • Hypertension
  • Palpable abdominal masses (usually bilateral)
  • Chronic kidney disease (CKD)

Extrarenal
features
  • Cerebral aneurysms
  • Hepatic & pancreatic cysts
  • Mitral valve prolapse, aortic regurgitation
  • Colonic diverticulosis
  • Ventral & inguinal hernias

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography showing multiple renal cysts

Management
  • Aggressive control of risk factors for CV & CKD
  • ACE inhibitors preferred for hypertension
  • Hemodialysis, renal transplant for ESRD

CV = cardiovascular; ESRD = end-stage renal disease.

title: Anion gap metabolic acidosis
noteText:
Anion gap metabolic acidosis

Calculation

Anion gap = sodium â (chloride + bicarbonate)
(normal: 10-14 mEq/L)

Common causes
(mnemonic: MUDPILES)
  • Methanol
  • Uremia
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Propylene glycol/paraldehyde
  • Isoniazid/iron
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Ethylene glycol (antifreeze)
  • Salicylate (aspirin)

Appropriate compensatory PaCO2 or HCO3â changes in acid-base disorders

Metabolic acidosis
(acute or chronic)

Expected PaCO2 = (1.5 Ã HCO3â) + 8 Â± 2 (Winters formula)

Metabolic alkalosis
(acute or chronic)

~7 mm Hg â in PaCO2 per 10 mEq/L â in HCO3â

Respiratory acidosis
(chronic only*)

~4 mEq/L â in HCO3â per 10 mm Hg â in PaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis
(chronic only*)

~4 mEq/L â in HCO3â per 10 mm Hg â in PaCO2

*Compensation for respiratory disturbances is minimal in the acute setting.  The full level of chronic compensation is achieved after ~72 hr.  For simplicity, normal baseline PaCO2 & HCO3â should be considered 40 mm Hg & 24 mEq/L, respectively.

title: Site of action of diuretics
Evaluation of hyponatremia
Vesicoureteral reflux
noteText:
Urinary tract infection (UTI) in children

Risk factors
  • Female sex
  • Uncircumcised male infants
  • Urologic abnormalities (eg, vesicoureteral reflux)
  • Bowel/bladder dysfunction (eg, constipation)

Clinical features
  • Infants: fever, fussiness, poor feeding
  • Older children: dysuria, suprapubic/flank pain

Laboratory findings
  • Urinalysis: leukocyte esterase, nitrites, WBCs
  • Urine culture: bacteriuria

Management
  • Antibiotics (eg, cephalosporin)
  • First febrile UTI:
    • Age <2 years: RBUS, followed by VCUG if abnormal
    • Age â¥2 years: observation alone
  • Recurrent febrile UTIs: RBUS & VCUG

RBUS = renal & bladder ultrasonography; VCUG = voiding cystourethrogram; WBCs = white blood cells.

title: UTI in children
noteText:
Urinary tract infection (UTI) in children

Risk factors
  • Female sex
  • Uncircumcised male infants
  • Urologic abnormalities (eg, vesicoureteral reflux)
  • Bowel/bladder dysfunction (eg, constipation)

Clinical features
  • Infants: fever, fussiness, poor feeding
  • Older children: dysuria, suprapubic/flank pain

Laboratory findings
  • Urinalysis: leukocyte esterase, nitrites, WBCs
  • Urine culture: bacteriuria

Management
  • Antibiotics (eg, cephalosporin)
  • First febrile UTI:
    • Age <2: RBUS, followed by VCUG if abnormal
    • Age â¥2: observation alone
  • Recurrent febrile UTIs: RBUS & VCUG

RBUS = renal & bladder ultrasound; VCUG = voiding cystourethrogram; WBCs = white blood cells.

title: Atherosclerosis in nephrotic syndrome
Calcium oxalate stone in crohn disease

noteText:
Prevention of calcium stone (calcium oxalate, calcium phosphate) recurrence
 

Intervention

Mechanism

Dietary
interventions

All calcium stones:

Pharmacologic
interventions

â Renal calcium reabsorption

GI = gastrointestinal.

title: FSGS
noteText:
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis

Pathogenesis
  • Primary FSGS: circulating factor causing immune injury to podocytes
  • Secondary FSGS: glomerular hyperfiltration (eg, obesity, solitary kidney, reflux nephropathy), podocyte toxin (eg, heroin), infection (eg, HIVAN)

Clinical features
  • Primary FSGS: usually nephrotic syndrome
  • Secondary FSGS: proteinuria Â± nephrotic syndrome

Diagnosis
  • LM: segmental scarring in <50% of glomeruli*
  • IF: usually negative
  • EM: podocyte foot process effacement**

Treatment
  • Renin-angiotensin blockade, loop diuretics
  • Primary FSGS: immunosuppression
  • Secondary FSGS: risk factor modification (eg, weight loss, ART)

*Glomerular tuft collapse is also seen in HIVAN.

**Diffuse (â¥80%) effacement in primary; segmental (<80%) effacement in secondary.

ART = antiretroviral therapy; EM = electron microscopy; FSGS = focal segmental glomerulosclerosis; HIVAN = HIV-associated nephropathy; IF = immunofluorescence microscopy; LM = light microscopy.

title: Glomerular vs nonglomerular hematuria
noteText:
Glomerular vs nonglomerular hematuria
 

Glomerular

Nonglomerular

May be seen1

Absent

Often present2

Rare, usually normal (ie, isomorphic)

Often â¥1+ (>500 mg/day)

Usually negative or trace (<500 mg/day)

Bright red or pink

Absent

Possible1
  1. Virtually pathognomonic when present.
  2. Acanthocytes highly specific; phase-contrast microscopy often needed for visualization.
  3. Urine dipstick sensitive for albuminuria (ie, glomerular proteinuria).

RBC = red blood cell.

IgA nephropathy

Clinical
features
  • Onset: spontaneous or several days after URI
  • Episodic gross hematuria
    • Â± Flank pain, low-grade fever, â BP
  • Asymptomatic, microscopic hematuria can occur

Laboratory
findings
  • Urinalysis: protein, blood, red blood cell casts
  • Normal serum C3 & C4
  • â Serum creatinine

Diagnosis
  • Usually clinical
  • Confirmed by kidney biopsy: mesangial IgA deposition

Prognosis/
risk factors
  • Often self-resolves
  • End-stage renal disease in some patients
    • Risk factors: â creatinine, â BP, persistent proteinuria
    • Slowly progressive (>10 yr)

BP = blood pressure; URI = upper respiratory infection.

title: Ureteral obstruction
Minimal change disease
noteText:
Minimal change disease

Epidemiology
  • Most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children

Pathogenesis
  • T-cellâmediated injury to podocytes â â molecular permeability to albumin

Clinical features
  • Edema (eg, periorbital, scrotal, generalized)
  • Fatigue
  • Â± Abdominal pain

Diagnosis
  • Urine: nephrotic-range proteinuria
  • Serum: hypoalbuminemia Â± hyperlipidemia
  • Kidney biopsy*: diffuse effacement of foot processes on EM

Treatment
  • Corticosteroids

Prognosis
  • Most achieve remission, but relapse is common
  • Low risk of chronic kidney disease if episodes are steroid responsive

*Indicated only for atypical cases.

EM = electron microscopy.

title: Mx of symptomatic ureteral stone
Evaluation of hematuria in children
Sickle cell trait
noteText:
Sickle cell trait

Clinical features
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • No change in overall life expectancy

Laboratory findings
  • Normal hemoglobin, reticulocyte count, RBC indices & morphology
  • Hemoglobin electrophoresis: Hb A > Hb S

Complications
  • Hematuria/papillary necrosis, hyposthenuria
  • Splenic infarction (especially at higher altitudes), venous thromboembolism, priapism
  • Exertional rhabdomyolysis

Hb A = hemoglobin A; Hb S = hemoglobin S; RBC = red blood cell.

title: Endometriosis
noteText:
Endometriosis

Pathogenesis

  • Ectopic implantation of endometrial glands

Clinical features

  • Dyspareunia
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Chronic pelvic pain
  • Infertility
  • Dyschezia
  • Cyclic dysuria, hematuria

Physical examination

  • Immobile uterus
  • Cervical motion tenderness
  • Adnexal mass
  • Rectovaginal septum, posterior cul-de-sac, uterosacral ligament nodules

Diagnosis

  • Direct visualization & surgical biopsy

Treatment

  • Medical (oral contraceptives, NSAIDs)  
  • Surgical resection

NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

title: Renal vein thrombosis
noteText:
Renal vein thrombosis

Causes
  • Hypercoagulability
    • Nephrotic syndrome (particularly membranous nephropathy)
    • Malignancy (particularly renal cell*)
    • Other (eg, inherited thrombophilia, OCPs)
  • Trauma or external compression

Clinical
features
  • Acute: renal infarction symptoms (flank pain, hematuria, â LDH, â kidney size on imaging)
  • Chronic: renal symptoms typically absent (may cause pulmonary embolus)

Diagnosis
  • CT or MR angiography
  • Renal venography

Treatment
  • Anticoagulation
  • Local thrombolysis/thrombectomy (if AKI present)

* Due to direct tumor extension into the renal vein, in addition to hypercoagulability.

AKI = acute kidney injury; LDH = lactate dehydrogenase; OCPs = oral contraceptive pills.

title: Struvite stone
noteText:
Struvite (magnesium ammonium phosphate) stones

Pathogenesis
  • Urease-producing organisms (eg, Klebsiella, Proteus)
  • Hydrolysis of urea to yield ammonia:

                        Urea â 2 NH3 + CO2
                        NH3 + H2O â NH4+ + OHâ

  • Increased urine pH
  • Precipitation of magnesium ammonium phosphate salts

Clinical
features
  • Recurrent upper urinary tract infections
  • Fever, dysuria, mild flank pain more common than renal colic
  • Urine pH >8, coffin lidâshaped crystals
  • Large staghorn calculi*

Treatment
  • Antibiotic therapy
  • Complete stone removal (eg, percutaneous nephrolithotomy) usually required
  • Urease inhibitor in select patients to prevent recurrence

*Common but nonspecific (also seen with uric acid & cysteine stones).

Uric acid kidney stones

Risk factors
  • Low urine pH: chronic diarrhea (GI bicarbonate loss), metabolic syndrome/
    diabetes mellitus
  • Increased uric acid excretion: gout, myeloproliferative disorders
  • Increased urine concentration: hot, arid climates; dehydration

Pathophysiology
  • Acidic urine favors formation of uric acid (insoluble) over urate (soluble)
  • Supersaturation of urine with uric acid precipitates crystal formation

Clinical
characteristics
  • Radiolucent stones (not visible on x-ray)
  • Uric acid crystals on urine microscopy (diamond/rhomboid shaped)
  • Urine pH usually <5.5

Treatment
  • Alkalinization of urine (eg, potassium citrate)
  • Reduction of uric acid production (eg, low-purine diet, allopurinol)

GI = gastrointestinal.

title: Membranous nephropathy
noteText:
Membranous nephropathy

Pathogenesis & etiology
  • Immune-mediated podocyte injury
  • Primary: PLA2R autoantibodies (most common)
  • Secondary: infection (eg, hepatitis B), malignancy, autoimmune (eg, SLE), medication (eg, NSAID)

Clinical features
  • Nephrotic syndrome, â thromboembolic risk

Diagnosis
  • Microscopy: diffuse GBM thickening, spikes on LM; granular IgG & C3 on IF; subepithelial deposits & podocyte effacement on EM
  • Laboratory testing: primary (eg, PLA2R studies); secondary (eg, ANA, viruses, cancer screening)

Treatment
  • All patients: supportive care (eg, RAAS blockade, loop diuretics)
  • Primary: monitoring (low risk, spontaneous remission), immunosuppression (higher risk)
  • Secondary: therapy for underlying cause

ANA = antinuclear antibody; EM = electron microscopy; GBM = glomerular basement membrane; IF = immunofluorescence; LM = light microscopy; NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug; PLA2R = phospholipase A2 receptor; RAAS = renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus.

Membranous nephropathy

Epidemiology
  • Adults: common, usually idiopathic/primary disease
  • Children: rare, usually secondary disease

Pathogenesis
  • Gradual subepithelial immune complex deposition & podocyte damage

Associated conditions
  • Malignancy
  • Infection (eg, hepatitis B)
  • Autoimmune (eg, systemic lupus erythematosus, thyroiditis)
  • Drugs (eg, NSAIDs, penicillamine)

Presentation
  • Subacute nephrotic syndrome
    • Edema
    • Proteinuria
    • Hyperlipidemia & hypoalbuminemia
  • BP & GFR usually normal

Prognosis
  • Partial/full remission common (spontaneous or treatment induced)
  • End-stage kidney disease rare

BP = blood pressure; GFR = glomerular filtration rate; NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

title: Lupus nephritis
noteText:
Lupus nephritis

Epidemiology
  • Affects ~50% of patients with SLE
  • Can be the presenting manifestation of SLE

Pathogenesis
  • Loss of immune tolerance to nuclear antigens (eg, nucleosomes)
  • Renal deposition of circulating ICs (eg, anti-dsDNA bound to DNA)
  • Complement activation & inflammatory injury

Clinical features
(related to site of ICs)
  • Mesangial: microscopic hematuria &/or asymptomatic hematuria
  • Subendothelial: glomerulonephritis Â± proteinuria
  • Subepithelial: nephrotic syndrome

Diagnostic tests
  • ANA, anti-dsDNA, anti-Smith
  • Low serum complement (C3 & C4)
  • Kidney biopsy

ANA = antinuclear antibody; ds = double-stranded; IC = immune complex; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus.

Lupus nephritis patterns of glomerular injury

Immune
complex
location

Class*

Clinical features

Treatment**

Mesangial
  • I (minimal mesangial)
  • II (mesangial proliferative)
  • Asymptomatic
  • Microscopic hematuria
  • Close monitoring

Subendothelial
  • III (focal proliferative)
  • IV (diffuse proliferative)
  • Glomerulonephritis
  • Â± Nephrotic syndrome
  • Immunosuppressant (eg, mycophenolate) & steroids

Subepithelial
  • V (membranous)
  • Large proteinuria
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Immunosuppressant (eg, mycophenolate) & steroids

*Class VI (advanced sclerosing) has scarring of >90% of glomeruli with no residual inflammation.

**Proteinuria should be treated with renin-angiotensin blockade and sodium restriction.

title: Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis
noteText:
Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis

Pathophysiology
  • Several weeks after GAS infection (eg, pharyngitis, impetigo)
  • GBM immune complex deposition
  • Complement component C3 & CH50 accumulation

Clinical
features
  • Can be asymptomatic
  • If symptomatic:
    • Gross hematuria (tea- or cola-colored urine)
    • Edema (periorbital, generalized)
    • Hypertension

Laboratory
findings
  • Urinalysis: + protein, + blood, Â± RBC casts
  • Serum:
    • â Creatinine
    • â C3 & CH50
    • Possible â C4
    • Positive streptozyme test*

Management
  • Supportive care
  • Volume overload: loop diuretics
  • Hypertension: Â± additional antihypertensives
  • Refractory cases: hemodialysis

Prognosis
  • Complete recovery in a few weeks in children
  • Adults more likely to develop chronic kidney disease

*Streptozyme tests: antistreptolysin O, anti-DNAse B, antihyaluronidase, antiânicotinamide
adenine dinucleotidase, antistreptokinase.

GAS = group A Streptococcus; GBM = glomerular basement membrane; RBC = red blood cell.

APSGN

  • Several days after upper respiratory tract infection or spontaneous
  • Most common in young adults

  • Immune complex deposition along GBM (ie, subepithelial)

Clinical features
  • Gross hematuria (often recurrent)
  • Â± Flank pain, low-grade fever, hypertension
  • May be asymptomatic
  • Gross hematuria
  • Edema (periorbital or generalized)
  • Hypertension
  • May be asymptomatic

Laboratory findings

  • Serum:
    • Normal C3 & C4
    • â Creatinine
  • Urinalysis: + protein, RBCs, RBC casts

    • â Or normal C4
    • â Creatinine

APSGN = acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis; CH50 = total complement; GBM = glomerular basement membrane; RBC = red blood cell.

title: AmiKacin induced ATN
noteText:
Acute tubular necrosis

Common causes
  • Ischemic
    • Prolonged hypotension, sepsis
  • Toxic
    • Antibiotics (eg, aminoglycosides, vancomycin)
    • Antivirals (eg, cidofovir, foscarnet)
    • Miscellaneous: radiographic contrast, cisplatin, heavy metals, heme pigment

Histologic findings
  • Tubular epithelial cell necrosis with cell detachment, cast formation & tubular lumen obstruction
  • Ischemic: corticomedullary PCT & TAL primarily affected
  • Toxic: cortical PCT primarily affected

Presentation
  • BUN/creatinine ratio <20:1, FENa >2%
  • Muddy brown (granular) or epithelial cell casts, low urine osmolality
  • Oliguria or polyuria, Â± electrolyte abnormalities

BUN = blood urea nitrogen; FENa = fractional excretion of sodium; PCT = proximal convoluted tubule; TAL = thick ascending loop.

title: Crystal induced AKI
noteText:
Clinical features of crystal-induced acute kidney injury

Common etiologies
  • Acyclovir
  • Sulfonamides
  • Methotrexate
  • Ethylene glycol
  • Protease inhibitors
  • Uric acid (tumor lysis syndrome)

Clinical presentation
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • AKI â¤7 days of starting drug
  • UA: Hematuria, pyuria & crystals
  • Increased risk with volume depletion, CKD

Management
  • Discontinuation of drug
  • Volume repletion
  • Loop diuretic

AKI = acute kidney injury; CKD = chronic kidney disease; UA = urinalysis.

title: RAS
noteText:
Clinical clues to renovascular disease

HTN-related symptoms
  • Resistant HTN (uncontrolled despite 3-drug regimen)
  • Malignant HTN (with end-organ damage)
  • Onset of severe HTN (>180/120 mm Hg) after age 55
  • Severe HTN with diffuse atherosclerosis
  • Recurrent flash pulmonary edema with severe HTN

Supportive evidence

Physical examination

  • Asymmetric renal size (>1.5 cm)
  • Abdominal bruit

Laboratory results

  • Unexplained rise in serum creatinine (>30%) after starting ACE inhibitors or ARBs

Imaging results

  • Unexplained atrophic kidney

ARBs = angiotensin II receptor blockers; HTN = hypertension.

title: Unintentional weight loss in elderly patient
noteText:
Unintentional weight loss in elderly patients

Definition
  • >5% involuntary weight loss over 6-12 months

Causes
  • Malignancy, depression
  • Chronic end-organ disease (eg, CKD, COPD)
  • Neurologic disease (eg, oropharyngeal dysphagia)
  • Social factors (eg, poverty, isolation)
  • Diminished smell & taste, poor dentition

CKD = chronic kidney disease; COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

title: Calciphylaxis
noteText:
Calcific uremic arteriolopathy (calciphylaxis)

Pathophysiology
  • Arteriolar & soft tissue calcification
  • Local tissue ischemia & necrosis

Risk factors
  • End-stage renal disease
  • Hypercalcemia, hyperphosphatemia
  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Oral anticoagulants (eg, warfarin)

Clinical manifestations
  • Painful nodules & ulcers
  • Soft tissue calcification on imaging
  • Diagnosis requires skin biopsy: arteriolar calcification/occlusion, subintimal fibrosis

Management
  • Analgesia & wound care
  • Treatment of risk factors (eg, high phosphorus, high calcium)
  • Optimization of dialysis

title: Rhabdomyolysis
noteText:
Rhabdomyolysis

Etiology

Skeletal muscle lysis/necrosis due to:

  • Crush injury or prolonged immobilization
  • Intense muscle activity (eg, seizure, exertion)
  • Drug/medication toxicity (eg, statins)

Clinical features
  • Muscle pain & weakness
  • Dark urine (myoglobinuria/pigmenturia)
  • + Blood on urinalysis & no RBCs on microscopy
  • â Serum K & PO4, â serum Ca, â AST > ALT
  • Acute kidney injury

Diagnosis
  • Serum creatine kinase >1,000 U/L
  • Consistent clinical features

Management
  • Aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation
  • Sodium bicarbonate in some cases

ALT = alanine aminotransferase; AST = aspartate aminotransferase; RBCs = red blood cells.

Drug-induced rhabdomyolysis

Major mechanism

Examples

Direct myotoxicity
  • Statins, fibrates
  • Colchicine
  • Ethanol
  • Cocaine

Vasoconstrictive ischemia
  • Cocaine
  • Amphetamines

Prolonged immobilization
(compression ischemia)
  • Ethanol
  • Opioids
  • Benzodiazepines

title: Cholesterol embolism
noteText:
Cholesterol crystal embolism (atheroembolism)

Risk factors
  • Comorbid conditions (hypercholesterolemia, hypertension, type 2 diabetes mellitus)
  • Cardiac catheterization or vascular procedure

Clinical features
  • Dermatologic (livedo reticularis, ulcers, gangrene, blue toe syndrome)
  • Renal (acute or subacute kidney injury)
  • CNS (stroke, amaurosis fugax)
  • Ocular involvement (Hollenhorst plaques)
  • Gastrointestinal (intestinal ischemia, pancreatitis)

Diagnosis

Laboratory findings

  • Elevated serum creatinine, eosinophilia, hypocomplementemia
  • Urinalysis, typically benign with few cells or casts, may have eosinophiluria

Skin or renal biopsy

  • Biconvex, needle-shaped clefts within occluded vessels
  • Perivascular inflammation with eosinophils

title: Analgesic nephropathy
noteText:
Analgesic nephropathy

Pathophysiology
  • Prolonged use of combination analgesics
    • Acetaminophen: depletion of glutathione impairs deactivation of reactive acetaminophen metabolites
    • Aspirin/NSAIDs: direct oxidative renal toxicity
  • Manifests as chronic interstitial nephritis Â± papillary necrosis

Clinical
presentation
  • History of chronic pain (eg, headaches, lower back pain)
  • Often asymptomatic, may have malaise, fatigue, flank pain
  • Urinalysis: WBCs & WBC casts Â± mild proteinuria
  • Hematuria & urine RBCs if papillary necrosis is present
  • Imaging: small kidneys Â± papillary calcification & irregular contours

NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; RBCs = red blood cells; WBCs = white blood cells.

title: Cardiorenal syndrome
Toxic alcohol ingestion
noteText:
Toxic alcohol ingestion (methanol or ethylene glycol)

Typical sources
  • Methanol: windshield wiper fluid, contaminated homemade liquor
  • Ethylene glycol: automotive coolant/antifreeze, brake fluid
  • Industrial solvents & deicing solutions may contain either toxic alcohol

Clinical features
  • Early: CNS sedation & inebriation, osmolar gap
  • Late: anion gap metabolic acidosis, compensatory tachypnea
    • Ocular toxicity (methanol)
    • Urine oxalate crystals, hypocalcemia, AKI (ethylene glycol)

Management
  • Fomepizole (inhibits ADHase) is preferred therapy
  • Ethanol solution (competes for ADHase) if fomepizole unavailable
  • IV sodium bicarbonate for acidemia (eg, pH <7.3)
  • Hemodialysis for severe cases (eg, acidosis, end-organ damage)

ADHase = alcohol dehydrogenase; AKI = acute kidney injury; IV = intravenous.

Serum osmolality

(normal: 275-295 mOsm/kg H2O)

Calculated serum osmolality

(2 Ã Na+) + (glucose / 18) + (BUN / 2.8) + (ethanol / 4.6)*

Serum osmolal gap

Laboratory-measured osmolality â calculated osmolality

(>10 suggests unmeasured substance)

*Ethanol is frequently measured in the laboratory & may be included in the calculated serum osmolality when appropriate.

BUN = blood urea nitrogen.

title: Metformin side efffect
noteText:
Metformin

Mechanism of action
  • Inhibits mitochondrial glycerophosphate dehydrogenase
  • Upregulates AMP-activated protein kinase

Metabolic effects
  • â Hepatic glucose production
  • â Intestinal glucose absorption
  • â Peripheral glucose uptake/utilization
  • â Lipogenesis

Pharmacokinetics
  • Renal clearance
  • No significant metabolites

Adverse effects
  • Diarrhea
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency

Precautions/ contraindications
  • Renal insufficiency (check serum creatinine)
  • Hepatic insufficiency
  • Decompensated heart failure

title: Uremia induced platelet dysfunction
Acromegaly
Anion gap metabolic acidosis
noteText:
Anion gap metabolic acidosis

Calculation

Anion gap = sodium â (chloride + bicarbonate)
(normal: 10-14 mEq/L)

Common causes
(mnemonic: MUDPILES)
  • Methanol
  • Uremia
  • Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Propylene glycol/paraldehyde
  • Isoniazid/iron
  • Lactic acidosis
  • Ethylene glycol (antifreeze)
  • Salicylate (aspirin)

title: Contrast associated acute kidney injury
noteText:
Contrast-associated acute kidney injury

Presentation
  • Highest risk with arterial iodinated contrast (eg, coronary angiogram)
  • Creatinine elevation 24-48 hr after contrast exposure, gradually returning to baseline within 3-7 days
  • Clinical diagnosis based on timing & trajectory above (ie, biopsy rarely needed)

Risk factors
  • Preexisting chronic kidney disease (especially diabetic nephropathy)
  • Decreased kidney perfusion (eg, NSAIDs, hypovolemia, venous congestion)
  • High contrast load

Pathophysiology
  • Prerenal vasoconstriction & direct tubular cytotoxicity
  • Prerenal state (eg, FeNa <1%) with concurrent necrosis (eg, muddy brown casts)

Prevention
  • Optimize kidney perfusion (eg, intravenous saline, avoidance of NSAIDs)
  • Minimize contrast load

FeNa = fractional excretion of sodium; NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug.

title: Acute interstitial nephritis
noteText:
Acute interstitial nephritis

Causes
  • Medications (eg, antibiotics, NSAIDs, PPIs)*
  • Rheumatologic disease (eg, SLE, SjÃ¶gren syndrome, sarcoidosis)
  • Infections (eg, Legionella, tuberculosis, CMV)

Clinical features
  • New medication exposure
  • Acute kidney injury
  • Arthralgias, malaise
  • Classic triad of fever, skin rash & eosinophilia rarely present**

Diagnosis
  • Clinical presentation
  • Urinalysis: WBCs & WBC casts Â± mild RBCs & proteinuria
  • Peripheral eosinophilia Â± urine eosinophils
  • Â± Renal biopsy: tubulointerstitial inflammation & edema

Management
  • Discontinue offending drug or treat underlying condition
  • Systemic glucocorticoids
  • Supportive hemodialysis if needed

*Medications account for ~75% of cases.

**Classic triad is present in only ~10% of cases.

CMV = cytomegalovirus; NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; PPIs = proton pump inhibitors; RBCs = red blood cells; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus; WBCs = white blood cells.

title: Cardiovascular risk factors in ESRD patient
noteText:
Cardiovascular risk factors in ESRD patients

Traditional risk factors
  • Hypertension, diabetes mellitus & dyslipidemia
  • Left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Advanced age & low physical activity

ESRD-specific risk factors
  • Anemia of chronic kidney disease
  • Vascular calcifications (â phosphorus, â calcium)
  • Oxidative stress related to uremia and dialysis

ESRD = end-stage renal disease.

title: Prerenal acute kidney injury
noteText:
Prerenal acute kidney injury

Etiology
  • Decreased renal perfusion
    • True volume depletion
    • Decreased EABV (eg, heart failure, cirrhosis)
    • Displacement of intravascular fluid (eg, sepsis, pancreatitis)
    • Bilateral renal artery stenosis with ACE inhibition
    • Afferent arteriole vasoconstriction (eg, NSAIDs)

Clinical features
  • Increase in serum creatinine (eg, 50% from baseline)
  • Decreased urine output
  • Blood urea nitrogen/creatinine ratio >20:1
  • Fractional excretion of sodium <1%
  • Unremarkable (bland) urine sediment

Treatment
  • Restoration of renal perfusion

EABV = effective arterial blood volume; NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug.

Stimuli for secretion of antidiuretic hormone

Osmotic
  • Serum osmolality > ~285 mOsm/kg H2O

Nonosmotic
  • Nausea
  • Pain
  • Physical or emotional stress
  • Hypotension
  • Hypovolemia
  • Hypoxia
  • Hypoglycemia

title: Evaluation of red urine
Hepatorenal syndrome
noteText:
Hepatorenal syndrome

Risk factors
  • Advanced cirrhosis with portal hypertension
  • Acute liver failure, severe alcoholic hepatitis

Pathophysiology
  • Splanchnic vasodilation* â renal hypoperfusion â RAAS
    activation â overwhelming renal vasoconstriction â AKI
  • Precipitants: gastrointestinal bleed, infection (eg, SBP)

Diagnosis
  • Bland urinalysis
  • Very low urine Na+ (<10 mEq/L)
  • Exclusion of other causes of AKI
  • No improvement with trial of volume expansion

Treatment
  • Albumin + splanchnic vasoconstrictors** (temporizing)
  • Liver transplantation (curative)

*Due to excess local release of vasodilators (eg, nitric oxide).

**Terlipressin, norepinephrine, or midodrine plus octreotide.

AKI = acute kidney injury; RAAS = renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system; SBP = spontaneous bacterial peritonitis.

title: Fibromuscular dysplasia
noteText:
Fibromuscular dysplasia

Clinical presentation
  • 90% women (in adults)
  • Internal carotid artery stenosis
    • Recurrent headache
    • Pulsatile tinnitus
    • Transient ischemic attack
    • Stroke
  • Renal artery stenosis
    • Secondary hypertension
    • Flank pain

Physical examination
  • Subauricular systolic bruit
  • Abdominal bruit

Diagnosis
  • Imaging preferred (eg, duplex US, CTA, MRA)
  • Catheter-based arteriography

Treatment
  • Antihypertensives (ACE inhibitors or ARBs 1st line)
  • PTA
  • Surgery (if PTA unsuccessful)
ARB = angiotensin II receptor blocker; CTA = CT angiography; MRA = MR angiography; PTA = percutaneous transluminal angioplasty; US = ultrasonography.

title: Tumor lysis syndrome
Hypoxic vasoconstriction
noteText:
Appropriate compensatory PaCO2 or HCO3â changes in acid-base disorders

Metabolic acidosis
(acute or chronic)

Expected PaCO2 = (1.5 Ã HCO3â) + 8 Â± 2 (Winters formula)

Metabolic alkalosis
(acute or chronic)

~7 mm Hg â in PaCO2 per 10 mEq/L â in HCO3â

Respiratory acidosis
(chronic only*)

~4 mEq/L â in HCO3â per 10 mm Hg â in PaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis
(chronic only*)

~4 mEq/L â in HCO3â per 10 mm Hg â in PaCO2

*Compensation for respiratory disturbances is minimal in the acute setting.  The full level of chronic compensation is achieved after ~72 hr.  For simplicity, normal baseline PaCO2 & HCO3â should be considered 40 mm Hg & 24 mEq/L, respectively.

title: Obesity hypoventilation syndrome
noteText:
Obesity hypoventilation syndrome

Diagnostic criteria
  • Obesity with BMI â¥30 kg/m2
  • Awake daytime hypercapnia (PaCO2 >45 mm Hg)
  • No alternate cause of hypoventilation

Workup
  • ABG on room air (hypercapnia, normal A-a gradient)
  • No intrinsic pulmonary disease on chest x-ray
  • Restrictive pattern on PFTs
  • Normal TSH
  • Polysomnography

Treatment
  • Nocturnal positive pressure ventilation as first-line therapy
  • Weight loss (bariatric surgery in select cases)
  • Avoidance of sedative medications
  • Respiratory stimulants (eg, acetazolamide) as last resort

ABG = arterial blood gas; PFT = pulmonary function test.

title: Renal osteodystrophy
Causes of neonatal acute kidney injury
noteText:
Common causes of neonatal acute kidney injury

Prerenal disease
  • Hypovolemia
  • Cardiac disease
  • Sepsis

Intrinsic renal
disease
  • Acute tubular necrosis (eg, ischemic injury)
  • Nephrotoxins (eg, maternal NSAID use, aminoglycosides)
  • Renal vascular disease (eg, renal vein thrombosis)
  • Glomerular & cystic disease (eg, polycystic kidney disease)
  • Congenital anomalies (eg, renal agenesis)

Postrenal
disease
  • Obstructive uropathy (eg, posterior urethral valves)

NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug.

title: Chronic dyspnoea in sickle cell disease
noteText:
Chronic dyspnea in sickle cell disease

Cause

Symptoms

Diagnostic findings

Asthma
  • Intermittent/chronic wheezing
  • May be worse at night or with exercise or upper respiratory infection
  • Pulmonary function testing showing reversible airway obstruction

Pulmonary
hypertension
  • Exertional dyspnea
  • Signs of right-sided heart failure (eg, jugular venous distension, edema)
  • Tricuspid regurgitation on echocardiography
  • â Pulmonary arterial pressure on right-sided heart catheterization

Pulmonary
fibrosis
  • Exertional dyspnea
  • Progressive
  • Honeycomb pattern on CT scan of the chest
  • Pulmonary function testing showing restrictive pattern

title: Arachidonic acid pathway
COPD
Excercise induced bronchoconstriction
noteText:
Exercise-induced bronchoconstriction

Pathophysiology
  • Hyperventilation â incomplete heating & humidification of inspired air â cooler, dry air triggers mast cell degranulation & bronchospasm
  • Can occur in isolation or in underlying asthma

Clinical features
& diagnosis
  • â Exercise tolerance; asthma symptoms appear within 5-10 min & improve* after 20 min of exercise
  • Diagnosis:
    • Supportive: empiric response to preexercise bronchodilator
    • Confirmatory: bronchoprovocation testing (eg, spirometry before & after exercise) showing â¥15% decline in FEV1

Management
  • Improve control of underlying asthma (ie, step-up therapy)
  • Premedicate before exercise: ICS-formoterol (10 min prior) preferred over SABA, LTRA (2 hr prior)
  • Daily ICS-beta agonist or LTRA may be needed for frequent, prolonged exercise

*Refractory period (â preformed mast cell mediators & â inhibitory prostaglandins).

ICS = inhaled corticosteroid; LTRA = leukotriene receptor antagonist; SABA = short-acting beta agonist.

Amyloid names begin with "A" followed by the precursor protein abbreviation.

*ATTR also occurs in a hereditary form that affects younger patients.

CTS = carpal tunnel syndrome; ESRD = end-stage renal disease.

title: Heart failure
Aortic stenosis vs HOCM
noteText:
Physical examination features of LVOT obstruction due to aortic stenosis & hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

(eg, Valsalva strain phase)

LVOT = left ventricular outflow tract.

title: Alcohol induced cardiomyopathy
noteText:
Alcohol-induced cardiomyopathy

Pathophysiology
  • Direct toxicity of ethanol leads to contractile dysfunction
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy eventually develops

Clinical presentation
  • History of heavy & prolonged alcohol use
  • Symptomatic HFrEF (eg, dyspnea, volume overload)
  • Laboratory evidence of heavy alcohol use (eg, AST/ALT >2:1)

Diagnosis
  • Consistent clinical presentation
  • Exclusion of other causes of HFrEF (eg, ischemic heart disease)

Management
  • Complete alcohol abstinence (may reverse cardiomyopathy)
  • Standard treatment of persistent HFrEF (eg, ARNI, diuretic)

ALT = alanine aminotransferase; ARNI = angiotensin receptor blocker-neprilysin inhibitor; AST = aspartate aminotransferase; HFrEF = heart failure with reduced ejection fraction.

title: Cor pulmonale
noteText:
Cor pulmonale

Etiology
  • RV failure due to pulmonary disease & resulting pulmonary HTN:
    • Chronic hypoxic vasoconstriction (eg, COPD, ILD, OHS)
    • Pulmonary thromboembolic disease
  • Absence of left-sided heart failure

Symptoms
  • Exertional fatigue, weakness, syncope (â cardiac output)
  • Exertional angina (â RV oxygen demand)
  • Venous congestion: abdominal distension, early satiety

Signs
  • Precordial heave due to RV hypertrophy
  • Loud P2 due to pulmonary HTN
  • Right-sided S3 &/or S4
  • Holosystolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation
  • JVD with HJR, ascites, peripheral edema, hepatomegaly

COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; HJR = hepatojugular reflux; HTN = hypertension; ILD = interstitial lung disease; JVD = jugular venous distension; OHS = obesity hypoventilation syndrome; RV = right ventricular.

title: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
noteText:
Stress-induced (takotsubo) cardiomyopathy

Risk factors
  • Postmenopausal woman
  • Recent physical or emotional stressor

Clinical features
  • Chest pain mimicking myocardial infarction
  • Decompensated heart failure
  • Moderate troponin elevation
  • ECG: ischemic changes in precordial leads

Diagnosis
  • Catheterization: no obstructive CAD
  • Echo: LV apical hypokinesis, basilar hyperkinesis

Treatment
  • Resolves in several weeks with supportive care

CAD = coronary artery disease; LV = left ventricular.

title: Chronic venous insufficiency
noteText:
Chronic venous insufficiency

Risk factors
  • Advanced age, family history
  • Prolonged standing, obesity
  • Smoking, prior deep vein thrombosis or trauma

Clinical features
  • Leg discomfort/pain & heaviness, often improve with walking
  • Varicose veins & telangiectasia, edema
  • Stasis dermatitis (chronic): pruritus, scaling, brawny discoloration, woody induration
  • Ulceration: painful, irregular ulcers with shallow bases, most often near medial malleoli

Initial management
  • Leg elevation, when possible
  • Leg exercises (eg, ankle flexion, walking) to â calf strength & venous return
  • Compression therapy (eg, graduated compression stockings)

title: Hypoplastic left heart syndrome
Costochondritis
pulsus paradoxus in severe asthma
Pericardial effusion
Medication induced orthostasis
noteText:
Medication-induced orthostasis

Mechanism

Examples

Î±1 blockadeâmediated vasodilation
  • Terazosin, prazosin, doxazosin
  • Antipsychotics (eg, risperidone)
  • Antihistamines, TCAs

Other vasodilation
  • ACE inhibitors & ARBs
  • Dihydropyridine CCBs
  • Hydralazine, nitrates
  • Phosphodiesterase inhibitors

Volume depletion
  • Diuretics
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors

Sympathetic blockade
  • Î² blockers
  • Clonidine

ARBs = angiotensin II receptor blockers; CCBs = calcium channel blockers;
SGLT-2 = sodium-glucose cotransporter-2; TCAs = tricyclic antidepressants.

title: Viral myocarditis
noteText:
Viral myocarditis

Clinical presentation
  • Commonly asymptomatic & resolves without detection
  • Heart failure that may progress to DCM*
  • Chest pain, ventricular arrhythmia with risk of SCD
  •  Relatively young adults usually affected (eg, age <55)
  • Â± Viral prodrome (eg, fever, malaise, myalgia)

Diagnosis
  • ECG: nonspecific findings
  • Laboratory: mild to moderate serum troponin elevation
  • Echocardiography: 4-chamber dilation with diffuse hypokinesis
  • Cardiac MRI: epicardial or midwall enhancement
  • Biopsy: lymphocytic infiltration, viral DNA or RNA**

Treatment
  • Supportive care to allow time for recovery
  • HFrEF medications (eg, diuretic, ACE inhibitor, beta blocker)
  • Temporary ventricular assist device, if needed
  • Heart transplant if no recovery

*Most common symptomatic presentation.

**Endomyocardial biopsy is rarely required for diagnosis.

DCM = dilated cardiomyopathy; HFrEF = heart failure with reduced ejection fraction; SCD = sudden cardiac death.

Dilated cardiomyopathy

Pathophysiology
  • Myocardial contractile dysfunction â ventricular dilation
  • Heart failure & myocardial fibrosis can eventually develop*
  • May be preceded by myocarditis (myocardial inflammation)

Notable causes
  • Infection (eg, viral, Chagas disease)
  • Toxins (eg, alcohol, cocaine)
  • Medications (eg, anthracyclines, anti-HER2 agents)
  • Inherited (eg, classic familial, Duchenne muscular dystrophy)
  • Rheumatologic/infiltrative (eg, sarcoidosis, amyloidosis)
  • Nutritional deficiency (eg, thiamine, selenium)
  • Other (eg, idiopathic, peripartum, tachycardia induced)

*Cardiomyopathy may be reversible if disease process is halted before substantial fibrosis develops.

Causes of myocarditis*

Infectious
  • Viral (eg, coxsackievirus, adenovirus)**
  • Protozoal (eg, Chagas disease)
  • Spirochetal (eg, Lyme disease)
  • Rickettsial (eg, RMSF)
  • Fungal (eg, histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
  • Mycobacterial (ie, tuberculosis)
  • Helminthic (eg, strongyloidiasis, trichinosis)
  • Bacterial toxins (eg, diphtheria)

Noninfectious
  • Rheumatologic disorders (eg, sarcoidosis, SLE)
  • Medication hypersensitivity (eg, antibiotics, clozapine)

*Some etiologies may cause persistent contractile dysfunction that can progress to dilated cardiomyopathy.

**Most common cause.

RMSF = Rocky Mountain spotted fever; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus.

title: blunt chest trauma
Malignant pericardial effusion
noteText:
Malignant pericardial effusion

Etiology
  • Common primary tumors: lung, breast, GI tract, lymphoma, melanoma
  • May be initial manifestation of malignancy or recurrence

Clinical features
  • Progressive dyspnea, chest fullness, fatigue
  • ECG: â QRS voltage Â± electrical alternans
  • CXR: enlarged cardiac silhouette & clear lung fields
  • Echocardiography: large effusion Â± signs of tamponade (eg, right atrial collapse)

Treatment
  • Acute management: pericardiocentesis, cytologic fluid analysis
  • Prevention of recurrence: prolonged drainage (eg, catheter, pericardial window)

CXR = chest x-ray; GI = gastrointestinal.

title: Orthostatic syncope
noteText:
Orthostatic syncope

Etiologies
  • Medications (eg, vasodilators, inotropic/chronotropic blockade, diuretics)
  • Autonomic dysfunction (eg, advanced age, neurodegenerative disease)
  • Hypovolemia (eg, fluid restriction, GI losses, fever)

Clinical features
  • Typically occurs with standing from seated/supine position
  • Premonitory symptoms (eg, light-headedness, visual blurring) common

Diagnosis
  • â¥20 mm Hg â in SBP or â¥10 mm Hg â in DBP after standing from supine position

Treatment
  • Modify postural transitions (eg, rise slowly when standing)
  • Discontinue or â dose of exacerbating medications
  • Increase fluid & salt intake

DBP = diastolic blood pressure; GI = gastrointestinal; SBP = systolic blood pressure.

title: Blunt cardiac injury
noteText:
Blunt cardiac injury

Pathophysiology
  • Rapid deceleration or direct blow to the precordium â shearing, compression, abrupt pressure change

Clinical
spectrum
  • Arrhythmia ranging from asymptomatic (eg, PVCs) to fatal (eg, VFib)
  • Acute coronary syndrome from coronary dissection or thrombosis
  • Myocardial dysfunction ("myocardial contusion")
  • Ruptured valve, septum, or ventricular wall
  • Cardiac tamponade

Confirmatory
testing
  • ECG
  • Echocardiography

PVCs = premature ventricular contractions; VFib = ventricular fibrillation.

title: Initial pharmacologic treatment of HTN
noteText:
Initial pharmacologic treatment of hypertension

No relevant comorbidity
  • ACE inhibitor
  • ARB
  • Thiazide diuretic
  • Calcium channel blocker (dihydropyridine)

Coronary artery disease
  • Consider Î²-blocker, ACE inhibitor/ARB

Chronic kidney disease
(including diabetic nephropathy)
  • Consider ACE inhibitor/ARB

Heart failure
  • Consider ACE inhibitor/ARB, Î²-blocker, diuretic, SGLT-2 inhibitor, mineralocorticoid antagonist based on ventricular ejection fraction

BP â¥10-20 mm Hg above goal
  • Consider 2-drug therapy

ARB = angiotensin receptor blocker; BP = blood pressure; SGLT-2 = sodium-glucose cotransporter-2.

title: Chronic venous stasis
noteText:
Chronic venous stasis

Risk factors
  • Obesity
  • Advanced age
  • Varicose veins
  • History of DVT

Clinical features
  • Leg pain (achy, heavy)
  • Edema
  • Venous dilation (varicosities, telangiectasias)
  • Dermatitis: erythema, pruritus, scaling, weeping
  • Chronic woody induration and brown discoloration
  • Ulcers

Management
  • Elevation
  • Compression stockings

DVT = deep vein thrombosis.

Postthrombotic syndrome

Epidemiology
  • Chronic venous insufficiency following acute DVT
  • Most cases arise within 2 years of thrombus

Manifestations
  • Leg edema, fatigue, pain, superficial venous dilation, venous stasis ulcers
  • Often worse at the end of the day

Treatment
  • Exercise (eg, ankle flexion, walking)
  • Compression (eg, bandages, stockings)

DVT = deep vein thrombosis.

title: Amiodarone adverse effect
noteText:
Amiodarone adverse effects

Cardiac
  • Bradycardia
  • QT interval prolongation*

Pulmonary
  • Interstitial pneumonitis
  • Organizing pneumonia, lung nodules

Endocrine
  • Hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism

Hepatic
  • Hepatitis

Ophthalmic
  • Corneal microdeposits
  • Optic neuritis

Dermatologic
  • Blue-gray skin discoloration

Neurologic
  • Peripheral neuropathy

*Low risk for torsades de pointes compared to other QT intervalâprolonging medications.

title: Flow volume loop
Asthmatic bronchiole
Adverse effect of inhaled steroid
noteText:
Adverse effects of inhaled corticosteroids

Local

~75% of dose deposited in oropharynx

  • Dysphonia: steroid-induced laryngeal myopathy; common (50%) & usually minor
  • Thrush: affects tongue & pharynx (esophagus: very rarely); prevent by rinsing & gargling with water, using spacer (decrease local deposition)
  • Other: contact dermatitis (budesonide hypersensitivity); cough & reflex bronchoconstriction

Systemic*

~25% of dose deposited in peripheral lung & systemically absorbed

  • HPA axis: secondary adrenal insufficiency (usually subclinical); can coexist with ICS-induced Cushing syndrome
  • Skeletal: small â osteoporosis & fracture risk
  • Other: dermal thinning (fragile skin, purpura), ocular effects (cataract formation, â IOP), small â CAP risk in patients with COPD

*Uncommon. Typically seen only with prolonged (years) high-dose ICS use, superimposed oral glucocorticoid use, or concurrent administration of potent cytochrome P-450 3A4 inhibitor.

CAP = community-acquired pneumonia; COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; HPA = hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal; ICS = inhaled corticosteroid; IOP = intraocular pressure.

title: Features of respiratory failure in acute asthma
noteText:
Features of respiratory failure in acute asthma

Clinical features
  • Absent/minimal wheezing (poor air movement â silent chest)
  • Accessory muscle use
  • Altered mental status

Laboratory findings
  • ABG*: poor ventilation (â PaCO2 & â pH), poor oxygenation (â PaO2)
  • Lactate: transient â due to muscle WOB (type A) &/or Î²-agonistâinduced (type B)
  • K+: transient â due to Î²-agonist &/or respiratory alkalosis

Management
  • Nebulized albuterol & ipratropium, IV corticosteroids Â± IV magnesium
  • Short trial (<2 hr) of NIPPV
  • Low threshold for intubation & invasive mechanical ventilation

*Impending respiratory failure: ââ respiratory effort to maintain normal/borderline PaCO2 & pH.

ABG = arterial blood gases; IV = intravenous; NIPPV = noninvasive positive pressure ventilation; WOB = work of breathing.

title: NIPPV For Obstructive lung disease
noteText:
Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation

Indications
(strongest evidence)
  • COPD (severe exacerbation, prevent extubation failure)
  • Cardiogenic pulmonary edema
  • Acute respiratory failure
    • Postoperative hypoxemic respiratory failure
    • Immunosuppressed patients
  • Facilitate early extubation

Contraindications

Medical instability

  • Cardiac or respiratory arrest (or impending arrest)
  • Severe acidosis (pH <7.1)
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • Nonrespiratory organ failure
    • Unstable cardiac arrhythmia/hemodynamic instability
    • Encephalopathy (Glasgow Coma Score <10)
    • Gastrointestinal bleed

Inability to protect airway

  • Uncooperative or agitated
  • Inability to clear secretions/high aspiration risk

Mechanical issues

  • Recent esophageal anastomosis
  • Facial or neurologic surgery, deformity, or trauma
  • Upper airway obstruction

COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

title: Tracheomalacia
Occupational asthma
noteText:
Occupational asthma

Pathogenesis
& high-risk
occupations
  • Workplace antigens â inflammation (IgE-dependent or independent) â bronchoconstriction
  • Classic antigens: animal proteins (eg, animal workers, seafood processors), grain carbohydrates (eg, bakers), isocyanates (eg, painters), metals (eg, welders)
  • Latency (months/years) due to gradual sensitization

Clinical
features
  • Initially, symptoms clearly exacerbated at workplace & relieved at home
  • Over time, symptoms persist throughout week & subside only after sustained work absence
  • Diagnosis: confirm asthma or BHR (eg, methacholine bronchoprovocation) â confirm workplace-specific worsening of obstruction (eg, serial PEFR at home & work)

Management
  • Antigen avoidance (change of workplace if possible) or reduction (eg, respirator, shift rotation)
  • Bronchodilators & inhaled corticosteroids
  • Desensitization (immunotherapy)

BHR = bronchial hyperresponsiveness; PEFR = peak expiratory flow rate.

title: Characteristics of cardiac tamponade
noteText:
Characteristics of cardiac tamponade

Rapidity of fluid accumulation

Acute

Subacute

Minutes to hours

Days to weeks

Clinical signs

Beck triad: hypotension, JVD, muffled heart sounds

Pulsus paradoxus (>10 mm Hg decrease in SBP with inspiration)

Effusion volume

100-200 mL

1-2 L

Chest x-ray findings

Normal cardiac silhouette

Enlarged, globular cardiac silhouette

JVD = jugular venous distension; SBP = systolic blood pressure.

title: AECOPD
noteText:
Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

Precipitants
  • Infectious (70%): respiratory viruses (eg, rhinovirus) & commensal bacteria (eg, nontypeable Haemophilus influenzae)
  • Noninfectious (30%): sterile inflammation (underlying disease), pulmonary embolism, inhaled irritants

Pathophysiology
& presentation
  • Bronchial inflammation: systemic response (eg, fever, leukocytosis) usually absent
  • Cardinal symptoms: â dyspnea, â sputum volume, â sputum purulence
  • â WOB (hyperinflation) & impaired gas exchange (hypoxemia [â V/Q], hypercapnia [â VD])

Management
  • Maximize expiratory flow: inhaled bronchodilators
  • Reduce airway inflammation: systemic glucocorticoids
  • Treat underlying triggers: Â± antibiotics* &/or antivirals (influenza, COVID-19)
  • Maintain adequate oxygenation: SpO2 target 88%-92%
  • Maintain adequate ventilation: NIPPV or invasive mechanical ventilation

*Antibiotics generally indicated if (1) there is increased sputum purulence + â¥1 other cardinal symptoms or (2) patient requires hospitalization.

NIPPV = noninvasive positive pressure ventilation; VD = alveolar dead space ventilation; V/Q = ventilation/perfusion ratio; WOB = work of breathing.

Management of stable chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

Nonpharmacologic
  • Smoking cessation*
  • Pulmonary rehabilitation*
  • Vaccination (influenza*, pneumococcal, COVID-19)
  • Long-term oxygen therapy* if SaO2 â¤88% at rest
  • Nocturnal noninvasive ventilation if daytime hypercapnia*

Surgical
  • Lung volume reduction or lung transplantation for advanced disease*

Medications
  • Bronchodilators (LAMA, LABA) Â± ICS
  • Long-term macrolide (eg, azithromycin 3Ã weekly)**
  • PDE4 inhibitor (eg, roflumilast)**
  • Biologic therapy (eg, antiâIL-5 mAb) if eosinophilic/asthma overlap**

*Reduces mortality.

**Reduces hospitalizations for patients with frequent exacerbations.

ICS = inhaled corticosteroid; LABA = long-acting Î²2 agonist; LAMA = long-acting muscarinic antagonist; mAb = monoclonal antibody; PDE4 = phosphodiesterase 4.

title: Asthma in pregnancy
noteText:
Asthma in pregnancy

Risk factors
  • Severe asthma prior to pregnancy
  • Obesity & excessive first-trimester weight gain
  • Smoking during pregnancy

Clinical
features
  • Symptoms: cough, wheezing, shortness of breath, chest tightness
  • Precipitants: URTI, cold air, allergens, exercise
  • Complications: preterm delivery, low birth weight, antenatal hypoxia

Management
  • Smoking cessation, asthma action plan, reducing environmental triggers
  • ICS-Î²2 agonist PRN (intermittent) or scheduled (persistent)
  • Systemic corticosteroid (eg, prednisone) for acute exacerbation

ICS = inhaled corticosteroid; URTI = upper respiratory tract infection.

test

screening

title: Normal thymus
Lt lung mass
Asbestosis
noteText:
Clinical features of asbestosis

Clinical presentation
  • Prolonged asbestos exposure (eg, shipyard, mining)
  • Symptoms develop >20 years after initial exposure
  • Progressive dyspnea, basilar fine crackles, clubbing
  • Increased risk for lung cancer & mesothelioma

Diagnostic evaluation
  • Pleural plaques on chest imaging
  • Imaging, PFT & histology consistent with pulmonary fibrosis

PFT = pulmonary function testing.

title: Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy
noteText:
Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy

Clinical
features
  • Digital clubbing (enlargement of distal digit tissue, flattening/convexity of nail fold)
  • Periostosis (tender thickening of periosteum)
  • Joint pain & effusions

Disease
associations
  • Lung malignancy: lung adenocarcinoma, metastasis
  • Nonmalignant lung disease: cystic fibrosis, bronchiectasis, lung abscess

title: Hyponatremia classification
noteText:
Classification of hyponatremia

Serum osmolality

ECV

Urine findings

Causes

Hypotonic (<275 mOsm/kg)

Hypovolemic

UNa <40 mEq/L
  • Nonrenal salt loss (eg, vomiting, diarrhea)

UNa >40 mEq/L
  • Renal salt loss (eg, diuretics, primary adrenal insufficiency)

Euvolemic

UOsm <100 mOsm/kg
  • Primary polydipsia
  • Malnutrition (eg, beer potomania)

UOsm >100 mOsm/kg & UNa >40 mEq/L
  • SIADH*

Hypervolemic

Variable
  • Heart failure, cirrhosis, nephrotic syndrome

Isotonic

Variable
  • Pseudohyponatremia (eg, paraproteinemia, hyperlipidemia)

Hypertonic (>295 mOsm/kg)
  • Translocational hyponatremia (eg, hyperglycemia, exogenous solutes such as mannitol)

*Hypothyroidism & secondary adrenal insufficiency should be ruled out.

ECV = extracellular volume; SIADH = syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion; UNa = urine sodium; UOsm = urine osmolality.

title: D/D of chest pain
noteText:
Differential diagnosis & features of chest pain

Coronary artery
disease
  • Substernal
  • Precipitated by exertion
  • Relieved by rest or nitroglycerin

Pulmonary/pleuritic
(pleurisy, pneumonia,
pericarditis, PE)

Aortic
(dissection,
intramural hematoma)

  • Hypertension and/or inherited aortopathy

Esophageal
  • Substernal, may refer to neck
  • Associated with regurgitation
  • Provoked by recumbent position
  • Nonexertional, relieved by antacids

Chest wall/
musculoskeletal
  • Persistent pain
  • Worse with movement or change in position
  • Often follows repetitive activity

PE = pulmonary embolism.

Risk factors for coronary heart disease
 

Highest risk factors (coronary heart disease equivalents)
  • Noncoronary atherosclerotic disease
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Chronic kidney disease
 

Major risk factors
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperlipidemia (â LDL & triglycerides)
  • Cigarette smoking
  • Advanced age
  • Obesity
  • Physical inactivity

title: Neonatal consequence of maternal diabetes
noteText:
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in infants of diabetic mothers

Pathogenesis
  • Maternal hyperglycemia â fetal hyperglycemia & hyperinsulinemia
  • â Glycogen & fat deposition in interventricular septum â dynamic LVOT obstruction

Clinical findings
  • Often asymptomatic
  • May have respiratory distress and/or hypotension
  • Systolic ejection murmur

Imaging
  • Chest x-ray: cardiomegaly
  • Echocardiogram: â thickness of interventricular septum, â LV chamber size

Treatment
  • Intravenous fluids & beta blockers to increase LV blood volume

Prognosis
  • Spontaneous regression by age 1

LVOT = left ventricular outflow tract.

Features

title: Carbon monoxide poisoning
noteText:
Carbon monoxide poisoning

Epidemiology
  • Smoke inhalation
  • Defective heating systems
  • Gas motors operating in poorly ventilated areas

Manifestations

Mild-moderate

  • Headache, confusion
  • Malaise, dizziness, nausea

Severe

  • Seizure, syncope, coma
  • Myocardial ischemia, arrhythmias

Diagnosis
  • ABG: carboxyhemoglobin level
  • ECG Â± cardiac enzymes

Treatment
  • High-flow 100% oxygen
  • Intubation/hyperbaric oxygen (severe)

ABG = arterial blood gas.

title: Acute pericarditis
noteText:
Acute pericarditis

Etiology
  • Viral or idiopathic
  • Autoimmune disease (eg, SLE)
  • Uremia (acute or chronic kidney failure)
  • Post myocardial infarction
    • Early: peri-infarction pericarditis
    • Late: Dressler syndrome

Clinical features & diagnosis
  • Pleuritic chest pain (â when sitting) Â± fever
  • Pericardial friction rub (highly specific)
  • ECG: diffuse ST-segment elevation & PR-segment depression
  • Echocardiography: pericardial effusion

Treatment
  • NSAIDs & colchicine for viral or idiopathic etiology
  • Variable for other etiologies

NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus.

Postâcardiac injury syndrome

Causes
  • Myocardial infarction (ie, Dressler syndrome)
  • Cardiac surgery or trauma
  • Percutaneous coronary intervention

Clinical features
  • Latent period of several weeks to months
  • Pleuritic chest pain, fever, leukocytosis
  • Chest x-ray: pleural effusion Â± enlarged cardiac silhouette
  • Echocardiography: pericardial effusion

Treatment
  • NSAID (usually high-dose aspirin) Â± colchicine
  • Corticosteroid in refractory disease

Prognosis
  • Usually self-limited disease course
  • May cause chronic/recurrent disease leading to constrictive pericarditis

NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug.

title: Purulent pericardial effusion
noteText:
Purulent pericardial effusion

Etiology
  • Hematogenous or direct intrathoracic spread
  • Risk factors: immunosuppression, hemodialysis, recent thoracic surgery/trauma
  • Organisms: Staphylococcus aureus (most common), Streptococcus pneumoniae, Salmonella, Candida

Clinical
features
  • Acute presentation, patients often appear severely ill
  • Fevers, chills, chest pain (pleuritic or nonpleuritic)
  • Can be rapidly fatal

Diagnosis
  • ECG: tachycardia, diffuse ST-segment elevation, Â± low-voltage QRS complexes
  • CXR: enlarged cardiac silhouette & clear lung fields
  • Echocardiography: pericardial effusion
  • Cytology: turbid fluid with â WBCs (neutrophil predominant), â protein, â glucose

Treatment
  • Intravenous antibiotics + pericardial drainage

CXR = chest x-ray; WBCs = white blood cells.

title: Bronchial carcinoid tumor
noteText:
Bronchial carcinoid tumor

Epidemiology
  • Most common lung cancer in adolescents/young adults

Manifestations
  • Proximal airway obstruction (eg, dyspnea, wheezing, cough)

title: SIADH
noteText:
Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone

Etiologies
  • CNS disturbance (eg, stroke, hemorrhage, trauma)
  • Medications (eg, carbamazepine, SSRIs, NSAIDs)
  • Lung disease (eg, pneumonia)
  • Ectopic ADH secretion (eg, small cell lung cancer)
  • Pain &/or nausea

Clinical
features
  • Mild/moderate hyponatremia: nausea, forgetfulness
  • Severe hyponatremia: seizures, coma
  • Euvolemia (eg, moist mucous membranes, no edema, no JVD)

Laboratory
findings
  • Hyponatremia
  • Serum osmolality <275 mOsm/kg H2O (hypotonic)
  • Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg H2O
  • Urine sodium >40 mEq/L

Management
  • Fluid restriction Â± salt tablets
  • Hypertonic (3%) saline for severe hyponatremia

ADH = antidiuretic hormone; JVD = jugular venous distension; NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; SSRIs = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors.

title: Superior pulmonary sulcus tumor
noteText:
Common manifestations of superior pulmonary sulcus tumor
  • Shoulder pain
  • Horner syndrome (invasion of paravertebral sympathetic chain/stellate ganglion)
    • Ipsilateral ptosis, miosis, enophthalmos & anhidrosis
  • Neurologic symptoms in the arm (invasion of C8-T2 nerves)
    • Weakness/atrophy of intrinsic hand muscles
    • Pain/paresthesia of 4th/5th digits & medial arm/forearm
  • Supraclavicular lymphadenopathy
  • Weight loss

title: Malignant pericardial effusion
noteText:
Malignant pericardial effusion

Etiology
  • Common primary tumors: lung, breast, GI tract, lymphoma, melanoma
  • May be initial manifestation of malignancy or recurrence

Clinical features
  • Progressive dyspnea, chest fullness, fatigue
  • ECG: â QRS voltage Â± electrical alternans
  • CXR: enlarged cardiac silhouette & clear lung fields
  • Echocardiography: large effusion Â± signs of tamponade (eg, right atrial collapse)

Treatment
  • Acute management: pericardiocentesis, cytologic fluid analysis
  • Prevention of recurrence: prolonged drainage (eg, catheter, pericardial window)

CXR = chest x-ray; GI = gastrointestinal.

title: Constrictive pericarditis
noteText:
Constrictive pericarditis

Etiology
  • Recurrent idiopathic or viral pericarditis
  • Cardiac surgery or radiation therapy
  • Tuberculous pericarditis (endemic areas)

Clinical presentation
  • Fatigue, dyspnea on exertion
  • Peripheral edema, ascites, hepatic congestion
  • Pericardial knock in early diastole
  • Elevated JVP with Kussmaul sign*
  • Prominent y descent of JVP waveform

Diagnostic findings
  • Chest x-ray: pericardial calcification
  • Cardiac CT scan/MRI: pericardial thickening & calcification
  • Echocardiography: biatrial enlargement, normal ventricular wall thickness & cavity size, abnormal septal motion during respiration

*Absence of the expected fall in JVP during inspiration.

JVP = jugular venous pulse.

title: GERD vs Angina
noteText:
Distinguishing acid reflux from angina
 

GERD

Angina

Symptoms
  • Substernal burning or dull pain; may radiate to arms, neck, jaw
  • Frequently accompanied by cough or reflux
  • Substernal pressure; may radiate to arms, neck, jaw
  • Frequently accompanied by dyspnea

Symptom duration
  • Prolonged, constant (eg, >1 hr)
  • Short, intermittent (eg, 2-5 min for chronic angina; >15 min suggests ACS)

Precipitating factors
  • Recumbency
  • Trigger foods (eg, alcohol, coffee)
  • Physical exertion
  • Stress

Alleviating factors
  • Antacids
  • Rest
  • Nitroglycerin

ACS = acute coronary syndrome; GERD = gastroesophageal reflux disease.

title: Cyanide toxicity
noteText:
Cyanide poisoning

Common etiologies
  • Structure fires (eg, combustion of plastics)
  • Occupational exposure (eg, mining)
  • Cyanide-containing medications (eg, sodium nitroprusside)

Pathophysiology
  • Inhibits oxidative phosphorylation & forces anaerobic metabolism
  • Rapidly lethal if untreated

Clinical features
  • Hypertension, tachycardia, tachypnea â circulatory collapse, death
  • Headache, confusion, anxiety â seizures, coma
  • Cherry-red skin
  • Elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis with â lactic acid

Management
  • Decontamination
  • Supportive care (eg, 100% oxygen, intravenous fluids, vasopressors)
  • Empiric treatment with hydroxocobalamin Â± sodium thiosulfate*

*Sodium nitrite + sodium thiosulfate is an alternate treatment but is contraindicated in carbon monoxide poisoning.

Manifestations of cyanide accumulation & toxicity
  • Skin: flushing (cherry-red color), cyanosis (occurs later)
  • CNS: headache, altered mental status, seizures, coma
  • Cardiovascular: arrhythmias
  • Respiratory: tachypnea followed by respiratory depression, pulmonary edema
  • Gastrointestinal: abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting
  • Renal: metabolic acidosis (from lactic acidosis), kidney failure

title: Peripartum cardiomyopathy
noteText:
Peripartum cardiomyopathy

Risk factors
  • Maternal age >30
  • Multiple gestation
  • Eclampsia or preeclampsia

Clinical features
  • Left ventricular ejection fraction <45%
  • Onset at â¥36 weeks gestation or â¤5 months postdelivery
  • No other causes of heart failure

Management
  • Urgent delivery if hemodynamic instability present
  • Standard management of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (eg, beta blocker, diuretics)

Increased rate
  • Tachycardia/palpitations
  • Atrial fibrillation

Peripheral vasodilation

title: Cardiac tamponde
noteText:
Cardiac tamponade

Etiology
  • Blood in pericardial space (eg, left ventricular rupture, cardiac surgery)
  • Pericardial effusion (eg, malignancy, infection, uremia)

Clinical signs
  • Beck triad: hypotension, JVD, â heart sounds
  • Pulsus paradoxus: >10 mm Hg drop in SBP during inspiration

Diagnosis
  • ECG: low-voltage QRS complex, electrical alternans
  • Chest x-ray: enlarged cardiac silhouette,* clear lungs
  • Echocardiogram: right atrial & ventricular collapse, IVC plethora

Treatment
  • Intravenous fluids to increase right-sided preload
  • Drainage via pericardiocentesis or pericardial window

*Subacute but not acute tamponade.

IVC = inferior vena cava; JVD = jugular venous distension; SBP = systolic blood pressure.

title: Viral myocarditis
noteText:
Viral myocarditis in children

Etiology
  • Commonly coxsackievirus B or adenovirus

Clinical features
  • Viral prodrome (eg, URI, gastrointestinal infection)
  • Heart failure: respiratory distress, gallop, hepatomegaly
  • Â± Arrhythmias (can cause sudden cardiac death)

Evaluation
  • Cardiac enzymes: â troponin
  • ECG: sinus tachycardia, nonspecific ST changes
  • Chest x-ray: cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema
  • Echocardiogram: diffuse hypokinesis with â ejection fraction

Diagnosis
  • Cardiac MRI: epicardial or midwall enhancement
  • Biopsy: lymphocytic infiltration, necrosis; viral DNA or RNA*

Treatment
  • Supportive: diuretics, ACE inhibitor, inotropes
  • IVIG may reduce morbidity/mortality

* Endomyocardial biopsy is often deferred (eg, high risk of sedation/intubation in critically ill children).

IVIG = intravenous immunoglobulin; URI = upper respiratory infection.

Acute rheumatic fever

Epidemiology
  • Peak incidence: age 5-15
  • Twice as common in girls

Clinical features

Major

  • Joints (migratory arthritis)
  • â¥ (Carditis)
  • Nodules (subcutaneous)
  • Erythema marginatum
  • Sydenham chorea

Minor

  • Fever
  • Arthralgias
  • Elevated ESR/CRP
  • Prolonged PR interval

Late sequelae

Mitral regurgitation/stenosis

Prevention

Penicillin for group A streptococcal
(Streptococcus pyogenes) pharyngitis

CRP = C-reactive protein; ESR = erythrocyte sedimentation rate.

title: Beta blocker toxicity
noteText:
Beta blocker toxicity

Mechanism
  • Excessive adrenergic blockade â ââ intracellular cAMP

Clinical
presentation
  • Beta 1 blockadeâmediated effects:
    • Cardiac suppression with bradycardia & hypotension*
    • Confusion due to cerebral hypoperfusion
  • Beta 2 blockadeâmediated effects:
    • Bronchospasm
    • Hypoglycemia (impaired gluconeogenesis/glycogenolysis)
    • Confusion & seizures due to hypoglycemia**

Diagnosis
  • ECG: sinus node dysfunction, atrioventricular block
  • Consistent clinical presentation (drug levels not useful)

Treatment
  • Intravenous fluids for hypotension & atropine for bradycardia
  • Glucagon to directly counteract toxicity (â intracellular cAMP)
  • Calcium gluconate sometimes given to â blood pressure

*Beta 1 blockadeâmediated effects are predominant with cardioselective beta blockers (eg, metoprolol), whereas all effects are seen with nonselective beta blockers (eg, propranolol).

**Lipid-soluble beta blockers (eg, propranolol) can also cause confusion & seizures via direct CNS effects.

Clinical manifestations of digoxin toxicity

Cardiac
  • Life-threatening arrhythmias

Gastrointestinal
  • Anorexia
  • Nausea & vomiting
  • Abdominal pain

Neurologic
  • Fatigue
  • Confusion
  • Weakness
  • Color vision alterations

title: VSD
noteText:
Moderate or large ventricular septal defect

Timeline

Pathophysiologic changes

In utero
  • Right & left ventricular pressures equal
  • No significant hemodynamic consequences

Postnatal transition
  • â PVR, â SVR
  • Left-to-right shunting through ventricular septal defect

Infancy
  • Pulmonary overcirculation
  • Left atrial & ventricular volume overload/dilation

Late childhood
  • Pulmonary arterial vascular thickening (â PVR)
  • Reversal to right-to-left shunting (ie, Eisenmenger syndrome)

PVR = pulmonary vascular resistance; SVR = systemic vascular resistance.

title: ASD
noteText:
Atrial septal defect

Etiology
  • Septum secundum (most common)
  • Septum primum (associated with other defects)

Clinical manifestations
  • Presentation in adulthood (unless large defect)
  • Wide & fixed splitting of S2
  • Right-sided volume overload with flow murmurs
    • Midsystolic (pulmonic valve)
    • Middiastolic (tricuspid valve)
  • Atrial arrhythmias, RBBB on ECG
  • Pulmonary hypertension & right-sided heart failure

Diagnosis
  • Echocardiography

Treatment
  • Percutaneous closure or surgery

RBBB = right bundle branch block.

title: Digeorge syndrome
noteText:
22q11.2 deletion syndromes (22qDS)

Phenotypes
  • DiGeorge syndrome, velocardiofacial syndrome*

Pathogenesis
  • Loss of genes that control embryonic tissue template transformation (eg, pharyngeal apparatus, secondary heart field) and migration of neural crest cells

Clinical features (CATCH)
  • Cardiac outflow tract anomalies (eg, tetralogy of Fallot, persistent truncus arteriosus)
  • Anomalous face (eg, prominent nasal bridge, low-set ears, micro/retrognathia)
  • Thymic hypoplasia / aplasia â decreased T-cell immunity
  • Cleft palate
  • Hypoparathyroidism (hypoplastic / aplastic parathyroids) â hypocalcemia

*DiGeorge requires thymic involvement (CD3+ T-cell count <500); velocardiofacial syndrome requires facial abnormalities.

title: Fetal circulation
Complete AV canal defect
Hypersensitivity pneumonitis
noteText:
Hypersensitivity pneumonitis

Etiology
  • Immunologic response to inhaled antigen (eg, mold, animal protein)

Clinical presentation

Acute

  • Abrupt-onset fever, chills, cough, dyspnea, fatigue, leukocytosis
  • Episodes often recurrent and self-resolving
  • Chest x-ray: scattered micronodular interstitial opacities

Chronic

  • Progressive cough, dyspnea, fatigue, weight loss
  • Hypoxemia that worsens with exertion
  • Chest x-ray: diffuse reticular interstitial opacities

Diagnosis
  • PFT: restrictive pattern, â DLCO (chronic only)
  • BAL: high relative lymphocyte count
  • Lung biopsy: lymphocytic infiltrate, poorly formed noncaseating granulomas, interstitial inflammation or fibrosis (chronic only)

Treatment
  • Remove antigen exposure (resolves acute disease)
  • Glucocorticoids and/or lung transplantation (chronic only)

BAL = bronchoalveolar lavage; DLCO = diffusion capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide; PFT = pulmonary function testing.

Common types of hypersensitivity pneumonitis

Condition

Causative agent

Farmer's lung

Moldy hay

(thermophilic actinomycetes, Aspergillus spp)

Bird fancier's

lung

Proteins in avian droppings or feathers

Hot tub lung

Mycobacterium avium complex, Cladosporium spp

Mushroom worker's

lung

Thermophilic actinomycetes

Potato riddler's

lung

Wine maker's

lung

Botrytis spp

Cheese maker's

lung

Penicillium spp, Aspergillus spp

Chemical worker's lung

Spray paints, dyes, varnishes

title: Methotrexate induced lung injury
noteText:
Methotrexate-induced lung injury

Pathogenesis
& risk factors
  • Idiosyncratic (ie, not dose dependent) hypersensitivity pneumonitis
  • Risk factors: rheumatoid arthritis, parenchymal lung disease

Clinical
features
  • Onset 1-12 months: pneumonitis â fibrosis (restrictive PFTs)
  • CT scan with variable mix of patterns: inflammation (eg, GGO, consolidation) & fibrosis (eg, reticulation)
  • BAL: lymphocytosis; peripheral blood: eosinophilia
  • Trial of MTX cessation is diagnostic & therapeutic

BAL = bronchoalveolar lavage; GGO = ground-glass opacities; MTX = methotrexate; PFTs = pulmonary function tests.
