COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; DLCO = diffusing capacity for carbon monoxide; TLC = total lung capacity.

*With positive bronchodilator response.

â Normal in early COPD.

title: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
noteText:
Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis

Pathophysiology
& risk factors
  • Microscopic alveolar epithelial injury (smoking, GERD, silent aspiration)
  • Inappropriate repair by fibrosis instead of epithelial regeneration
  • Risk factors/demographics: male, age >60, smoking, polymorphisms in genes regulating epithelial regeneration & health

Clinical presentation
  • Chronic progressive dyspnea, nonproductive cough, fatigue
  • Fine, Velcro-like inspiratory crackles; digital clubbing
  • HRCT: UIP (subpleural honeycombing, reticular opacities); PFTs: restrictive pattern

Management
  • Antifibrotic therapy (eg, pirfenidone, nintedanib)
  • Smoking cessation & treatment of GERD
  • Supplemental oxygen & pulmonary rehabilitation
  • Lung transplantation

GERD = gastroesophageal reflux disease; HRCT = high-resolution computed tomography; PFT = pulmonary function test; UIP = usual interstitial pneumonia.

title: Sarcoidosis
noteText:
Manifestations of sarcoidosis

Pulmonary
  • Bilateral hilar adenopathy
  • Interstitial infiltrates

Cutaneous
  • Papular, nodular, or plaquelike lesions
  • Erythema nodosum

Ophthalmologic
  • Anterior uveitis (iridocyclitis or iritis)
  • Posterior uveitis
  • Keratoconjunctivitis sicca

Reticuloendothelial
  • Peripheral lymphadenopathy
  • Hepatomegaly
  • Splenomegaly

Musculoskeletal
  • Acute polyarthritis (especially ankles)
  • Chronic arthritis

Cardiovascular
  • Atrioventricular block
  • Dilated or restrictive cardiomyopathy

CNS/endocrine
  • Facial nerve palsy
  • Central diabetes insipidus
  • Hypercalcemia

LÃ¶fgren syndrome
  • Erythema nodosum
  • Hilar adenopathy
  • Migratory polyarthralgia
  • Fever

title: Atelactasis due to mucus plug
Asbestosis
noteText:
Clinical features of asbestosis

Clinical presentation
  • Prolonged asbestos exposure (eg, shipyard, mining)
  • Symptoms develop â¥20 years after initial exposure
  • Progressive dyspnea, basilar fine crackles, clubbing
  • Increased risk for lung cancer & mesothelioma

Diagnostic evaluation
  • Pleural plaques on chest imaging
  • Imaging, PFT & histology consistent with pulmonary fibrosis

PFT = pulmonary function testing.

title: Rx of pulmonary arterial HTN
Coarctation of aorta
noteText:
Coarctation of the aorta

Etiology
  • Congenital
  • Acquired (rare) (eg, Takayasu arteritis)

Clinical features
  • Upper body
    • Well developed
    • Hypertension (headaches, epistaxis)
  • Lower extremities
    • Underdeveloped
    • Claudication
  • Brachial-femoral pulse delay
  • Upper & lower extremity blood pressure differential
  • Left interscapular systolic or continuous murmur

Diagnostic studies
  • ECG: Left ventricular hypertrophy
  • Chest x-ray
    • Inferior notching of the 3rd to 8th ribs
    • "3" sign due to aortic indentation
  • Echocardiography: diagnostic confirmation

Treatment
  • Balloon angioplasty Â± stent placement
  • Surgery

Coarctation of the aorta

Pathology
  • Thickening of tunica media of aortic arch
  • Can be associated with Turner syndrome or bicuspid aortic valve

Clinical features
  • â BP & strong pulses in upper extremities
  • â BP & weak pulses in lower extremities
  • Neonates (critical narrowing)
    • May have differential cyanosis affecting lower extremities*
    • Heart failure & shock after ductal closure
  • Children/adults (lesser degree of narrowing)
    • Lower extremity claudication
    • Palpable pulsations of intercostal vessels (collaterals)
    • Secondary hypertension (upper body)

Complications
  • Aortic aneurysm, dissection, or rupture
  • Cerebral aneurysm & subarachnoid hemorrhage

Treatment
  • Prostaglandin E1 for neonates with critical narrowing
  • Surgical repair or balloon angioplasty with stent placement

*Open ductus arteriosus shunts deoxygenated blood into descending aorta.

BP = blood pressure.

title: Laboratory evaluation of HTN
noteText:
Laboratory evaluation of hypertension

Renal function tests
  • Serum electrolytes (Na, K, Ca)
  • Serum creatinine
  • Urinalysis
  • Urine albumin/creatinine ratio (optional)

Endocrine tests
  • Fasting glucose or hemoglobin A1c
  • Lipid profile
  • TSH

Cardiac tests
  • ECG
  • Echocardiography (optional)

Other tests
  • Complete blood count
  • Uric acid (optional)

title: Cushing syndrome
Coarctation of aorta
Turners syndrome
noteText:
Comorbidity screening in Turner syndrome

Cardiovascular
  • Congenital heart defects*: 4-extremity BP, ECG, echocardiogram
  • Aortic dilatation/dissection**: TTE or cardiac MRI
  • Metabolic syndrome: BP, HbA1c, lipid panel, LFT

Renal
  • Horseshoe kidney: renal ultrasound

Musculoskeletal
  • Osteoporosis: 25-hydroxyvitamin D level, DXA scan

Vision & hearing
  • Strabismus, myopia: ophthalmology evaluation
  • Recurrent otitis media, hearing loss: audiology testing

Autoimmune
  • Celiac disease: tissue transglutaminase antibodies
  • Hypothyroidism: TSH, free T4

*Aortic coarctation, bicuspid aortic valve.

**High risk in pregnancy.

BP = blood pressure; HbA1c = glycosylated hemoglobin; LFT = liver function test;
TTE = transthoracic echocardiogram.

title: Transposition of great arteries
Cyanosis in children
noteText:
Cyanosis in children
 

Central

Peripheral

Mechanism
  • â Systemic O2 saturation
  • â Tissue oxygen extraction

Typical causes
  • Pulmonary disease
  • Cyanotic heart disease
  • Vasomotor instability*
  • Cold exposure*
  • Low cardiac output
  • Venous obstruction

Features
  • Diffuse &/or mucosal cyanosis
  • Warm extremities
  • May improve with oxygen**
  • Finger, toe, perioral cyanosis
  • Cool extremities
  • Does not improve with oxygen

*Benign etiologies of peripheral cyanosis.

**Supplemental oxygen may improve central cyanosis due to pulmonary etiologies but will not improve central cyanosis due to right-to-left shunting (ie, cyanotic heart disease).

Routine newborn care

Preventive
  • Intramuscular vitamin K
  • Erythromycin eye ointment
  • Hepatitis B vaccine

Screening
  • Newborn screen (metabolic/genetic disorders)
  • Hyperbilirubinemia
  • Hearing screen
  • Pre- & postductal pulse oximetry (congenital heart disease)
  • Hypoglycemia (select populations)

title: Pulmonary HTN Mx
noteText:
Management of pulmonary hypertension

Group 1
PAH
  • Evaluate for autoimmune CTD, toxins (eg, amphetamines), HIV, schistosomiasis, etc.
  • Pulmonary vasodilator therapy, treat underlying (eg, autoimmune) cause

Group 2
Left-sided
heart disease
  • Echocardiography (Â± RHC if diagnosis unclear)
  • Optimize left ventricular function (eg, heart failure therapy), treat significant valve disease

Group 3
Lung disease &/or
chronic hypoxemia
  • Pulmonary function tests, chest imaging, polysomnography
  • Treat underlying respiratory condition (eg, obstructive sleep apnea)

Group 4
CTEPH
  • V/Q scan, pulmonary angiography
  • Pulmonary thromboendarterectomy surgery (curative), anticoagulation

General
measures
  • Refer to accredited PH center
  • Maintain normoxia, euvolemia & sinus rhythm
  • Contraceptive counseling, immunization, cardiac rehabilitation
  • Refractory PH: bilateral lung transplant

CTD = connective tissue disease (eg, scleroderma); CTEPH = chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension; PAH = pulmonary arterial hypertension; PH = pulmonary hypertension; RHC = right-sided heart catheterization; V/Q = ventilation-perfusion.

Clinical features of pulmonary hypertension

Classification
  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension (WHO group 1)
  • Due to left heart disease (group 2)
  • Due to chronic lung disease or hypoxemia (eg, COPD, OSA) (group 3)
  • Due to chronic thromboembolic disease (group 4)
  • Due to other causes (eg, sarcoidosis) (group 5)

Symptoms
  • â Cardiac output: exertional syncope/presyncope, fatigue, weakness
  • â PA pressure: chest tightness, hemoptysis (rare)
  • RV demand ischemia: exertional angina/tightness
  • Venous congestion: abdominal distension (bowel edema), early satiety

Signs
  • Precordial heave due to RV hypertrophy
  • Loud P2, right-sided S3 &/or S4
  • Holosystolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation
  • JVD, ascites, peripheral edema, hepatomegaly
COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; JVD = jugular venous distension; OSA = obstructive sleep apnea; PA = pulmonary artery; RV = right ventricular.

title: Peak pressure and Plateau pressure
Capnography waveform
ADPKD
noteText:
Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease

Clinical
presentation
  • Most patients asymptomatic until age 30-40
  • Flank pain, hematuria
  • Hypertension
  • Palpable abdominal masses (usually bilateral)
  • Chronic kidney disease (CKD)

Extrarenal
features
  • Cerebral aneurysms
  • Hepatic & pancreatic cysts
  • Mitral valve prolapse, aortic regurgitation
  • Colonic diverticulosis
  • Ventral & inguinal hernias

Diagnosis
  • Ultrasonography showing multiple renal cysts

Management
  • Aggressive control of risk factors for CV & CKD
  • ACE inhibitors preferred for hypertension
  • Hemodialysis, renal transplant for ESRD

CV = cardiovascular; ESRD = end-stage renal disease.

title: Small vs large VSD
noteText:
Ventricular septal defect
 

Small

Moderate to large

Clinical
features
  • Asymptomatic
  • Loud, harsh, holosystolic murmur at LLSB
  • Respiratory distress, poor feeding, poor growth (due to pulmonary overcirculation & high-output LV failure)
  • Â± Holosystolic murmur at LLSB; loud S2

Chest x-ray
  • Normal
  • Cardiomegaly
  • Increased pulmonary markings

Management
  • Serial echocardiography
  • Most spontaneously close at age <2
  • Diuretics
  • Surgical closure

LLSB = lower left sternal border; LV = left ventricular.

title: Persistent pulmonary HTN
noteText:
Persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn

Pathogenesis
  • Abnormal persistence of elevated fetal pulmonary vascular resistance
  • Right-to-left shunting across ductus arteriosus

Risk factors
  • Lung hypoplasia (eg, congenital diaphragmatic hernia)
  • Meconium aspiration syndrome
  • Infection (eg, neonatal pneumonia)

Examination
  • â Postductal relative to preductal oxygen saturation
  • Respiratory distress & cyanosis
  • Prominent S2

Treatment
  • Oxygenation & ventilation
  • Inhaled nitric oxide (pulmonary vasodilator)

title: Ductus dependent congenital heart disease
noteText:
PDA-dependent congenital heart disease
  • Coarctation of the aorta
  • D-transposition of the great arteries
  • Hypoplastic left heart syndrome
  • Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
  • Tricuspid atresia

title: Cocaine use
noteText:
Clues to surreptitious cocaine use

Behavioral
features
  • Personality & mood changes
  • Changes in sleep patterns
  • Unexplained weight loss
  • Financial difficulties

Reported
symptoms
  • Chest pain
  • Epistaxis, rhinitis (intranasal use)
  • Headaches

Examination
signs
  • Hypertension, tachycardia
  • Dilated pupils
  • Psychomotor agitation

Emergent
complications
  • Seizures
  • Acute myocardial ischemia
  • Aortic dissection
  • Intracranial hemorrhage

title: Fibromuscular dysplasia
noteText:
Clinical features of FMD

Patients to screen

Women age <50 with 1 of the following:

  • Severe or resistant hypertension
  • Onset of hypertension before age 35
  • Sudden increase in blood pressure from baseline
  • Increase in creatinine (â¥0.5-1 mg/dL) after starting angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor or angiotensin receptor blocker & without significant effect on blood pressure
  • Systolic-diastolic epigastric bruit

Clinical presentation
  • Resistant hypertension from renal artery involvement
  • Cerebrovascular FMD with symptoms of brain ischemia (eg, amaurosis fugax, Hornerâs syndrome, transient ischemic attack, stroke)
  • Nonspecific symptoms (eg, headache, pulsatile tinnitus, dizziness) from carotid or vertebral artery involvement
  • Can also involve iliac, subclavian & visceral arteries

Diagnosis & follow-up
  • Noninvasive testing preferred (eg, computed tomography angiography, duplex ultrasound)
  • Catheter-based digital subtraction arteriography for patients with inconclusive noninvasive testing
  • Medically treated patients need follow-up blood pressure & creatinine every 3-4 months & renal ultrasound every 6-12 months

FMD = fibromuscular dysplasia.

title: Choice of antihypertensive drugs
noteText:
Choice of antihypertensive drug
for comorbid conditions

Coronary
atherosclerosis
  • Angina pectoris: Î² blocker, CCB
  • Postâmyocardial infarction: ACE inhibitor or ARB, Î² blocker

Heart failure
with reduced
ejection fraction
  • ACE inhibitor or ARB, Î² blocker, diuretic, aldosterone antagonist, dihydropyridine CCB

Atrial fibrillation
or flutter
  • Î² Blocker, nondihydropyridine CCB

Chronic kidney
disease
  • ACE inhibitor or ARB

Gout
  • Losartan, other ARB, CCB (avoid diuretics)

Osteoporosis
  • Thiazide diuretic

Migraine
  • Î² Blocker, CCB

Calcium kidney stones
  • Thiazide diuretic

ARB = angiotensin II receptor blocker; CCB = calcium channel blocker.

title: Benign vs pathologic murmur
noteText:
Benign vs pathologic murmurs
 

Benign

Pathologic

History
  • Asymptomatic
  • Normal growth
  • No significant family history
  • Infants: poor weight gain, respiratory distress, difficulty feeding
  • Older children: exertional fatigue, chest pain, syncope
  • Family history of SCD or CHD

Murmur
characteristics*
  • Early or midsystolic
  • Musical or vibratory
  • Grade 1-2 intensity
  • Decreases or disappears with standing & Valsalva maneuver**
  • Holosystolic or diastolic
  • Harsh
  • Grade â¥3 intensity
  • Intensity persists with standing & Valsalva maneuver

Other
findings
  • Normal vital signs
  • Normal S1 & S2
  • Symmetric pulses
  • Central cyanosis
  • Loud, fixed, or single S2
  • Weak femoral pulses
  • Hepatomegaly

Management
  • Reassurance
  • ECG & echocardiography

*Any single pathologic feature warrants evaluation.

**Venous hum is a benign murmur exception that increases with standing.

CHD = congenital heart defect; SCD = sudden cardiac death.

title: Obstructive sleep apnea
noteText:
Obstructive sleep apnea

Pathophysiology
  • Relaxation of pharyngeal muscles, leading to closure of airway
  • Loud snoring with periods of apnea

Symptoms
  • Daytime somnolence
  • Nonrestorative sleep with frequent awakenings
  • Morning headaches
  • Affective & cognitive symptoms

Sequelae
  • Systemic hypertension
  • Pulmonary hypertension & right-sided heart failure

title: Renal artery stenosis
noteText:
Clinical clues to renovascular disease

HTN-related symptoms
  • Resistant HTN (uncontrolled despite 3-drug regimen)
  • Malignant HTN (with end-organ damage)
  • Onset of severe HTN (>180/120 mm Hg) after age 55
  • Severe HTN with diffuse atherosclerosis
  • Recurrent flash pulmonary edema with severe HTN

Supportive evidence

Physical examination

  • Asymmetric renal size (>1.5 cm)
  • Abdominal bruit

Laboratory results

  • Unexplained rise in serum creatinine (>30%) after starting ACE inhibitors or ARBs

Imaging results

  • Unexplained atrophic kidney

ARBs = angiotensin II receptor blockers; HTN = hypertension.

title: Secondary HTN causes
noteText:
Secondary causes of hypertension

Condition

Clinical clues/features

Renal parenchymal disease
  • Elevated creatinine level
  • Abnormal urinalysis (proteinuria, red blood cell casts)

Renovascular disease
  • Recurrent flash pulmonary edema
  • Elevated creatinine level (particularly with ACE inhibitor use)
  • Abdominal bruit

Primary hyperaldosteronism
  • Hypokalemia (spontaneous or thiazide induced)
  • Metabolic alkalosis

Obstructive sleep apnea
  • Daytime somnolence
  • Increased neck circumference

Pheochromocytoma
  • Paroxysmal hypertension & tachycardia
  • Headaches, palpitations, diaphoresis

Cushing syndrome
  • Cushingoid body habitus & proximal muscle atrophy
  • Hyperglycemia

Thyroid disease
  • Hyperthyroidism: anxiety, heat intolerance, weight loss, tachycardia
  • Hypothyroidism: fatigue, cold intolerance, weight gain, bradycardia

Primary hyperparathyroidism
  • Mild hypercalcemia Â± symptoms (eg, constipation)
  • Kidney stones

Coarctation of the aorta
  • Upper extremity hypertension with brachial-femoral pulse delay (common)
  • Lateralizing hypertension (less common)

title: Hpertensive disorder of pregnancy
noteText:
Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy

Chronic hypertension
  • Systolic pressure â¥140 mm Hg &/or diastolic pressure â¥90 mm Hg prior to conception or at <20 weeks gestation

Gestational hypertension
  • New-onset elevated blood pressure at â¥20 weeks gestation
  • No proteinuria or signs of end-organ damage

Preeclampsia
  • New-onset elevated blood pressure at â¥20 weeks gestation

     AND

  • Proteinuria OR signs of end-organ damage

Eclampsia
  • Preeclampsia

     AND

  • New-onset tonic-clonic seizures

title: Chronic pulmonic regurgitation
noteText:
Chronic pulmonic regurgitation

Etiologies
  • Correction of pulmonic stenosis or RVOT obstruction (iatrogenic)*
  • Rheumatic heart disease, infective endocarditis

Pathophysiology
  • Progressive RV volume overload â RV dilation & eventual failure

Clinical

findings
  • Decrescendo, diastolic murmur at LSB, â with inspiration
  • Soft (or sometimes absent) P2
  • Dyspnea & prominent parasternal impulse (once RV dilation develops)

Management
  • Serial echocardiography
  • Valve replacement once symptoms or RV dysfunction develops

*Most common cause of severe pulmonic regurgitation.

LSB = left sternal border; RV = right ventricular; RVOT = right ventricular outflow tract.

title: Causes of chronic stridor in infants
noteText:
Causes of chronic stridor in infants

Diagnosis

Pathophysiology

Symptoms

Laryngomalacia

Floppy supraglottis
  • Inspiratory stridor worse with feeding, crying, or supine positioning
  • Prominent at age 4-8 months

Vascular ring

Great vessels encircle & compress trachea
  • Biphasic stridor improved with neck extension
  • Feeding difficulties from esophageal compression

Airway hemangioma

Vascular malformation involving trachea &/or larynx
  • Growth in the first few weeks of life â progressive biphasic stridor
  • Concurrent skin hemangiomas (beard distribution) common

title: Antihypertensive during pregnancy
noteText:
Antihypertensives during pregnancy

First line

  • Beta blockers (eg, labetalol)
  • Calcium channel blockers (eg, nifedipine)
  • Hydralazine
  • Methyldopa

Second line

  • Clonidine
  • Thiazide diuretics

Contraindicated

  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin II receptor blockers

noteText:

Etiology
  • Extracellular deposition of insoluble protein fibrils

title: RAAS
Pulmonary arterial HTN
AF
noteText:
Conditions that increase the risk of atrial fibrillation

Precipitants of atrial dilation &/or
conduction remodeling
  • Advanced age
  • Systemic hypertension
  • Mitral valve dysfunction
  • Left ventricular failure
  • Coronary artery disease & related factors (eg, DM, smoking)
  • Obesity & obstructive sleep apnea
  • Chronic hypoxic lung disease (eg, COPD)

Triggers of increased automaticity
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Excessive alcohol use
  • Increased sympathetic tone
    • Acute illness (eg, sepsis, PE, MI)
    • Cardiac surgery
  • Sympathomimetic drugs (eg, cocaine)

COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; DM = diabetes mellitus; MI = myocardial infarction; PE = pulmonary embolism.

Causes of QT-interval prolongation

Acquired
  • Medications
    • Macrolides & fluoroquinolones
    • Antiemetics (eg, ondansetron)
    • Azoles (eg, fluconazole)
    • Antipsychotics, TCAs & SSRIs
    • Some opioids (eg, methadone, oxycodone)
    • Class Ia antiarrhythmics (eg, quinidine)
    • Class III antiarrhythmics (eg, dofetilide, sotalol)
  • Electrolyte abnormalities
    • â Magnesium, â potassium, â calcium

Congenital
  • Romano-Ward syndrome (autosomal dominant)
  • Jervell & Lange-Nielsen syndrome (autosomal recessive)*

*Associated with sensorineural hearing loss.

SSRIs = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors; TCAs = tricyclic antidepressants.

title: Angioedema
Gallop
noteText:
Extra (gallop) heart sounds
 

Features

Associated disorders*

S3
  • Heard just after S2
  • Caused by reverberant sound as blood fills an enlarged LV cavity during early diastolic filling
  • Heart failure with reduced EF
  • High-output states (eg, thyrotoxicosis)
  • Mitral or aortic regurgitation

S4
  • Heard just before S1
  • Caused by blood striking a stiff LV wall during atrial contraction
  • Concentric LV hypertrophy
  • Restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • Acute myocardial infarction

*S3 can be normal in children, young adults & pregnant patients.  S4 can be normal in older adults (eg, age >70).

EF = ejection fraction; LV = left ventricular.

title: Heart failure with preserved EF
noteText:
Heart failure with preserved ejection fraction

Etiology
  • LV diastolic dysfunction due to impaired relaxation

Risk factors
  • Chronic hypertension (concentric LV hypertrophy)
  • Obesity & sedentary lifestyle (myocardial interstitial fibrosis)
  • CAD & related risk factors (eg, diabetes mellitus)

Management
  • Specific therapies to reduce hospitalization & possibly mortality:
    • SGLT-2 inhibitor (eg, empagliflozin) added first
    • MRA (eg, spironolactone) added secondarily
  • Loop diuretics as needed to treat volume overload
  • Antihypertensives as needed to reduce afterload
  • Treatment of exacerbating conditions (eg, CAD, OSA, A-fib)
  • Exercise training, weight loss & cardiac rehabilitation

A-fib = atrial fibrillation; CAD = coronary artery disease; LV = left ventricular; MRA = mineralocorticoid antagonist; OSA = obstructive sleep apnea; SGLT-2 = sodium-glucose cotransporter-2.

noteText:

Increased rate

High-output heart failure

Pathophysiology
  • â SVR leads to â cardiac output & â venous return

Causes
  • Morbid obesity (most common)
  • Arteriovenous fistula (congenital or acquired)
  • Hyperthyroidism, severe anemia, advanced cirrhosis
  • Paget disease, thiamine deficiency

Clinical presentation
  • Hyperdynamic circulation (â PP, warm extremities)
  • Peripheral & pulmonary edema
  • Laterally displaced PMI, systolic flow murmur

Echocardiographic findings
  • Dilated LV, RV & inferior vena cava
  • Elevated resting cardiac index

LV = left ventricle; PMI = point of maximal impulse; PP = pulse pressure; RV = right ventricle; SVR = systemic vascular resistance.

Common mechanisms of reduced systemic vascular resistance
leading to high-output heart failure

Bypass of systemic
arteriolar resistance
  • Acquired AV fistula (eg, trauma, HD)
  • Congenital AV malformation
  • Paget disease of bone

unmet metabolic demand
in the tissues
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Severe anemia
  • Thiamine deficiency (wet beriberi)
  • Myeloproliferative disease
  • Chronic lung disease

Peripheral vasodilation
due to other factors
  • Morbid obesity (vasodilatory adipokines)
  • Cirrhosis (splanchnic vasodilation)

AV = arteriovenous; HD = hemodialysis.

title: Acute pulmonary embolism
Cardiorenal syndrome
Etiology of syncope
noteText:
Clues to etiology of syncope

Reflex syncope

Vasovagal
  • Trigger (eg, emotional stress, prolonged standing)
  • Prodrome (eg, nausea, sweating, warmth)

Situational
  • Occurs with micturition, defecation, swallowing, or coughing

Carotid hypersensitivity
  • Tactile stimulation of carotid sinus while standing
  • Advanced age, carotid atherosclerosis

Orthostatic syncope

Medications
  • Vasodilators (eg, alpha-1 blockers, antihypertensives)
  • Inotropic/chronotropic blockade (eg, beta blockers)

Hypovolemia
  • History consistent with volume loss

Autonomic dysfunction
  • Advanced age
  • Predisposing disease (eg, DM, Parkinson)

Cardiac syncope

LV outflow obstruction
  • Syncope with exertion
  • Systolic ejection murmur

Ventricular tachycardia
  • No warning symptoms
  • Cardiomyopathy or ischemic HD (monomorphic)
  • QT-interval prolongation (polymorphic)

Conduction impairment*
  • Preceding fatigue or light-headedness
  • ECG abnormalities (eg, sinus pauses, dropped QRS complexes)

*Sick sinus syndrome or advanced atrioventricular block.

DM = diabetes mellitus; HD = heart disease; LV = left ventricular.

Cardiac syncope

Etiology

Clues to diagnosis

Aortic stenosis or HCM
  • Exertional syncope
  • Systolic murmur on examination

Ventricular tachycardia
  • No preceding symptoms
  • Cardiomyopathy or previous MI

Sick sinus syndrome
  • Preceding fatigue or dizziness
  • Sinus pauses on ECG

Advanced AV block
  • Bifascicular block or â PR interval on ECG
  • Dropped QRS complexes on ECG

Torsades de pointes
  • No preceding symptoms
  • Medications that prolong QT interval
  • Hypokalemia or hypomagnesemia

AV = atrioventricular; HCM = hypertrophic cardiomyopathy; MI = myocardial infarction.

NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug.

title: Informed consent
noteText:
Elements of informed consent

Preconditions
  • Competency
  • Voluntariness

Disclosure of key facts
  • Diagnosis
  • Proposed treatment or procedure
  • Alternate treatment options (medical, surgical)
  • Risks/benefits of proposed treatment & alternatives
    • Common complications
    • Rare but major complications
  • Risks of refusing treatment

Other disclosures if applicable
  • Role of residents & medical students
  • Anticipated additional procedures
  • Financial conflicts

title: Acute limb ischemia
noteText:
Clinical features of acute limb ischemia
 

Viable limb

(no tissue loss)

Threatened limb

(risk for tissue loss)

Nonviable limb

(permanent tissue damage)

Pain

Mild

Severe

Variable

Sensory/motor deficit

None

Mild/partial

Severe/complete

Capillary refill

Intact

Delayed

Absent

Arterial Doppler

Audible

Inaudible

Inaudible

Venous Doppler

Audible

Audible

Inaudible

Management

Urgent revascularization

Emergency revascularization

Amputation

Patients with ALI should immediately receive anticoagulation (ie, heparin infusion).  Further management is then determined by the severity of ischemia:

  • Patients such as this one with signs and symptoms of ALI (eg, pain, pallor) but pulses detectable by arterial Doppler and no motor or sensory deficit have a viable limb with no active tissue loss.  These patients should undergo imaging with CT angiography to characterize the location and extent of arterial obstruction, followed by urgent catheter-based or surgical revascularization.

  • Patients with pulses that cannot be detected by arterial Doppler and partial motor and sensory loss have an immediately threatened limb and should undergo emergency surgical revascularization to save it (Choice B).  CT angiography is helpful in such cases but may not always be temporally feasible.

  • Patients with undetectable Doppler pulses and profound motor and sensory loss have an irreversibly ischemic limb (nonviable limb) that requires surgical amputation.  Nonurgent revascularization is sometimes required to aid in the healing of the amputation site

Ankylosing spondylitis

  • MRI of sacroiliac joints

CRP = C-reactive protein; ESR = erythrocyte sedimentation rate.

AF = atrial fibrillation; IE = infective endocarditis; LV = left ventricular; PAD = peripheral artery disease.

title: Turners syndrome
noteText:
Comorbidity screening in Turner syndrome

Cardiovascular
  • Congenital heart defects*: 4-extremity BP, ECG, echocardiogram
  • Aortic dilatation/dissection**: TTE or cardiac MRI
  • Metabolic syndrome: BP, HbA1c, lipid panel, LFT

Renal
  • Horseshoe kidney: renal ultrasound

Musculoskeletal
  • Osteoporosis: 25-hydroxyvitamin D level, DXA scan

Vision & hearing
  • Strabismus, myopia: ophthalmology evaluation
  • Recurrent otitis media, hearing loss: audiology testing

Autoimmune
  • Celiac disease: tissue transglutaminase antibodies
  • Hypothyroidism: TSH, free T4

*Aortic coarctation, bicuspid aortic valve.

**High risk in pregnancy.

BP = blood pressure; HbA1c = glycosylated hemoglobin; LFT = liver function test;
TTE = transthoracic echocardiogram.

title: Medical Mx following MI
noteText:
Medical management following myocardial infarction

Medication

Indication

Dual antiplatelet therapy
(low-dose aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor)
  • All patients (regardless of stent placement)
  • Low-dose aspirin continued indefinitely
  • P2Y12 inhibitor continued for 12 months

Beta blocker
(eg, metoprolol, carvedilol)
  • All patients, continued indefinitely
  • Reduces myocardial oxygen demand, decreases arrhythmia risk & inhibits remodeling

ACE inhibitor or angiotensin II receptor blocker
  • All patients, continued indefinitely for reduced LVEF
  • Inhibits post-MI remodeling

High-intensity statin
(eg, atorvastatin, rosuvastatin)
  • All patients, continued indefinitely
  • Stabilizes atherosclerotic plaque & reduces recurrent MI

Mineralocorticoid antagonist
(eg, spironolactone)
  • Reduced LVEF with symptoms or comorbid DM
  • Inhibits post-MI remodeling

DM = diabetes mellitus; LVEF = left ventricular ejection fraction; MI = myocardial infarction.

ABI = SBP of dorsalis pedis or posterior tibial artery / SBP of brachial artery

â¤0.9

Diagnostic of peripheral artery disease

0.91-1.3

Normal

>1.3

Treatment of symptomatic peripheral artery disease

Step 1A

Risk factor management

Step 1B

Step 2

Revascularization for persistent symptoms

  • â Pressure within enclosed fascial space

Common causes

    • Progressive, severe pain

title: Screening for AAA
noteText:
Abdominal aortic aneurysm

Risk factors
  • Advanced age (eg, >60)
  • Smoking, male sex, hypertension
  • History of atherosclerosis or CTD

Clinical presentation
  • Mostly asymptomatic
  • Rapid expansion
    • Dull abdominal/back pain
    • Distal embolization
  • Rupture
    • Sudden, severe abdominal/back pain Â± shock
    • Umbilical/flank hematoma

Management
  • Smoking cessation
  • Asymptomatic:
    • Serial imaging: size <5.5 cm*
    • Elective repair: size â¥5.5 cm or rapid expansion
  • Symptomatic:
    • Urgent repair: HD stable patients
    • Emergency repair: HD unstable patients

*A smaller repair cutoff of 5 cm is used for women.  Serial imaging frequency depends on aneurysm size & expansion rate.

CTD = connective tissue disease; HD = hemodynamically.

Screening: abdominal aortic aneurysm

Patient population
  • Men
  • Age 65-75

Risk factor indication
  • Any smoking history

Test
  • 1-time abdominal duplex ultrasonography

title: Complication of aortic dissection
noteText:
Acute aortic dissection

Risk factors
  • Chronic hypertension (strongest overall risk factor)
  • Underlying aortopathy (eg, Marfan syndrome)
  • Cocaine use

Clinical presentation
  • Severe, tearing chest or back pain, maximal at onset
  • Â± Variation in SBP between arms >20 mm Hg
  • Hypertension usually present*

Diagnosis
  • ECG: normal or nonspecific ST-segment & T-wave changes
  • Chest x-ray: mediastinal widening
  • CT angiography or TEE for definitive diagnosis

Treatment
  • Pain control (eg, morphine)
  • Intravenous beta blockers (eg, esmolol)
  • Â± Sodium nitroprusside (if SBP >120 mm Hg despite beta blockers)
  • Emergency surgical repair for ascending dissection

*Hypotension on presentation suggests aortic rupture or other complication (eg, cardiac tamponade, acute aortic regurgitation).

SBP = systolic blood pressure; TEE = transesophageal echocardiography.

Complications due to extension of acute aortic dissection

Complication

(involved structure)
  • Stroke (carotid artery)
  • Horner syndrome (carotid sympathetic plexus)
  • Acute aortic regurgitation (aortic root/valve)
  • Myocardial ischemia/infarction (coronary artery ostia)
  • Pericardial effusion/tamponade (pericardium)
  • Hemothorax (pleural cavity)
  • Renal infarction (renal arteries)
  • Intestinal ischemia (mesenteric arteries)
  • Lower extremity paralysis (spinal arteries)

  • Aspirin for inhibition of cocaine-induced platelet aggregation
  • Nitroglycerin & calcium channel blockers for vasoconstrictive pain
  • Immediate cardiac catheterization if indicated (eg, STEMI)
  • Caution with: fibrinolysis (â risk of ICH), beta blockers (â risk of coronary vasoconstriction*)

*Theoretical risk due to unopposed alpha stimulation.  Mixed alpha/beta blockers are sometimes considered.

ICH = intracranial hemorrhage; STEMI = ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction.

title: Localization of STEMI
noteText:

Involved myocardium

title: Acute Mx of ACS
noteText:
Acute coronary syndromes
 

Primary diagnostic finding

Management

STEMI

ST-segment elevation in â¥2 contiguous ECG leads

Emergency reperfusion (eg, PCI)

Non-STEMI

Troponin elevation*

Medical management initially, reperfusion within 24 hr

Unstable angina

Consistent history (eg, rest angina)**

*ECG shows nonspecific ischemic changes but no ST-segment elevation.

**ECG shows nonspecific changes & troponin is not elevated.

PCI = percutaneous coronary intervention; STEMI = ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction.

Acute management of acute coronary syndrome

(STEMI, NSTEMI, or unstable angina)

Nitrates
  • Rapid chest pain relief
  • Caution with hypotension (eg, RV infarction)

Beta blocker
  • Cardioselective (eg, metoprolol, atenolol)
  • Decreases myocardial O2 demand to limit infarct size
  • Contraindicated in cardiogenic shock & bradycardia

Antiplatelet therapy
  • Aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor (eg, prasugrel, clopidogrel)*
  • Reduces platelet activity

Anticoagulation
  • Unfractionated heparin, bivalirudin, or enoxaparin
  • Limits thrombus expansion

Statin therapy
  • High potency (eg, atorvastatin, rosuvastatin)
  • Stabilizes atherosclerotic plaque

Coronary reperfusion

STEMI

  • PCI <90 min from first medical contact
  • Fibrinolytics (eg, alteplase) if PCI is unavailable

NSTEMI or unstable angina

  • Coronary angiography often within 24 hr

*In patients with NSTEMI or unstable angina, P2Y12 inhibitor therapy is often held until after coronary angiography in case the atherosclerotic coronary anatomy indicates the need for coronary artery bypass grafting.

NSTEMI = nonâST-segment elevation myocardial infarction; PCI = percutaneous coronary intervention; RV = right ventricular; STEMI = ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction.

ASCVD = atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease; CABG = coronary artery bypass grafting; PAD = peripheral artery disease; TIA = transient ischemic attack.

title: Anaphylaxis
noteText:
Anaphylaxis

Triggers
  • Food (eg, nuts, shellfish)
  • Medications (eg, Î²-lactam antibiotics)
  • Insect stings

Clinical
manifestations
  • Cardiovascular
    • Vasodilation â hypotension & tissue edema
    • Tachycardia
  • Respiratory
    • Upper airway edema â stridor & hoarseness
    • Bronchospasm â wheezing
  • Cutaneous
    • Urticarial rash, pruritus, flushing
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain

Treatment
  • Intramuscular epinephrine
  • Airway management & volume resuscitation
  • Adjunct therapy (eg, antihistamines, glucocorticoids)

Diagnostic challenges in anaphylaxis

Nonclassic
presentation
  • No prior allergic reactions (ie, first episode)
  • Absence of hypotension, respiratory symptoms, or cutaneous signs
  • Protracted or biphasic presentation

Challenging
clinical situations
  • Preexisting conditions with similar symptoms (eg, asthma, COPD)
  • Ongoing physiologic shifts (eg, childbirth, hemodialysis)
  • Impaired communication (eg, sedation, severe psychiatric illness)

Medication
effects
  • Directly activate mast cells (eg, opiates, NSAIDs)
  • Interfere with epinephrine effect (eg, Î²-blockers,
    Î±-adrenergic blockers)

COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs.

Diagnostic criteria for anaphylaxis

Anaphylaxis is likely if there is rapid symptom onset & any 1 of the following criteria:

1

Skin/mucosa involvement (eg, hives, lip/tongue swelling) & either hypotension or respiratory distress

2

Involvement of â¥2 organ systems after exposure to a likely allergen

  • Skin/mucosa (eg, hives, lip/tongue swelling)
  • Respiratory (eg, wheezing, stridor, dyspnea)
  • Cardiovascular (eg, hypotension, tachycardia, syncope)
  • Gastrointestinal (eg, abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea)

3

Hypotension after exposure to a known allergen

Management of anaphylaxis

Immediate
management
  • Epinephrine (most important):
    • IM preferred, may be repeated (eg, 3 doses)
    • IV in severe/refractory cases
  • IV crystalloid & Trendelenburg positioning for hypotension
  • Albuterol for bronchospasm
  • Early intubation for upper airway obstruction

Adjunct
management
  • H1/H2 antihistamines
  • Glucocorticoids
  • Glucagon for patients on beta blockers (reversal)
  • Hospital admission for severe initial presentation (eg, shock) or ongoing symptoms despite treatment

IM = intramuscular; IV = intravenous.

title: Flial chest
ARDS
noteText:
Acute respiratory distress syndrome: pathogenesis & diagnosis

Risk factors &
pathogenesis
  • Direct (eg, pneumonia, inhalation) or indirect (eg, sepsis, pancreatitis, trauma) lung injury
  • Inflammatory cell activation & â permeability â fluid & cytokine leakage into alveoli

Pathophysiology
  • â Lung compliance (alveolar flooding) â â work of breathing
  • Severe V/Q mismatch (intrapulmonary shunt) â severe hypoxemia
  • â Hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction â â RV afterload & acute PHTN

Diagnosis
  • New bilateral alveolar opacities within 1 week of inciting insult
  • Edema not explained by cardiac failure or volume overload
  • Hypoxemia with PaO2/FiO2 â¤300
PHTN = pulmonary hypertension; RV = right ventricular; V/Q = ventilation/perfusion.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome: management & prognosis

Mechanical ventilation
  • Lung protection: limit alveolar distending volume (VT 6 mL/kg) & pressure (Pplat â¤30 cm H2O)
  • Ventilation: tolerate permissive hypercapnia (ie, â PaCO2 & â pH acceptable) to avoid excessive VT
  • Oxygenation: set lowest feasible FiO2 (goal SpO2 92%-96%) to avoid O2 toxicity

Supportive care
  • Treat underlying etiology: source control (eg, sepsis)
  • Prevent iatrogenic harm: negative fluid balance, timely extubation (eg, minimize sedation)
  • Â± Corticosteroids: select patients with moderate-to-severe early ARDS

Prognosis
  • Mortality rate: 40% in hospital, death mostly due to multiorgan failure
  • Morbidity rate: 50% with chronic cognitive impairment & physical debility, 25% with chronic pulmonary dysfunction (restriction & â DLCO)

ARDS = acute respiratory distress syndrome; DLCO = diffusion capacity of lung for carbon monoxide; Pplat = plateau pressure; SpO2 = oxygen saturation as measured by pulse oximetry; VT = tidal volume.

nonfatal cardiac arrest,
or nonfatal MI

event rates of later studies probably due to using troponins (â sensitivity) and including

noteText:
Common causes of primary acid-base disturbance

Metabolic acidosis

Elevated anion gap

(hypoventilation)

  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease

(hyperventilation)
  • Acute V/Q mismatch (eg, PE, pneumonia)
  • Anxiety, inadequate pain control
  • High altitude, pregnancy

OHS = obesity hypoventilation syndrome; PE = pulmonary embolism; V/Q = ventilation/perfusion.

Appropriate compensatory PaCO2 or HCO3â changes in acid-base disorders

Metabolic acidosis
(acute or chronic)

Expected PaCO2 = (1.5 Ã HCO3â) + 8 Â± 2 (Winters formula)

Metabolic alkalosis
(acute or chronic)

~7 mm Hg â in PaCO2 per 10 mEq/L â in HCO3â

Respiratory acidosis
(chronic only*)

~4 mEq/L â in HCO3â per 10 mm Hg â in PaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis
(chronic only*)

~4 mEq/L â in HCO3â per 10 mm Hg â in PaCO2

*Compensation for respiratory disturbances is minimal in the acute setting.  The full level of chronic compensation is achieved after ~72 hr.  For simplicity, normal baseline PaCO2 & HCO3â should be considered 40 mm Hg & 24 mEq/L, respectively.

title: ACS Mx
noteText:
Acute management of acute coronary syndrome

(STEMI, NSTEMI, or unstable angina)

Nitrates
  • Rapid chest pain relief
  • Caution with hypotension (eg, RV infarction)

Beta blocker
  • Cardioselective (eg, metoprolol, atenolol)
  • Decreases myocardial O2 demand to limit infarct size
  • Contraindicated in cardiogenic shock & bradycardia

Antiplatelet therapy
  • Aspirin + P2Y12 inhibitor (eg, prasugrel, clopidogrel)*
  • Reduces platelet activity

Anticoagulation
  • Unfractionated heparin, bivalirudin, or enoxaparin
  • Limits thrombus expansion

Statin therapy
  • High potency (eg, atorvastatin, rosuvastatin)
  • Stabilizes atherosclerotic plaque

Coronary reperfusion

STEMI

  • PCI <90 min from first medical contact
  • Fibrinolytics (eg, alteplase) if PCI is unavailable

NSTEMI or unstable angina

  • Coronary angiography often within 24 hr

*In patients with NSTEMI or unstable angina, P2Y12 inhibitor therapy is often held until after coronary angiography in case the atherosclerotic coronary anatomy indicates the need for coronary artery bypass grafting.

NSTEMI = nonâST-segment elevation myocardial infarction; PCI = percutaneous coronary intervention; RV = right ventricular; STEMI = ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction.

Acute coronary syndromes
 

Primary diagnostic finding

Management

STEMI

ST-segment elevation in â¥2 contiguous ECG leads

Emergency reperfusion (eg, PCI)

Non-STEMI

Troponin elevation*

Medical management initially, reperfusion within 24 hr

Unstable angina

Consistent history (eg, rest angina)**

*ECG shows nonspecific ischemic changes but no ST-segment elevation.

**ECG shows nonspecific changes & troponin is not elevated.

PCI = percutaneous coronary intervention; STEMI = ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction.

Preferred approach for nonemergency coronary revascularization

Stent placement
  • Single-vessel disease
  • Most 2-vessel disease (eg, RCA & LCx)

Coronary artery bypass grafting
  • 2-vessel disease involving LAD in patients with diabetes mellitus
  • 3-vessel disease (ie, LAD, RCA & LCx)
  • Most left main artery disease

LAD = left anterior descending artery; LCx = left circumflex artery; RCA = right coronary artery.

title: Cocaine intoxication
noteText:
Clinical features of cocaine use

Clinical presentation
  • Sympathetic hyperactivity: tachycardia, hypertension, dilated pupils
  • Chest pain due to coronary vasoconstriction
  • Psychomotor agitation, seizures

Complications
  • Acute myocardial ischemia
  • Aortic dissection
  • ICH

Management of chest pain

  • Aspirin for inhibition of cocaine-induced platelet aggregation
  • Nitroglycerin & calcium channel blockers for vasoconstrictive pain
  • Immediate cardiac catheterization if indicated (eg, STEMI)
  • Caution with: fibrinolysis (â risk of ICH), beta blockers (â risk of coronary vasoconstriction*)

title: Inhalation injury
noteText:
Inhalation injury

Pathophysiology
  • Upper airway thermal injury Â± lower airway chemical injury
  • Concomitant CO & cyanide poisoning common

Concerning
features

  • Physical: singed hair, facial burns, carbonaceous sputum, wheezing

Strong indicators
of airway injury

Management
  • 100% oxygen to displace CO
  • Stable patients with concerning features but no strong indicators: bedside fiberoptic laryngoscopy
  • Unstable patients or patients with strong indicators: endotracheal intubation

Epidemiology

Mild-moderate

Severe

  • Myocardial ischemia, arrhythmias

Diagnosis

  • Intubation/hyperbaric oxygen (severe)

ABG = arterial blood gas.

title: Mechanical ventilation settings
noteText:
Acute respiratory distress syndrome: management & prognosis

Mechanical ventilation
  • Lung protection: limit alveolar distending volume (VT 6 mL/kg) & pressure (Pplat â¤30 cm H2O)
  • Ventilation: tolerate permissive hypercapnia (ie, â PaCO2 & â pH acceptable) to avoid excessive VT
  • Oxygenation: set lowest feasible FiO2 (goal SpO2 92%-96%) to avoid O2 toxicity

Supportive care
  • Treat underlying etiology: source control (eg, sepsis)
  • Prevent iatrogenic harm: negative fluid balance, timely extubation (eg, minimize sedation)
  • Â± Corticosteroids: select patients with moderate-to-severe early ARDS

Prognosis
  • Mortality rate: 40% in hospital, death mostly due to multiorgan failure
  • Morbidity rate: 50% with chronic cognitive impairment & physical debility, 25% with chronic pulmonary dysfunction (restriction & â DLCO)

ARDS = acute respiratory distress syndrome; DLCO = diffusion capacity of lung for carbon monoxide; Pplat = plateau pressure; SpO2 = oxygen saturation as measured by pulse oximetry; VT = tidal volume.

title: Drowning injuries
noteText:
Drowning injuries

Risk factors
  • Children age <5 & males age 15-25
  • Inability to swim &/or inadequate supervision
  • Concomitant drug/alcohol use

  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • Cerebral edema

title: ARDS
noteText:
Acute respiratory distress syndrome: pathogenesis & diagnosis

Risk factors &
pathogenesis
  • Direct (eg, pneumonia, inhalation) or indirect (eg, sepsis, pancreatitis, trauma) lung injury
  • Inflammatory cell activation & â permeability â fluid & cytokine leakage into alveoli

Pathophysiology
  • â Lung compliance (alveolar flooding) â â work of breathing
  • Severe V/Q mismatch (intrapulmonary shunt) â severe hypoxemia
  • â Hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction â â RV afterload & acute PHTN

Diagnosis
  • New bilateral alveolar opacities within 1 week of inciting insult
  • Edema not explained by cardiac failure or volume overload
  • Hypoxemia with PaO2/FiO2 â¤300
PHTN = pulmonary hypertension; RV = right ventricular; V/Q = ventilation/perfusion.

title: Myasthenic crisis
noteText:
Myasthenic crisis

Precipitating
factors
  • Infection or surgery
  • Pregnancy or childbirth
  • Tapering of immunosuppressive drugs
  • Medications (eg, aminoglycosides, beta blockers)

Signs/symptoms
  • â Generalized & oropharyngeal weakness
  • Respiratory insufficiency/dyspnea

Treatment
  • Intubation for deteriorating respiratory status
  • Plasmapheresis or IVIG as well as corticosteroids

IVIG = intravenous immunoglobulin.

Noninvasive positive pressure ventilation

Indications
(strongest evidence)
  • COPD (severe exacerbation, prevent extubation failure)
  • Cardiogenic pulmonary edema
  • Acute respiratory failure
    • Postoperative hypoxemic respiratory failure
    • Immunosuppressed patients
  • Facilitate early extubation

Contraindications

Medical instability

  • Cardiac or respiratory arrest (or impending arrest)
  • Severe acidosis (pH <7.1)
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • Nonrespiratory organ failure
    • Unstable cardiac arrhythmia/hemodynamic instability
    • Encephalopathy (Glasgow Coma Score <10)
    • Gastrointestinal bleed

Inability to protect airway

  • Uncooperative or agitated
  • Inability to clear secretions/high aspiration risk

Mechanical issues

  • Recent esophageal anastomosis
  • Facial or neurologic surgery, deformity, or trauma
  • Upper airway obstruction

COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

title: HCM
noteText:
Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

Pathophysiology
  • Genetic mutations affecting cardiac sarcomere proteins
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance
  • Variable phenotypic penetrance

Clinical features
  • Many patients are asymptomatic
  • Exertional dyspnea, fatigue, angina, light-headedness, syncope
  • Systolic ejection murmur accentuated by â LV blood volume
  • Diastolic dysfunction with audible S4
  • â Risk for atrial fibrillation & ventricular tachycardia

Diagnosis
  • ECG: left axis deviation, abnormalities of depolarization (eg, Q waves) or repolarization (eg, inverted T waves)
  • Echocardiography: septal LV hypertrophy, dynamic LVOT obstruction, LA dilation

Management
  • Beta blocker or nondihydropyridine CCB (facilitate â LV blood volume)
  • Avoidance of dehydration & vasodilators (avoid â LV blood volume)
  • ICD placement for increased risk for SCD
  • Septal ablation, cardiac transplantation
CCB = calcium channel blocker; ICD = implantable cardiac defibrillator; LA = left atrial; LV = left ventricular; LVOT = left ventricular outflow tract; SCD = sudden cardiac death.

title: Monomorphic VT
SVT
Anticoagulant
Origin of common SVT
Vasovagal syncope
noteText:
Vasovagal & situational syncope

Triggers
  • Pain,* anxiety,* emotional stress, heat, prolonged standing
  • Situational: cough,* micturition,* defecation, eating, hair-combing*

Clinical
presentation
  • Prodrome (eg, warmth, pallor, nausea, diaphoresis)
  • Rapid recovery of consciousness (eg, <1-2 min)

Diagnosis
  • Mainly based on clinical history of event
  • Upright tilt table testing sometimes indicated in uncertain cases

Treatment
  • Reassurance & avoidance of triggers
  • Counterpressure techniques for recurrent episodes

*Particularly common triggers in the pediatric population.

Clues to etiology of syncope

Reflex syncope

Vasovagal
  • Trigger (eg, emotional stress, prolonged standing)
  • Prodrome (eg, nausea, sweating, warmth)

Situational
  • Occurs with micturition, defecation, swallowing, or coughing

Carotid hypersensitivity
  • Tactile stimulation of carotid sinus while standing
  • Advanced age, carotid atherosclerosis

Orthostatic syncope

Medications
  • Vasodilators (eg, alpha-1 blockers, antihypertensives)
  • Inotropic/chronotropic blockade (eg, beta blockers)

Hypovolemia
  • History consistent with volume loss

Autonomic dysfunction
  • Advanced age
  • Predisposing disease (eg, DM, Parkinson)

Cardiac syncope

LV outflow obstruction
  • Syncope with exertion
  • Systolic ejection murmur

Ventricular tachycardia
  • No warning symptoms
  • Cardiomyopathy or ischemic HD (monomorphic)
  • QT-interval prolongation (polymorphic)

Conduction impairment*
  • Preceding fatigue or light-headedness
  • ECG abnormalities (eg, sinus pauses, dropped QRS complexes)

*Sick sinus syndrome or advanced atrioventricular block.

DM = diabetes mellitus; HD = heart disease; LV = left ventricular.

title: Common cause of neonatal respiratory distress
noteText:
Common causes of neonatal respiratory distress

Diagnosis

Transient tachypnea
of the newborn

Respiratory distress

syndrome

Persistent pulmonary
hypertension

Pathophysiology
  • Inadequate alveolar fluid clearance at birth
  • Surfactant deficiency
  • Alveolar collapse & diffuse atelectasis
  • High pulmonary vascular resistance
  • Right-to-left shunt

  • Tachypnea shortly after birth
  • Resolves by day 2 of life

title: Vascular ring
noteText:
Vascular ring

Pathophysiology
  • Congenital aortic arch malformation (eg, double aortic arch)
  • Great vessels encircle & compress trachea &/or esophagus (level of T3 -T4)
  • Associated cardiac defects (eg, VSD) in 50% of patients

Clinical features
  • Respiratory symptoms:
    • Biphasic stridor (improves with neck extension)
    • Recurrent respiratory tract infections
  • Esophageal symptoms:
    • Feeding difficulties, vomiting
    • Solid-food dysphagia

Imaging*
  • Chest x-ray: right aortic arch, tracheal narrowing
  • Esophagram: posterior esophageal indentation
  • CT/MR angiography of the chest (diagnostic)

Treatment
  • Surgical correction

*Choice of prediagnostic imaging studies varies depending on presenting symptoms (ie, respiratory vs esophageal).

VSD = ventricular septal defect.

Transient tachypnea of the newborn

Pathophysiology

  • Retained fetal lung fluid

Risk factors

  • Cesarean birth
  • Prematurity
  • Maternal diabetes mellitus

Clinical findings

  • Tachypnea, increased work of breathing
  • Clear breath sounds

title: Neonatal RDS
noteText:
Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome

Pathophysiology
  • Surfactant deficiency in premature infants
  • â Alveolar surface tension â diffuse atelectasis
  • Ventilation/perfusion mismatch causes right-to-left intrapulmonary shunting

Clinical features
  • Tachypnea, retractions, grunting immediately after birth
  • Cyanosis & hypoxia
  • Decreased breath sounds

Chest x-ray
  • Diffuse, ground-glass appearance
  • Air bronchograms
  • â Lung volumes

Management
  • Surfactant administration
  • Respiratory support (eg, continuous positive airway pressure)

Prevention
  • Antenatal corticosteroids (stimulate fetal surfactant production)

Complications
  • Bronchopulmonary dysplasia (chronic lung disease)

title: Cystic fibrosis
Necrotizing enterocolitis
noteText:
Necrotizing enterocolitis

Pathogenesis
  • Gut mucosal wall invasion by gas-producing bacteria
  • Intestinal inflammation, necrosis

Risk
factors
  • Prematurity
  • Very low birth weight (<1.5 kg [3 lb 4 oz])
  • Enteral feeding

Clinical
findings
  • Nonspecific: apnea, lethargy, vital sign instability
  • Gastrointestinal
    • Abdominal distension
    • Feeding intolerance, bilious emesis
    • Bloody stools

X-ray
findings
  • Pneumatosis intestinalis (air in bowel wall)
  • Pneumoperitoneum (free air under diaphragm)

Complications
  • Sepsis, disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Late: strictures, short-bowel syndrome

title: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia
noteText:
Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

Pathogenesis
  • Incomplete fusion of pleuroperitoneal folds
  • Herniation of bowel into chest â pulmonary hypoplasia & hypertension

Clinical
features
  • Respiratory distress (within hours of birth)
  • Absent breath sounds ipsilateral to defect
  • Concave abdomen; barrel-shaped chest

Diagnosis
  • Chest x-ray: intrathoracic bowel loops, displaced cardiac silhouette

Management
  • Endotracheal intubation
  • Gastric decompression (eg, nasogastric tube)
  • Surgical correction

title: Pulmonary changes in pregnancy
noteText:
Pulmonary changes in pregnancy

Pathophysiology
  • Progesterone-induced hyperventilation

Clinical features
  • Dyspnea of pregnancy
  • â PaO2, â PaCO2 (respiratory alkalosis)

Lung volumes
  • â Minute ventilation (mostly via â tidal volume)
  • â Residual volume & functional residual capacity
  • Normal vital capacity & FEV1

title: Sick sinus syndrome
noteText:
Sick sinus syndrome

Clinical features
  • Elderly patients
  • Bradycardia
    • Fatigue, dyspnea, dizziness, syncope
  • Bradycardia-tachycardia syndrome
    • Atrial arrhythmias (eg, atrial fibrillation)
    • Palpitations

ECG findings
  • Sinus bradycardia
  • Sinus pauses (delayed P waves)
  • Sinoatrial nodal exit block (dropped P waves)

Treatment
  • Pacemaker
  • +/- Rate-control medication (if tachyarrhythmias)

title: Primary ciliary dyskinesia
noteText:
Features of primary ciliary dyskinesia

Pathophysiology
  • Mutations in ciliary dynein arms lead to absent or dysmotile cilia & poor mucociliary clearance

Clinical manifestations
  • Recurrent sinopulmonary infections
  • Bronchiectasis
  • Â± Situs inversus (Kartagener syndrome)

Diagnosis
  • Low nasal nitric oxide levels
  • Bronchoscopy & electron microscopic visualization of ciliary abnormalities
  • Genetic testing

title: AF
noteText:
Long-term management of atrial fibrillation

Rate-control strategy*

Rhythm-control strategy*
  • Atrioventricular node blockade
    • Beta blockers
    • Nondihydropyridine CCBs
    • Digoxin
  • Anticoagulation usually indicated
  • Electrical cardioversion
  • Pharmacologic antiarrhythmics
    • Flecainide, amiodarone
  • Radiofrequency ablation
  • Anticoagulation often indicated

*Clinical outcomes for each strategy are roughly equivalent.  Choice of strategy is typically based on case particulars (eg, duration of atrial fibrillation) & patient preference.

CCBs = calcium channel blockers.

title: Acute limb ischemia
noteText:
Acute limb ischemia

Etiology
  • Cardiac/arterial embolus (eg, AF, LV thrombus, IE)
  • Arterial thrombosis (eg, PAD)
  • Iatrogenic/blunt trauma

Clinical
features

6 Ps of acute limb ischemia

  • Pain
  • Pallor
  • Paresthesia
  • Pulselessness
  • Poikilothermia (cool extremity)
  • Paralysis (late)

Management
  • Anticoagulation (eg, heparin)
  • Thrombolysis vs surgery

AF = atrial fibrillation; IE = infective endocarditis; LV = left ventricular; PAD = peripheral artery disease.

title: Monomorphic VT
noteText:
Monomorphic nonsustained ventricular tachycardia

Identification
  • â¥3 consecutive ventricular beats (wide QRS complex)
  • Rate >100/min & duration <30 sec

Predisposing conditions
  • Heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
  • Ischemic heart disease
  • Other cardiomyopathy (eg, HCM)

Precipitating factors
  • Serum electrolyte abnormalities (eg, â K, â Mg)
  • Hypoxemia or acute myocardial ischemia
  • Elevated sympathetic tone (eg, sepsis)

Management
  • Address precipitating factors (eg, replace electrolytes)
  • Consider adding (or increasing dose of) beta blockade

HCM = hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

title: Atrial fibrillation
noteText:
Conditions that increase the risk of atrial fibrillation

Precipitants of atrial dilation &/or
conduction remodeling
  • Advanced age
  • Systemic hypertension
  • Mitral valve dysfunction
  • Left ventricular failure
  • Coronary artery disease & related factors (eg, DM, smoking)
  • Obesity & obstructive sleep apnea
  • Chronic hypoxic lung disease (eg, COPD)

Triggers of increased automaticity
  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Excessive alcohol use
  • Increased sympathetic tone
    • Acute illness (eg, sepsis, PE, MI)
    • Cardiac surgery
  • Sympathomimetic drugs (eg, cocaine)

COPD = chronic obstructive pulmonary disease; DM = diabetes mellitus; MI = myocardial infarction; PE = pulmonary embolism.

title: Long QT syndrome
noteText:
Causes of QT-interval prolongation

Acquired
  • Medications
    • Macrolides & fluoroquinolones
    • Antiemetics (eg, ondansetron)
    • Azoles (eg, fluconazole)
    • Antipsychotics, TCAs & SSRIs
    • Some opioids (eg, methadone, oxycodone)
    • Class Ia antiarrhythmics (eg, quinidine)
    • Class III antiarrhythmics (eg, dofetilide, sotalol)
  • Electrolyte abnormalities
    • â Magnesium, â potassium, â calcium

Congenital
  • Romano-Ward syndrome (autosomal dominant)
  • Jervell & Lange-Nielsen syndrome (autosomal recessive)*

*Associated with sensorineural hearing loss.

SSRIs = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors; TCAs = tricyclic antidepressants.

title: Bronchopulmonary dysplasia
noteText:
Bronchopulmonary dysplasia

Pathogenesis
  • Premature arrest of pulmonary development
  • Alveolar hypoplasia with â septation
  • Impaired vasculogenesis

Clinical diagnosis
  • Premature infant with continued supplemental oxygen requirement â¥28 days from birth*

Chest x-ray
  • Mild: diffuse hazy infiltrates, low/normal lung volumes
  • Severe: fibrocystic changes, hyperinflation

Treatment
  • Supportive (eg, oxygen, nutrition, fluid restriction/diuretics)

Complications
  • Pulmonary artery hypertension
  • Cardiovascular disease (eg, hypertension)
  • Recurrent respiratory infections

*Some definitions include an oxygen requirement at 36 weeks postmenstrual age (ie, gestational + chronologic age).

title: RDS
Diaphragmatic rupture
psoas abscess
noteText:
Psoas abscess

Clinical
presentation
  • Subacute fever & abdominal/flank pain that may radiate to the groin or hip
  • Anorexia, weight loss
  • Abdominal pain with hip extension (psoas sign)

Diagnosis
  • CT scan of the abdomen & pelvis
  • Leukocytosis, elevated inflammatory markers
  • Blood & abscess cultures

Treatment
  • Drainage
  • Broad-spectrum antibiotics

title: Ovarian adenocarcinoma
noteText:
Epithelial ovarian carcinoma

Clinical
presentation
  • Acute: shortness of breath, obstipation/constipation with vomiting, abdominal distension
  • Subacute: pelvic/abdominal pain, bloating, early satiety
  • Asymptomatic adnexal mass

Laboratory
findings
  • â CA-125

Ultrasound
findings
  • Solid mass
  • Thick septations
  • Ascites

Management
  • Exploratory laparotomy

title: Herpes zoster
FAST assessment
Cardiac murmurs
Rotavirus vaccine
noteText:
Rotavirus vaccine

Indications
  • Prevent most common cause of viral gastroenteritis
    worldwide

Specifications

  • Live attenuated oral vaccine
  • Series administration at age 2-6 months

Contraindications
  • Allergy to vaccine ingredients
  • Severe combined immunodeficiency
  • History of intussusception

title: Pumonary stenosis
noteText:
Pulmonic valve stenosis

Etiology
  • Congenital (usually isolated defect)
  • Rarely acquired (eg, carcinoid) 

Clinical presentation
  • Severe: Right-sided heart failure in childhood
  • Mild: Symptoms (eg, dyspnea) in early adulthood
  • Crescendo-decrescendo murmur (â on inspiration)
  • Systolic ejection click & widened split of S2

Diagnosis
  • Echocardiography

Treatment
  • Percutaneous balloon valvulotomy (preferred)
  • Surgical repair in some cases

title: Prosthetic valve dysfunction
noteText:
Prosthetic valve dysfunction

Types & causes
  • Transvalvular regurgitation (cusp degeneration)
  • Paravalvular leak (annular degeneration, IE)
  • Valvular obstruction/stenosis (valve thrombus)

Clinical manifestations
  • New murmur (regurgitant or stenotic)
  • Macroangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  • Heart failure symptoms, thromboembolism

Diagnosis
  • Echocardiography

IE = infective endocarditis.

title: Pulmonary HTN
noteText:
Classification of pulmonary hypertension

Pulmonary arterial
hypertension
(group 1)
  • Primary change in pulmonary arteries
    • Hereditary (eg, BMPR2 mutation)
    • Connective tissue disease (eg, RA, SS)
    • HIV infection
  • Treatment targeted at endothelial dysfunction

Pulmonary
hypertension
(groups 2-5)
  • Secondary to another disease process
    • Left-sided heart failure (group 2)
    • Chronic lung disease/hypoxia (group 3)
    • Chronic pulmonary thromboembolism (group 4)
    • Other (eg, sarcoidosis) (group 5)
  • Treatment aimed at underlying disease

RA = rheumatoid arthritis; SS = systemic sclerosis.

title: Cardiac myxoma
noteText:
Cardiac myxoma

Tumor characteristics
  • Benign neoplasm, 80% located in left atrium

Clinical features
  • Position-dependent mitral valve obstruction
    • Middiastolic murmur
    • Dyspnea, lightheadedness, syncope
  • Embolization of tumor fragments (eg, stroke)
  • Constitutional symptoms (eg, fever, weight loss)

Diagnosis & management
  • Echocardiography & prompt surgical resection

title: JVP waveform
Groin hernia
Evisceration
noteText:
Abdominal surgery can result in a variety of postoperative wound complications (eg, infection, dehiscence).  These complications are more common after procedures with large incisions and in patients with risk factors for poor wound healing (eg, cancer, chronic corticosteroids, hypoalbuminemia) or increased intraabdominal pressure (eg, cough, obesity).

Postoperative abdominal wounds can be categorized based on fascial involvement:

  • Superficial wound dehiscences are separations of the skin and subcutaneous tissue with intact rectus fascia.  These typically develop within the first postoperative week due to an abnormal subcutaneous fluid buildup (eg, seroma) and can often be managed conservatively with careful dressing changes.

  • Deep (fascial) wound dehiscences involve the rectus fascia (ie, nonintact) and result in exposure of the intraabdominal organs to the external environment.

title: Crying in young infants
noteText:
Crying in young infants

Diagnosis

Key features

Normal
  • Intermittent, consolable, <3 hr/day

Colic
  • â¥3 hr/day (usually evening), â¥3 days/week
  • Healthy infant age <3 months

Gastroesophageal
reflux disease
  • Frequent spit-up
  • Back-arching after feeding

Infection
  • Acute otitis media: bulging tympanic membrane, Â± fever
  • Meningitis: fever, lethargy, bulging fontanel
  • Septic arthritis: fever, limited extremity movement
  • UTI: fever, vomiting, poor feeding

Intussusception
  • Episodic irritability with legs drawn to abdomen
  • Â± Bilious emesis, bloody stools

Torsion
  • Testicular swelling or abdominal distension (ovarian)

Trauma
  • Hair tourniquet: hair accidentally wrapped around digit
  • Corneal abrasion: tearing, photophobia; + fluorescein test
  • Abuse/fracture: bruising, laceration, asymmetric movements
UTI = urinary tract infection.

title: Factitius disorder(imposed on another)
noteText:
Factitious disorder (imposed on another)

Definition
  • Intentional falsification of symptoms or induction of illness in another person (eg, child, older person)

Characteristics of caregiver (offender)
  • Motivated by desire to assume caregiver role (no external gain)
  • Female > male (95% are female, often primary caretaker)

Clinical presentation
  • Frequent visits
  • History is incongruent with clinical findings
  • Unexplained illness persists despite comprehensive evaluation
  • Caregiver seeks multiple opinions (eg, doctor shopping)
  • Symptoms improve when caregiver is absent

Intervention
  • Seek information from other observers (eg, teacher, other family members)
  • Review previous medical records from all available sources
  • Create a multidisciplinary team of specialists for case analysis
  • Involve child/adult protective services

title: Cystic fibrosis
noteText:
Cystic fibrosis

Pathogenesis

  • Mutation (ÎF508) of CFTR gene
  • Autosomal recessive  

Clinical features

  • Recurrent sinopulmonary infections
  • Intestinal obstruction (eg, meconium ileus)
  • Pancreatic insufficiency & diabetes
  • Male infertility  

Diagnosis

  • Elevated sweat chloride levels
  • CFTR mutation on genetic testing
  • Abnormal nasal potential difference

Management

  • Nutritional support
  • Airway clearance
  • Antibiotic coverage (Staphylococcus aureus, Pseudomonas aeruginosa)

CFTR = cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator.

title: Atraumatic splenic rupture
noteText:
Atraumatic splenic rupture

Risk factors
  • Hematologic malignancy (eg, leukemia, lymphoma)
  • Infection (eg, CMV, EBV, malaria)
  • Inflammatory disease (eg, SLE, pancreatitis)
  • Splenic congestion (eg, cirrhosis, pregnancy)
  • Medications (eg, anticoagulation, G-CSF)

Clinical presentation
  • Diffuse or LUQ abdominal pain, peritonitis
  • Referred left shoulder pain (Kehr sign)
  • Hemodynamic instability

Diagnosis
  • Acute anemia
  • Intraperitoneal free fluid on imaging

Treatment
  • Catheter-based angioembolization (stable patients)
  • Emergency splenectomy (unstable patients)

CMV = cytomegalovirus; EBV = Epstein-Barr virus; G-CSF = granulocyte-stimulating colony factor; LUQ = left upper quadrant; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus.

title: Foreign body ingestion
noteText:
Immediate endoscopic removal should be performed in the following circumstances:

  • Sharp object (eg, needle, safety pin) in the esophagus, stomach, or proximal duodenum (as in this patient)
  • Symptoms of esophageal obstruction (eg, drooling, inability to swallow secretions)
  • Symptoms of respiratory compromise
  • Button battery in the esophagus (due to the risk of electrical and chemical injury)
  • Magnets in the esophagus or stomach (due to the potential for bowel entrapment as a result of magnetic attraction across intestinal segments)

title: Perforation of hollow viscus
Non bacterial thrombotic endocarditis
noteText:
Nonbacterial thrombotic endocarditis

Etiology
  • Hypercoagulable state usually due to malignancy or SLE
  • Noninfectious thrombi form on healthy valve

Manifestations
  • Usually asymptomatic until embolization occurs (eg, stroke)
  • Fever, leukocytosis, valve regurgitation (eg, murmur) usually absent

Diagnosis
  • Negative infective endocarditis work-up (eg, blood cultures)
  • Echocardiography: small, mobile vegetations on aortic &/or mitral valve

Management
  • Anticoagulation to reduce thromboembolic risk
  • Identification & treatment of underlying cause

SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus.

title: Aortic stenosis
noteText:
Aortic stenosis

Causes
  • Age-related calcification of normal valve (age >70)*
  • Calcification of congenital bicuspid valve (younger patients)
  • Rheumatic (common worldwide, rare in resource-rich countries)

Clinical manifestations
  • Prolonged asymptomatic period
  • Symptoms progressively develop as stenosis becomes severe:
    • Dyspnea on exertion, â exercise tolerance
    • Exertional angina
    • Syncope or presyncope
    • Decompensated heart failure

Physical examination
  • Crescendo-decrescendo systolic murmur at RUSB
  • Murmur radiates to carotids; S4 may be present (concentric LVH)
  • Diminished & delayed pulses (pulsus parvus et tardus)

Management
  • Valve replacement for symptomatic severe aortic stenosis**

*Most common cause in resource-rich countries.

**Valve replacement is the only effective therapy.  Medical therapy for severe aortic stenosis is limited.

LVH = left ventricular hypertrophy; RUSB = right upper sternal border.

Extra (gallop) heart sounds
 

Features

Associated disorders*

S3
  • Heard just after S2
  • Caused by abrupt cessation of LV filling during early diastole
  • Generally indicative of elevated LV filling pressure
  • Heart failure
  • High-output states (eg, thyrotoxicosis)
  • Mitral or aortic regurgitation

S4
  • Heard just after S1
  • Caused by blood striking a stiff LV wall during atrial contraction
  • Concentric LV hypertrophy
  • Restrictive cardiomyopathy
  • Acute myocardial infarction

*S3 can be normal in children, young adults & pregnant patients.  S4 can be normal in older adults (eg, age >70).

LV = left ventricular.

Valve replacement in aortic stenosis

Severe AS criteria

  • Aortic jet velocity â¥4.0 m/sec, or
  • Mean transvalvular pressure gradient â¥40 mm Hg
  • Valve area usually â¤1.0 cm2 but not required

Indications for valve replacement

Severe AS & â¥1 of the following:

  • Onset of symptoms (eg, angina, syncope)  
  • Left ventricular ejection fraction <50%
  • Undergoing other cardiac surgery (eg, CABG)

AS = aortic stenosis; CABG = coronary artery bypass grafting.

title: Mitral stenosis
noteText:
Mitral stenosis in adults

Etiology/epidemiology
  • Rheumatic heart disease (vast majority of cases)
  • Radiation induced (eg, previous lymphoma treatment)
  • More common in women (~80% of cases)

Clinical presentation
  • Exertional dyspnea, orthopnea, PND, hemoptysis
  • Pulmonary edema Â± right-sided heart failure (eg, LE edema)
  • Atrial fibrillation, â risk for systemic embolization

Diagnosis
  • Opening snap with middiastolic rumble at cardiac apex
  • Echocardiography: â LA size with normal LV size, â transmitral flow velocity

Treatment
  • Percutaneous valvotomy or surgical repair/replacement

LA = left atrial; LE = lower extremity; LV = left ventricular; PND = paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea.

title: Cardiovascular contraindication of pregnancy
noteText:
Cardiovascular contraindications to pregnancy

Highest risk conditions*
  • Symptomatic mitral stenosis
  • Symptomatic aortic stenosis
  • Symptomatic heart failure with LVEF Ë30%
  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension
  • Bicuspid AV with ascending aorta enlargement >50 mm

* Pregnancy contraindicated unless condition is corrected.

AV = aortic valve; LVEF = left ventricular ejection fraction.

title: Chronic MR
noteText:
Chronic mitral regurgitation

Etiology
  • Myxomatous degeneration leading to mitral valve prolapse
    • Usually occurs as an isolated valvular process
    • Connective tissue syndrome (eg, Marfan, Ehlers-Danlos)
  • Rheumatic heart disease
  • Sequelae of prior infective endocarditis

Clinical features
  • Systolic murmur best heard at cardiac apex
  • LV dilation develops when severe (S3, laterally displaced PMI)
  • Atrial fibrillation is common due to left atrial dilation

Management
  • Medications to reduce afterload (eg, ACE inhibitor)
  • Surgical repair or replacement for severe disease

LV = left ventricular; PMI = point of maximal impulse.

Surgical indications for severe chronic mitral valve regurgitation

Primary MR
  • Surgery if LVEF 30%-60% (regardless of symptoms)
  • Consider surgery if successful valve repair* is highly likely:
    • Asymptomatic & LVEF >60%
    • Symptomatic & LVEF <30%

Secondary MR
  • Medical management, valve surgery rarely indicated
*When possible, durable valve repair is favored over replacement because replacement necessitates lifelong anticoagulation & repeat replacement is often needed after ~10 yr.

LVEF = left ventricular ejection fraction; MR = mitral regurgitation.

MR = mitral regurgitation.

title: Chronic AR
noteText:
Chronic aortic regurgitation

Common etiologies
  • Congenital bicuspid aortic valve
  • Postinflammatory (eg, rheumatic heart disease, endocarditis)
  • Aortic root dilation (eg, Marfan syndrome, syphilis)

Pathophysiology
  • Backflow from aorta into LV â â LV end-diastolic volume
  • LV initially compensates with eccentric hypertrophy â â SV & CO
  • Eventual LV dysfunction â â SV & CO â heart failure

Clinical

findings
  • Decrescendo diastolic murmur
  • Widened pulse pressure (âSBP & âDBP)
  • Rapid rise-rapid fall (âwater-hammerâ) pulsation
  • Abrupt carotid distension & collapse, âpistol-shotâ femoral pulses

CO = cardiac output; DBP = diastolic blood pressure; LV = left ventricle; SBP = systolic blood pressure; SV = stroke volume.

title: Dual chamber  pacemaker
Valvular heart disease Mx in noncardiac surgery
noteText:
Revised Cardiac Risk Index (RCRI)
(cardiovascular risk of noncardiac surgery)

6 risk predictors
  • High-risk surgery (eg, vascular, intrathoracic)
  • Ischemic heart disease
  • History of congestive heart failure
  • History of cerebrovascular disease (stroke or TIA)
  • Diabetes mellitus treated with insulin
  • Preoperative creatinine >2 mg/dL

Risk of cardiac death,
nonfatal cardiac arrest,
or nonfatal MI
  • 0-1 factor: low risk*
  • â¥2 factors: elevated risk

*RCRI score of 0-1 originally reported as â¤1% and still accepted as low risk.  Slightly higher
event rates of later studies probably due to using troponins (â sensitivity) and including
additional outcomes (eg, all-cause mortality).

MI = myocardial infarction; TIA = transient ischemic attack.

title: Stable angina
noteText:
Classification of angina

Classic
  • Typical location (eg, substernal), quality & duration
  • Provoked by exercise or emotional stress
  • Relieved by rest or nitroglycerin

Atypical
  • 2 of the 3 characteristics of classic angina

Nonanginal
  • <2 of the 3 characteristics of classic angina

title: Tricuspid atresia
Infective endocarditis in I/V drug users
noteText:
Infective endocarditis: modified Duke criteria

Diagnostic criteria
for IE

Major criteria

  • Blood culture positive for typical microorganism (eg, Staphylococcus aureus, Enterococcus, viridans streptococci)
  • Echocardiography showing valvular vegetation

Minor criteria

  • Predisposing cardiac lesion
  • Intravenous drug use
  • Temperature >38 C (100.4 F)
  • Embolic phenomena
  • Immunologic phenomena (eg, glomerulonephritis)
  • Positive blood culture not meeting above criteria

Definite IE

  • 2 major OR 1 major + 3 minor criteria

Possible IE

  • 1 major + 1 minor OR 3 minor criteria

Clinical findings
(frequency)
  • Fever (>90%)
  • Heart murmur (85%)
  • Petechiae (â¤50%)
  • Subungual splinter hemorrhages (<50%)
  • Osler nodes, Janeway lesions (<50%)
  • Neurologic phenomena (embolic) (â¤40%)
  • Splenomegaly (â¤30%)
  • Roth spots (retinal hemorrhage) (<5%)

IE = infective endocarditis.

Infective endocarditis with intravenous drug use

Pathogenesis
  • Injected particles cause microdamage to right-sided
    valves before being filtered out by the lungs
  • Microdamage facilitates bacterial attachment
  • Increased risk with HIV

Clinical features
  • Tricuspid valve most commonly affected
  • Staphylococcus aureus is the most common organism
  • Septic pulmonary emboli present in up to 75% of cases
  • Audible murmur possibly absent in 50% of cases
  • Few peripheral manifestations (eg, splinter hemorrhages, Janeway lesions)
  • Heart failure uncommon

title: High risk conditions for infective endocarditis
noteText:
High-risk conditions for infective endocarditis
  • Prosthetic heart valve
  • Previous infective endocarditis
  • Structural valve abnormality in transplanted heart
  • Unrepaired cyanotic congenital heart disease
  • Repaired congenital heart disease with residual defect
Prophylactic antibiotics administered 30-60 minutes prior to these procedures reduce the quantity and duration of transient bacteremia; therefore, antibiotics should be administered to those with a high risk of IE (eg, prosthetic valve, prosthetic cardiac graft, certain congenital cyanotic heart diseases). Oral amoxicillin (one 2 g dose) is used prior to dental and respiratory procedures to reduce Streptococcus viridans bacteremia; it can also be used prior to GU/GI procedures in patients with active GU/GI infection to reduce Enterococcus bacteremia.  Patients undergoing procedures in areas of skin and soft tissue infection usually receive intravenous vancomycin to reduce Staphylococcus bacteremia.

Prevention of infective endocarditis with antimicrobial prophylaxis*

High-risk procedures

(Prophylaxis needed)
  • Gingival/apical tooth manipulation (amoxicillin)
  • Respiratory mucosa incision (amoxicillin)
  • Surgery on infected skin or muscle (vancomycin)
  • GI or GU procedure in setting of active infection (ampicillin)

Low-risk procedures

(No prophylaxis)
  • GI or GU endoscopy/procedure in absence of infection
  • Most vaginal/caesarian deliveries

*Indicated for high-risk patients (eg, prosthetic heart valve, previous infective endocarditis, certain congenital cyanotic heart diseases).

GI = gastrointestinal; GU = genitourinary.

title: Acute MR
noteText:

Etiology

    • Mitral valve prolapse
    • Infective endocarditis

  • Acute LV failure (also causing acute RV failure)

Physical examination
