Management
  • Bedside echocardiography
  • Emergency surgical intervention

LV = left ventricular; MI = myocardial infarction; RV = right ventricular.

title: Retroperitoneal hematoma
Lactation failure jaundice vs breast milk jaundice
noteText:
Lactation failure jaundice vs breast milk jaundice

Diagnosis

Timing

Pathophysiology

Clinical features

Lactation failure jaundice

Age <1 week

Insufficient intake of breast milk:

  • â Bilirubin elimination
  • â Enterohepatic circulation
  • Suboptimal breastfeeding
  • Signs of dehydration

Breast milk jaundice

Age >1 week

(peaks at 2 weeks)

â Î²-glucuronidase in breast milk:

  • â Deconjugation of intestinal bilirubin
  • â Enterohepatic circulation
  • Adequate breastfeeding
  • Well-hydrated
Presentation is in the first week of life with jaundice (from unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia) and signs of dehydration.  For example, wet diapers typically equal a neonate's age in days (eg, â¥4 diapers on day 4, increasing to >6 daily), whereas this patient has inadequate urine output with only 3 wet diapers on day 5.  In addition, bowel movements should transition from meconium to frequent, yellow stools in the first few days, and delayed transition can be another sign of dehydration.  Excessive weight loss (â¥10% from birth weight), as seen in this neonate, is also common.

title: Splenic infarction
Polyarteritis nodosa
noteText:
Polyarteritis nodosa

Pathophysiology
  • Correlation with underlying hepatitis B/C (immune complexes)
  • Fibrinoid necrosis of arterial wall â luminal narrowing & thrombosis â tissue ischemia
  • Internal/external elastic lamina damage â microaneurysm formation  â rupture & bleeding

Clinical
features
  • Constitutional: fever, weight loss, malaise
  • Skin: nodules, livedo reticularis, ulcers, purpura
  • Renal: hypertension, renal insufficiency, arterial aneurysms
  • Nervous: headache, seizures, mononeuritis multiplex
  • Gastrointestinal: mesenteric ischemia/infarction
  • Musculoskeletal: myalgias, arthritis

Diagnosis
  • Negative ANCA & ANA
  • Angiography: microaneurysms & segmental/distal narrowing
  • Tissue biopsy: nongranulomatous transmural inflammation

ANA = antinuclear antibodies; ANCA = antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies.

    • Acute onset of nausea, abdominal pain, headache, vomiting
    • Self-limited, lasting 1-2 days
  • Between episodes
    • Usually asymptomatic
    • Often regular intervals (eg, 2-4 weeks)

noteText:
Benign vs pathologic murmurs
 

Benign

Pathologic

History
  • Asymptomatic

  • Infants: poor weight gain, respiratory distress, difficulty feeding
  • Older children: exertional fatigue, chest pain, syncope
  • Family history of SCD or CHD

Murmur
characteristics*
  • Early or midsystolic

  • Decreases or disappears with standing & Valsalva maneuver**

  • Harsh

findings

  • Hepatomegaly

title: Surveillance after colon cancer resection
noteText:
Surveillance after colon cancer resection

Stage I
  • Colonoscopy in 1 year & then every 3-5 years

Stages II & III
  • Colonoscopy in 1 year & then every 3-5 years
  • Periodic CEA testing
  • Annual CT scan of the chest, abdomen (Â± pelvis)

Stage IV
  • Individualize
  • Consider stage II/III strategy but more frequent CT scans

CEA = carcinoembryonic antigen.
Unlike localized colon adenocarcinoma, tumors that invade the muscular and serosal layers (eg, stage II) or exhibit lymph node involvement (eg, stage III) have a significant risk of distant metastasis despite appropriate treatment.

title: Chronic pancreatitis
noteText:
Overview of chronic pancreatitis

Etiology
  • Alcohol use
  • Cystic fibrosis (common in children)
  • Ductal obstruction (eg, malignancy, stones)
  • Autoimmune

Clinical presentation
  • Chronic epigastric pain with intermittent pain-free intervals

Laboratory results/imaging
  • Amylase/lipase can be normal & nondiagnostic

Treatment
  • Pain management
  • Alcohol & smoking cessation
  • Frequent, small meals
  • Pancreatic enzyme supplements

MRCP = magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography.

title: Measures for diagnostic tests
noteText:
Common performance measures for diagnostic tests

Parameter

Definition

Calculation

Sensitivity

The probability of an individual testing positive given the presence of disease

Sensitivity = true positives / (true positives + false negatives)

Specificity

The probability of an individual testing negative given the absence of disease

Specificity = true negatives / (true negatives + false positives)

Positive predictive value (PPV)

The probability that an individual who tests positive actually has the disease

PPV = true positives / (true positives + false positives)

Negative predictive value (NPV)

The probability that an individual who tests negative actually does not have the disease

NPV = true negatives / (true negatives + false negatives)

Positive likelihood ratio (LR+)

The probability of an individual with the disease testing positive divided by the probability of an individual without the disease testing positive

LR+ = sensitivity / (1 â specificity)

Negative likelihood ratio (LRâ)

The probability of an individual with the disease testing negative divided by the probability of an individual without the disease testing negative

LRâ = (1 â sensitivity) / specificity

title: Abdominal compartment syndrome
noteText:
Abdominal compartment syndrome

Etiology
  • â Intraabdominal pressure causing organ dysfunction
  • Risk factors: massive fluid resuscitation, major intraabdominal surgery or pathology

Clinical manifestations
  • Tense, distended abdomen
  • â Ventilatory requirements (diaphragmatic elevation, â intrathoracic pressure)
  • â CVP (venous compression but â venous return & cardiac preload)
  • Hypotension, tachycardia (â venous return & cardiac output)
  • â Urine output (â intraabdominal organ perfusion)

Management
  • Temporizing measures:
    • Avoid over resuscitation with fluids
    • â Intraabdominal volume (eg, NG tube)
    • â Abdominal wall compliance (eg, sedation)
  • Definitive management: surgical decompression

CVP = central venous pressure; NG = nasogastric.

title: Mean, median,mode
PPV, NPV
Factors affecting power
Cut off value
Normal distribution curve
Livedo reticularis
Severe acute pancreatitis
noteText:
Clinical features of severe pancreatitis

Clinical presentation
  • Fever, tachycardia, hypotension
  • Dyspnea, tachypnea &/or basilar crackles
  • Abdominal tenderness &/or distension
  • Cullen sign: periumbilical bluish coloration indicating hemoperitoneum
  • Grey Turner sign: reddish-brown coloration around flanks indicating retroperitoneal bleed

Associated with â risk of severe pancreatitis
  • Age >75
  • Obesity
  • Alcoholism
  • C-reactive protein >150 mg/dL at 48 hr after presentation
  • Rising blood urea nitrogen & creatinine in the first 48 hr
  • Chest x-ray with pulmonary infiltrates or pleural effusion
  • CT scan/magnetic resonance cholangiopancreatography with pancreatic necrosis & extra pancreatic inflammation

Complications
  • Pseudocyst
  • Peripancreatic fluid collection
  • Necrotizing pancreatitis
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome
  • Acute renal failure
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding

Severe acute pancreatitis

Definition
  • Acute pancreatitis with organ failure (eg, respiratory, cardiovascular, renal) persisting >48 hr

Predictors
  • Patient factors:
    • Older age (eg, age >55)
    • Comorbidities, including obesity (BMI >30 kg/m2)
  • Clinical findings:
    • Altered mental status
    • SIRS (eg, leukocytes >12,000/mm3, temperature >38 C [100.4 F])
  • Laboratory findings of intravascular volume depletion:
    • â BUN (>20 mg/dL) and/or â creatinine (>1.8 mg/dL)
    • â HCT (>44%)
  • Radiologic findings:
    • CXR: pulmonary infiltrates, pleural effusions
    • Abdominal CT scan: severe pancreatic necrosis

BUN = blood urea nitrogen; CXR = chest x-ray; HCT = hematocrit; SIRS = systemic inflammatory response syndrome.

title: Acute pancretitis due to cholesterol embolism
noteText:
Acute pancreatitis

Etiology
  • Chronic alcohol use (~40%)
  • Gallstones (~40%)
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Drugs (eg, azathioprine, valproic acid, thiazides)
  • Infection (eg, CMV, Legionella, Aspergillus)
  • Iatrogenic (post-ERCP, ischemic/atheroembolic)

Clinical presentation

Diagnosis (requires 2 of the following)

  • Acute epigastric pain radiating to the back
  • Amylase or lipase >3Ã normal limit
  • Abnormalities on imaging consistent with pancreatitis
 

Other findings

  • ALT level >150 U/L suggests biliary pancreatitis
  • Severe disease: fever, tachypnea, hypoxemia, hypotension

ALT = alanine aminotransferase; CMV = cytomegalovirus; ERCP = endoscopic retrograde
cholangiopancreatograPHY

title: Triglyceride induced pancreatitis
noteText:
Triglyceride-induced pancreatitis

Risk

Triglyceride levels (mg/dL)

  • <500: minimal risk
  • 500-999: mild risk
  • 1,000-1,999: moderate risk
  • â¥2,000: high risk

Other risk factors: pregnancy, alcoholism, obesity, uncontrolled diabetes

Clinical features
  • Acute epigastric pain radiating to back
  • Â± Fever, nausea, vomiting
  • Elevated serum lipase (>3 times upper limit of normal)

Management
  • Intravenous fluid hydration, pain control
  • Triglycerides â¥500 mg/dL: consider insulin infusion
  • Triglycerides >1,000 mg/dL or severe pancreatitis (eg, lactic acidosis, hypocalcemia): consider apheresis (therapeutic plasma exchange)

  • Amylase or lipase >3Ã normal limit

  • ALT level >150 U/L suggests biliary pancreatitis
  • Severe disease: fever, tachypnea, hypoxemia, hypotension

ALT = alanine aminotransferase; CMV = cytomegalovirus; ERCP = endoscopic retrograde
cholangiopancreatography.

Clinical features of acute pancreatitis

Etiology
  • Chronic alcohol use
  • Gallstones
  • Hyperlipidemia (types I, IV & V)
  • Drugs (eg, didanosine, azathioprine, valproic acid)
  • Infections (eg, cytomegalovirus, Legionella, Aspergillus)
  • Trauma
  • Iatrogenic (post-ERCP)

Clinical presentation

Diagnosis requires 2 of the following:

  • Acute epigastric abdominal pain often radiating to the back
  • â Amylase/lipase >3 times normal limit
  • Abdominal imaging showing focal or diffuse pancreatic enlargement with heterogeneous enhancement with intravenous contrast (CT scan) or diffusely enlarged & hypoechoic pancreas (ultrasonography)
 

Other findings:

  • Nausea, vomiting, leukocytosis
  • Severe disease with possible abdominal tenderness, fever, tachypnea, hypoxemia & hypotension
  • ALT level >150 U/L â biliary pancreatitis

Complications
  • Pleural effusion
  • Ileus
  • Pancreatic pseudocyst/abscess/necrosis
  • Acute respiratory distress syndrome

ALT = alanine aminotransferase; ERCP = endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography.

Drugs associated with drug-induced pancreatitis

Analgesics
  • Acetaminophen
  • Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs

Antibiotics

title: RR and OR
Precision and accuracy
Pancreatic adenocarcinoma
noteText:
Pancreatic adenocarcinoma

Clinical presentation

Laboratory & imaging findings

  • â Cancer-associated antigen 19-9 (not as a screening test)

title: Pleural effusion types
noteText:
Exudative & transudative pleural effusions
 

Exudate

Transudate

Light criteria

Pleural protein/serum protein >0.5

OR

Pleural LDH/serum LDH >0.6

OR

Pleural LDH >2/3 upper limit of normal of serum LDH

Exudate criteria not met

Inflammatory disruption of vascular permeability

Change in hydrostatic or oncotic pressure

Common causes
  • Infection (eg, TB, pneumonia)

  • Rheumatologic disease (eg, RA, SLE)
  • Pulmonary embolism
  • Pancreatitis
  • Post-CABG
  • Heart failure
  • Cirrhosis (hepatic hydrothorax)
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Constrictive pericarditis

CABG = coronary artery bypass grafting; LDH = lactate dehydrogenase; RA = rheumatoid arthritis; SLE = systemic lupus erythematosus; TB = tuberculosis.

title: Camphylobacter gastroenteritis
noteText:
Campylobacter gastroenteritis

Epidemiology
  • Most commonly transmitted via undercooked poultry

Clinical
features
  • Fever, abdominal pain, diarrhea (mucoid Â± blood)
  • Pseudoappendicitis (RLQ pain due to acute ileocecitis)

Treatment
  • Supportive care (symptoms usually self-limited <7 days)
  • Antibiotics only in severe or high-risk cases*

Complications
  • Guillain-BarrÃ© syndrome
  • Reactive arthritis

*Duration >7 days; bloody stools; high fevers; patients who are pregnant, immunocompromised, or elderly.

RLQ = right lower quadrant.

title: Complicated smaal bowel obstruction with perforation
Shiga toxin producing E. coli
noteText:
Shiga toxinâproducing Escherichia coli

Pathogenesis
  • Ingestion of contaminated/undercooked beef or contact with farm animals
  • Invasion of intestinal epithelial cells
  • Production of Shiga toxin

Clinical features
  • Watery â bloody diarrhea within 3 days
  • No high fever*

Diagnosis
  • Multiplex stool PCR testing
  • Stool Shiga toxin assay
  • Stool culture

Management
  • Supportive care (eg, aggressive fluids)
  • Avoidance of antibiotics & antidiarrheals

Complications
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (may develop 1-2 weeks after diarrhea onset)

*Low-grade temperature of <38.5 C (101.3 F) may occur.

title: Acute colonic pseudoobstruction
noteText:
Acute colonic pseudoobstruction (Ogilvie syndrome)

Etiologies
  • Major surgery, traumatic injury, severe infection
  • Electrolyte derangement (â K, â Mg, â Ca)
  • Medications (eg, opiates, anticholinergics)
  • Neurologic disorders (eg, dementia, stroke)

Clinical
findings
  • Abdominal distension, pain, obstipation, vomiting
  • Tympanic to percussion, â bowel sounds
  • If perforation: guarding, rigidity, rebound tenderness

Imaging
  • X-ray: colonic dilation, normal haustra, nondilated small bowel
  • CT scan: colonic dilation without anatomic obstruction

Management
  • NPO, nasogastric/rectal tube decompression
  • Neostigmine if no improvement within 48 hr

title: Acute aortic dissection
noteText:
Acute aortic dissection

Risk factors
  • Chronic hypertension (strongest overall risk factor)
  • Underlying aortopathy (eg, Marfan syndrome)
  • Cocaine use

Clinical presentation
  • Severe, tearing chest or back pain, maximal at onset
  • Â± Variation in SBP between arms >20 mm Hg
  • Hypertension usually present*

Diagnosis
  • ECG: normal or nonspecific ST-segment & T-wave changes
  • Chest x-ray: mediastinal widening
  • CT angiography or TEE for definitive diagnosis

Treatment
  • Pain control (eg, morphine)
  • Intravenous beta blockers (eg, esmolol)
  • Â± Sodium nitroprusside (if SBP >120 mm Hg despite beta blockers)
  • Emergency surgical repair for ascending dissection

*Hypotension on presentation suggests aortic rupture or other complication (eg, cardiac tamponade, acute aortic regurgitation).

SBP = systolic blood pressure; TEE = transesophageal echocardiography.

Complications due to extension of acute aortic dissection

Complication

(involved structure)
  • Stroke (carotid artery)
  • Horner syndrome (carotid sympathetic plexus)
  • Acute aortic regurgitation (aortic root/valve)
  • Myocardial ischemia/infarction (coronary artery ostia)
  • Pericardial effusion/tamponade (pericardium)
  • Hemothorax (pleural cavity)
  • Renal infarction (renal arteries)
  • Intestinal ischemia (mesenteric arteries)
  • Lower extremity paralysis (spinal arteries)

title: Retroperitoneal organ
noteText:
Retroperitoneal abdominal organs
  • Suprarenal (adrenal) glands
  • Aorta & inferior vena cava
  • Duodenum* (except 1st part)
  • Pancreas* (head & body)
  • Ureters
  • Colon* (ascending & descending)
  • Kidneys
  • Esophagus
  • Rectum (middistal)

Mnemonic: SAD PUCKER

*Secondarily retroperitoneal (developed intraperitoneal & migrated retroperitoneal).

title: Proctalgia fugax
noteText:
Proctalgia fugax

Pathophysiology
  • Spastic contraction of the anal sphincter
  • Pudendal nerve compression

Risk factors
  • Female sex
  • Other functional pathologies (eg, irritable bowel syndrome)
  • Psychosocial stress, anxiety

Manifestations
  • Recurrent rectal pain unrelated to defecation
  • Episodes lasting seconds to minutes (â¤30 min)
  • No pain between episodes

Evaluation
  • Normal physical examination (eg, rectal, pelvic, prostate)
  • No laboratory abnormalities

Management
  • Reassurance
  • Nitroglycerin cream Â± biofeedback therapy for refractory symptoms

title: Factitious disorder
noteText:
Factitious disorder (imposed on self)

Behavioral
characteristics
  • Intentional falsification of illness:
    • Feigning illness
    • Self-induced illness
    • Exacerbation of preexisting illness
  • Motivation by internal factors rather than external gain (eg, financial compensation)

Clinical
presentation
  • Overt/dramatic symptoms
  • Frequent visits for medical care
  • Patient possibly refusing consent to release records or tampering with test samples
  • More common in health care workers

Diagnostic
confirmation
  • Direct observation or discovery of medical supplies (eg, medications, syringes)
  • Confirmatory testing (eg, sulfonylurea screen, stool laxative screen)
  • Medical record review

Stool osmotic gap

290 mOsm/kg â 2 Ã (stool Na + stool K)

<50

Secretory diarrhea

50-125

Indeterminate

>125

Osmotic diarrhea

title: Radiation proctitis
noteText:
Radiation proctitis
 

Acute radiation proctitis

Chronic radiation proctitis

Postradiation onset
  • â¤8 weeks
  • >3 months to years

Pathogenesis
  • Direct mucosal damage
  • Obliterative endarteritis & chronic mucosal ischemia
  • Submucosal fibrosis

Manifestations
  • Diarrhea, mucus discharge, tenesmus
  • Minimal bleeding
  • Severe bleeding
  • Â± Strictures with constipation & rectal pain

Endoscopic appearance
  • Severe erythema
  • Edema, ulcerations
  • Multiple telangiectasias
  • Mucosal pallor & friability

Management
  • Antidiarrheals (eg, loperamide)
  • Butyrate enemas
  • Endoscopic thermal coagulation
  • Sucralfate or glucocorticoid enemas

title: Mx of suspected appendicitis
noteText:
Modified Alvarado score

Points
(each)

Clinical feature

1
  • Migratory RLQ pain
  • Anorexia
  • Nausea or vomiting
  • Fever >37.5 C (>99.5 F)
  • RLQ rebound tenderness

2
  • RLQ tenderness
  • Leukocytes >10,000/mm3

9

Total possible score

0-3: appendicitis unlikely

 â¥4: evaluate for appendicitis

RLQ = right lower quadrant.

Examination signs of appendicitis

Sign

Findings

Significance

Peritoneal signs

  • Rebound tenderness
  • Involuntary guarding
  • Abdominal rigidity
  • Acute increase in pain after removing the hand from applying pressure
  • Tensing of abdominal wall muscles during palpation of abdomen
  • Persistent tension of abdominal wall muscles

Peritoneal irritation (rupture or impending rupture)

Psoas sign
  • RLQ pain with extension of right thigh

Abscess adjacent to psoas or retrocecal appendix

Obturator sign
  • RLQ pain with internal rotation of right thigh

Pelvic appendix or abscess

Rovsing's sign
  • RLQ pain with LLQ palpation & retropulsion of colonic contents

Acute appendicitis

Rectal tenderness
  • Right pelvic pain during rectal examination, especially with pressure on the right rectal wall

Pelvic appendix or abscess

title: Anorexia nervosa
noteText:
Anorexia nervosa

Clinical features
  • BMI <18.5 kg/m2
  • Fear of weight gain, distorted body image

Medical complications

  • Osteoporosis
  • Amenorrhea
  • Lanugo, hair loss, dry skin
  • Gastroparesis, constipation
  • Enlarged parotid glands (if binge/purge type)
  • Hypotension, hypothermia, bradycardia
  • Cardiac atrophy, arrhythmias

title: Opioid induced constipation Mx
noteText:
Opioid-induced constipation management

Nonpharmacologic
interventions
  • Increased fluids
  • Increased dietary fiber
  • Increased exercise
  • Early ambulation (postsurgical)

Pharmacotherapy
  • Osmotic laxatives (eg, polyethylene glycol, lactulose)
  • Contact cathartics or stimulant laxatives (eg, senna, bisacodyl)
  • Hard stools: stool softeners (eg, docusate)
  • Refractory: methylnaltrexone or lubiprostone

title: Giardiasis
noteText:
Giardiasis

Risk factors
  • Contaminated food or water
  • Fecal incontinence & crowding (eg, day care, nursing home)
  • Immunodeficiency (eg, CVID, IgA deficiency, CF, HIV)

Pathogenesis
  • Villous blunting, disruption of epithelial tight junctions, loss of brush border enzymes â malabsorption

Clinical features
  • Subacute (<4 weeks) or chronic (months)
  • Loose, oily, nonbloody stools
  • Bloating, flatulence
  • Weight loss, decreased linear velocity (children), vitamin deficiencies

Diagnosis
  • Stool antigen or PCR testing (â sensitivity)
  • Stool microscopy (â sensitivity)

Treatment
  • First-line: tinidazole or nitazoxanide
  • Alternate: metronidazole
  • Pregnancy (first trimester): paromomycin
  • Refractory/recurrent symptoms: evaluation for immunodeficiency

CF = cystic fibrosis; CVID = common variable immunodeficiency.

title: Carcinoid syndrome
noteText:
Features of carcinoid syndrome

Clinical manifestations
  • Skin: flushing, telangiectasias, cyanosis
  • Gastrointestinal: diarrhea, cramping
  • Cardiac: valvular lesions (right > left side)
  • Pulmonary: bronchospasm
  • Miscellaneous: niacin deficiency (dermatitis, diarrhea, dementia)

Diagnosis
  • Elevated 24-hr urinary excretion of 5-HIAA
  • CT scan/MRI of abdomen & pelvis to localize tumor
  • OctreoScan to detect metastases
  • Echocardiogram (if symptoms of carcinoid heart disease are present)

Treatment
  • Octreotide for symptomatic patients & prior to surgery/anesthesia
  • Surgery for liver metastases

title: Delayed passage of meconium
noteText:
Delayed passage of meconium
 

Hirschsprung disease

Meconium ileus

Pathophysiology
  • Failure of neural crest cell migration
  • Obstruction by inspissated stool

Level of obstruction
  • Rectosigmoid
  • Ileum

Rectal examination
  • Increased tone
  • Positive squirt sign*
  • Normal tone
  • Negative squirt sign*

Meconium consistency
  • Normal
  • Inspissated

Imaging
  • Dilated proximal colon Â± small bowel
  • Narrow rectosigmoid
  • Dilated small bowel
  • Microcolon

Associated disorder
  • Down syndrome
  • Cystic fibrosis

*Expulsion of gas/stool on rectal examination.

title: Bile acid diarrhoea
noteText:
Bile acid diarrhea

Pathophysiology
  • Unresorbed bile acids spill into the colon, resulting in mucosal irritation
    • Bile acid enters terminal ileum too rapidly & overwhelms resorptive capacity (eg, post cholecystectomy)
    • Ileal disease impairs bile absorption (eg, Crohn disease, abdominal radiation damage)

Clinical features
  • Secretory diarrhea (eg, fasting diarrhea, nocturnal episodes)
  • Bloating, abdominal cramps
  • Unremarkable serum & stool studies

Treatment
  • Bile acidâbinding resins (eg, cholestyramine, colestipol)

title: Anal fissure
noteText:
Anal fissures

Etiology
  • Local trauma (eg, constipation, prolonged diarrhea, anal sex)
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (eg, Crohn disease)
  • Malignancy

Clinical
presentation
  • Pain with bowel movements
  • Bright red blood on toilet paper or stool surface
  • Most common at posterior anal midline
  • Chronic fissure may have skin tag at distal end

Treatment
  • High-fiber diet & adequate fluid intake
  • Stool softeners
  • Sitz baths
  • Topical anesthetics & vasodilators (eg, nifedipine, nitroglycerin)

title: IBD
noteText:
Inflammatory bowel disease subtype characteristics
 

Crohn disease

Ulcerative colitis

Involvement
  • Anywhere mouth to anus (mostly ileum & colon)
  • Perianal disease with rectal sparing
  • Skip lesions
  • Rectum (always) & colon
  • Continuous lesions

Microscopy
  • Noncaseating granulomas
  • No granulomas

Gross
findings
  • Transmural inflammation
  • Linear mucosal ulcerations
  • Cobblestoning, creeping fat
  • Mucosal & submucosal inflammation
  • Pseudopolyps

Clinical
manifestations
  • Abdominal pain (often RLQ)
  • Watery diarrhea (bloody if colitis)
  • Abdominal pain (varying locations)
  • Bloody diarrhea

Intestinal
complications
  • Fistulae, abscesses
  • Strictures (bowel obstruction)
  • Toxic megacolon

RLQ = right lower quadrant.

title: Acute diverticulitis
noteText:
Clinical features of acute diverticulitis

Clinical presentation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Nausea/vomiting, altered bowel movements
  • Fever, leukocytosis
  • Possible sterile pyuria

Diagnosis
  • CT scan of the abdomen (oral & intravenous contrast)

Management
  • Bowel rest
  • Antibiotics (eg, ciprofloxacin, metronidazole)
  • Colonoscopy 6-8 weeks after resolution

Complications
  • Abscess, obstruction, fistula, perforation

title: Initial stabilization of STEMI patient
noteText:
Comparison of left ventricular & right ventricular myocardial infarction
 

Left ventricular MI

Right ventricular MI

Clinical features
  • Pulmonary edema
  • S3 & S4
  • Clear lungs & JVD
  • Marked hypotension

ECG findings
  • Ischemic changes in anterior, lateral, or inferior leads
  • Inferior ischemic changes
  • ST-segment elevation in V4R
  • Bradyarrhythmias

Hemodynamic findings
  • â LV & RV preload
  • â SVR
  • â RV preload, â LV preload
  • â SVR

Management
  • Fluid restriction
  • Preload & afterload reduction
  • Reperfusion therapy
  • Fluid resuscitation
  • Avoid preload reduction
  • Reperfusion therapy

JVD = jugular venous distension; LV = left ventricular; MI = myocardial infarction; RV = right ventricular; SVR = systemic vascular resistance.

title: Vasospastic angina
noteText:
Vasospastic angina

Pathogenesis

  • Hyperreactivity of coronary smooth muscle

Clinical
presentation

  • Young patients (age <50)
  • Smoking (minimal other CAD risk factors)
  • Recurrent chest discomfort
    • Occurs at rest or during sleep
    • Spontaneous resolution â¤15 min

Diagnosis

  • Ambulatory ECG: ST-segment elevation
  • Coronary angiography: no CAD

Treatment

  • Calcium channel blocker (preventive)
  • Sublingual nitroglycerin (abortive)

CAD = coronary artery disease.

title: Anorectal fistula
noteText:
Anorectal fistula (fistula in ano)

Causes
  • Perianal abscess
  • Crohn disease
  • Malignancy, radiation proctitis
  • Infection (eg, lymphogranuloma venereum)

Clinical manifestations
  • Perirectal pain, discharge
  • Inflammatory papule/pustule
  • Palpable fistula tract

Management
  • Assess extent of fistula
    • Gentle probe
    • Imaging (endosonography, fistulogram, MRI)
  • Surgery (eg, fistulotomy)

title: Sigmoid volvulus
noteText:
Sigmoid volvulus

Risk factors
  • Sigmoid colon redundancy (eg, dilation/elongation from chronic constipation)
  • Colonic dysmotility (eg, underlying neurologic disorder)

Presentation
  • Slowly progressive abdominal discomfort/distension Â± obstructive symptoms (eg, nausea, emesis, obstipation)
  • Abdomen distended & tympanitic to percussion

Imaging
  • X-ray: dilated, inverted, U-shaped loop of colon (coffee bean sign)
  • CT scan: dilated sigmoid colon, mesenteric twisting (whirl sign)

Management
  • Endoscopic detorsion (eg, flexible sigmoidoscopy) & elective sigmoid colectomy
  • Emergency sigmoid colectomy if perforation/peritonitis present

title: Toxic megacolon
noteText:
Toxic megacolon

Pathophysiology
  • Colonic smooth muscle inflammation & paralysis
  • Complication of IBD or infectious colitis
  • â Risk with use of antimotility agents (eg, loperamide) or opioids

Clinical features
  • Systemic toxicity (eg, fever, tachycardia, hypotension)
  • Abdominal pain & distension following diarrheal illness

Diagnosis
  • Colonic dilation (>6 cm) on imaging

Treatment
  • Bowel rest/decompression, antibiotics
  • Corticosteroids if IBD-associated
  • Surgery for perforation, peritonitis, clinical deterioration

IBD = inflammatory bowel disease.

Inflammatory bowel disease subtype characteristics
 

Crohn disease

Ulcerative colitis

Involvement
  • Anywhere mouth to anus (mostly ileum & colon)
  • Perianal disease with rectal sparing
  • Skip lesions
  • Rectum (always) & colon
  • Continuous lesions

Microscopy
  • Noncaseating granulomas
  • No granulomas

Gross
findings
  • Transmural inflammation
  • Linear mucosal ulcerations
  • Cobblestoning, creeping fat
  • Mucosal & submucosal inflammation
  • Pseudopolyps

Clinical
manifestations
  • Abdominal pain (often RLQ)
  • Watery diarrhea (bloody if colitis)
  • Abdominal pain (varying locations)
  • Bloody diarrhea

Intestinal
complications
  • Fistulae, abscesses
  • Strictures (bowel obstruction)
  • Toxic megacolon

RLQ = right lower quadrant.

title: Anal and perianal masses
noteText:
Anal & perianal masses

Rectal prolapse
  • Erythematous mass with concentric rings that occurs with Valsalva
  • Mucus discharge, mild abdominal pain, mass sensation

External hemorrhoid
  • Dusky/purple lump or polyp
  • Associated itching, bleeding
  • Thrombosis: acute enlargement with pain

Internal hemorrhoid
  • Intermittent itching, painless bleeding, leakage of stool
  • Detected with digital rectal examination or anoscopy (unless prolapsed)

Perianal abscess
  • Fluctuant mass/swelling with erythema
  • Fever
  • Gradual onset

Anogenital wart
  • Pink or flesh-colored papules, plaques, or cauliflower-shaped masses
  • Chronic onset
  • Mild itching, bleeding

Anorectal cancer
  • Squamous cell carcinoma most common
  • Bleeding, pain
  • Ulcerating, enlarging mass

Skin tags
  • Small, flesh-colored papules
  • May represent external terminus of anal fissure (sentinel tag)

title: Appendicitis during pregnancy
Downs syndrome
Mx of clostridium difficile infection
Jejunal atresia
Clinical feature of anabolic steroid abuse
noteText:
Clinical features of anabolic steroid abuse

Musculoskeletal
  • â Muscle mass

Reproductive
  • Low testosterone, FSH, LH
  • Testicular atrophy
  • â Spermatogenesis
  • Normal libido & erectile function (during use)
  • â Libido, impotence (during withdrawal)

Endocrine
  • â LDL, â HDL cholesterol

Hematologic
  • Erythrocytosis

Psychological
  • Affective symptoms
  • Aggression

Dermatologic/breast
  • Acne
  • Gynecomastia

title: Specific phobia
noteText:
Specific phobia

History &
clinical features
  • Marked anxiety about a specific object or situation (the phobic stimulus) for >6 months
  • Common types: fear of flying, heights, animals, injections, blood
  • Avoidance behavior (eg, avoiding bridges & elevators, refusing work requiring travel)
  • Common (10% of population)
  • Usually develops in childhood, often after traumatic event

Treatment
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy with exposure (first-line)
  • Short-acting benzodiazepines (limited role, may help acutely if therapist unavailable or insufficient time)

title: Methamphetamine intoxication
noteText:
Methamphetamine intoxication

Clinical features
  • Euphoric or dysphoric mood (eg, anxiety, irritability)
  • Agitated behaviors (eg, restlessness, tremor)
  • Bruxism, poor dentition
  • Psychotic symptoms
    • Delusions (eg, paranoia, grandiosity)
    • Hallucinations
    • Formication (eg, "bugs crawling under the skin")
  • Anorexia
  • Decreased need for sleep
  • Sympathomimetic effects (eg, tachycardia, hypertension, mydriasis, diaphoresis)

title: Neuroleptic malignant syndrome
noteText:
Neuroleptic malignant syndrome

Causative
agents
  • Antipsychotic medication (eg, haloperidol)
  • Antiemetic medications (eg, promethazine)
  • Withdrawal of Parkinson medications

Pathophysiology
  • Central dopaminergic receptor blockade (hyperthermia, dysautonomia)
  • Disruption of nigrostriatal dopamine pathways (rigidity)

Signs/symptoms
  • Fever
  • Altered mental status
  • Generalized muscle rigidity (lead-pipe rigidity)
  • Autonomic instability (abnormal vital signs, diaphoresis)
  • Elevated creatine kinase Â± renal failure

Treatment
  • Stop antipsychotics or restart dopamine agents
  • Supportive care (hydration, cooling), intensive care unit
  • Benzodiazepines
  • Bromocriptine or dantrolene if refractory

title: PTSD
noteText:
Posttraumatic stress disorder

Clinical
features
  • Exposure to life-threatening trauma
  • Nightmares, flashbacks, intrusive memories
  • Avoidance of reminders, dissociation
  • Emotional detachment, negative mood, decreased interest in activities
  • Sleep disturbance, hypervigilance, irritability
  • Duration >1 month

Treatment
  • Trauma-focused cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Antidepressants (SSRIs, SNRIs)

SNRIs = serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors; SSRIs = selective serotonin
reuptake inhibitors.

title: Pharmacotherapy for smoking cessation
noteText:
Pharmacotherapy for smoking cessation

Treatment

Indications

Adverse effects/
contraindications

Varenicline
  • More effective than either bupropion or combination NRT
  • Disordered sleep & abnormal dreams

Long-acting NRT
(nicotine patch)
  • â Cravings & daytime withdrawal symptoms
  • Long-acting may be combined with short-acting NRT ("patch plus") to improve efficacy
  • No significant effects, safe in almost all patients

Short-acting NRT
(nasal spray, gum,
lozenge, inhaler)

Bupropion
  • â Postcessation weight gain
  • Good choice for patients with unipolar depression
  • Contraindicated in patients with seizure or eating disorders

NRT = nicotine replacement therapy.

title: Motivational interviewing
noteText:
Motivational interviewing

Indications
  • Substance use disorders
  • Other behaviors in patients who are not ready to change

Principles
  • Acknowledge resistance to change
  • Address discrepancies between behavior & long-term goals
  • Enhance motivation to change
  • Nonjudgmental

Technique (OARS)
  • Ask Open-ended questions (encourage further discussion)
  • Give Affirmations
  • Reflect & Summarize main points

Motivational interviewing: components

Engaging
  • Start a nonjudgmental, open-ended conversation
  • Collaborate to set the agenda
  • Elicit patient strengths

Focusing
  • Ask the patient to identify 1 or 2 behavior targets

Evoking
  • Elicit change talk to get the patient's:
    • Commitment
    • Reasons to change

Planning
  • Guide the patient toward:
    • Identifying specific next steps
    • Anticipating obstacles
    • Deciding how to measure success

title: Side eefect of cough and cold medication
noteText: Over-the-counter antihistamines (eg, diphenhydramine, doxylamine) that decrease nasal discharge also have anticholinergic properties that can cause confusion and hallucinations.  Alpha-adrenergic agents (eg, phenylephrine, pseudoephedrine) constrict blood vessels, decreasing nasal congestion; they can also result in agitation and psychosis via sympathomimetic properties.  In addition, the cough suppressant dextromethorphan, which is an NMDA antagonist, can result in dissociative symptoms and hallucinations.

title: Common withdrawal symptoms
noteText:
Opioid withdrawal

Time course
  • 4 to 48 hr after opioid cessation
  • Immediately after opioid antagonist (life-threatening)

Clinical
presentation
  • Gastrointestinal: nausea, vomiting, cramping, diarrhea, â bowel sounds
  • Cardiac: â pulse, â blood pressure, diaphoresis
  • Psychologic: insomnia, yawning, dysphoric mood
  • Other: myalgia, arthralgia, mydriasis, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, piloerection

Diagnosis
  • History & examination alone (clinical diagnosis)

Management
  • Opioid agonist: methadone or buprenorphine
  • Nonopioid: clonidine or adjunctive medications (antiemetics, antidiarrheals, benzodiazepines)

Cholinergic toxicity

Muscarinic effects
(DUMBELS)
  • Diarrhea/diaphoresis
  • Urination
  • Miosis
  • Bronchospasm, bronchorrhea & bradycardia
  • Emesis
  • Lacrimation
  • Salivation

Nicotinic effects
  • Muscle weakness, paralysis & fasciculations

Common withdrawal syndromes

Substance

Withdrawal symptoms

Examination findings

Alcohol

Tremors, agitation, anxiety, delirium, psychosis

Seizures, tachycardia, palpitations

Benzodiazepines

Tremors, anxiety, perceptual disturbances, psychosis, insomnia

Opioids

Nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramping, diarrhea, muscle aches

(eg, cocaine, amphetamines)

No significant findings

No significant findings

noteText:

Normal

Abnormal

title: Classification of UC
noteText:
Classification & management of mild ulcerative colitis

Clinical features
  • <4 watery bowel movements per day
  • Hematochezia is rare or intermittent

Laboratory findings
  • No anemia
  • Normal ESR & CRP

  • 5-Aminosalicylic acid agents (eg, mesalamine,

CRP = C-reactive protein; ESR = erythrocyte sedimentation rate.

title: Evaluation of occult GIT bleeding
Clostridium difficile colitis
noteText:
Clostridioides difficile colitis

Risk factors
  • Recent antibiotic use or hospitalization
  • Advanced age (>65)
  • Gastric acid suppression (eg, PPI, H2 blocker)
  • Underlying inflammatory bowel disease
  • Chemotherapy

Clinical
presentation
  • Profuse watery diarrhea
  • Leukocytosis (~15,000/mm3)
  • Fulminant colitis or toxic megacolon

Diagnosis
  • Stool PCR for C difficile genes*
  • Stool EIA for C difficile toxin & glutamate dehydrogenase antigen

Infection
control
  • Hand hygiene with soap & water
  • Contact isolation
  • Sporicidal disinfectants (eg, bleach)

*Genes specific to toxigenic strains are assessed.

EIA = enzyme immunoassay; H2 = histamine-2 receptor; PPI = proton pump inhibitor.

Cecal volvulus

Pathophysiology

title: Evaluation of IBS
noteText:
Clinical features of irritable bowel syndrome

Rome IV diagnostic criteria

Recurrent abdominal pain/discomfort â¥1 days/week for past 3 months & â¥2 of the following:

  • Related to defecation (improves or worsens)
  • Change in stool frequency
  • Change in stool form

Alarm features
  • Older age of onset (â¥50)
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding
  • Nocturnal diarrhea (ie, fasting state)
  • Worsening pain
  • Unintended weight loss
  • Iron deficiency anemia
  • Elevated C-reactive protein
  • Positive fecal lactoferrin or calprotectin
  • Family history of early colon cancer or IBD

IBD = inflammatory bowel disease.

title: Pediatric constipation
noteText:
Pediatric constipation
 

Pathologic

Functional

Risk factors
  • Delayed meconium passage
  • Down syndrome (associated with HD & intestinal atresia/stenosis)
  • Solid food introduction
  • Toilet training
  • School entry

History
  • Poor weight gain or linear growth
  • Narrow (ribbon) stools
  • Blood mixed in stool
  • Bilious vomiting or fever
  • Absence of pathologic features
  • Painful, infrequent, large-caliber or pellet-like stools*
  • Fecal soiling (encopresis)

Examination
  • Displaced anus, â rectal tone, or sacral anomalies (eg, hair tuft)
  • Abnormal lower extremity neurologic findings (eg, weakness)
  • Severe abdominal distension
  • Absence of pathologic features
  • Mild abdominal distension
  • Anal fissure (Â± rectal bleeding)

Management
  • Work up for organic cause
    • Common (eg, celiac disease, hypothyroidism)
    • Urgent (eg, HD, CF, spinal dysraphism)
  • Age-appropriate toileting plan
  • Dietary changes (â fiber/water)
  • Laxatives (eg, polyethylene glycol)

*Benign features refractory to functional constipation management may also be pathologic.
CF = cystic fibrosis; HD = Hirschsprung disease.

title: Duodenal hematoma
Approach to straining impairment
Gonococcal proctitis
noteText:
Gonococcal proctitis

Transmission
  • Receptive anal intercourse

Manifestations
  • Mucopurulent anal discharge, occasional rectal bleeding
  • Tenesmus, constipation

title: SEROTONIN SYNDROME
noteText:
Serotonin syndrome

Causes
  • Serotonergic medications, especially in combination (eg, SSRI/SNRI, TCA, tramadol)
  • Drug interactions: serotonergic medication & MAOI or linezolid
  • Intentional overdose of serotonergic medications
  • Serotonergic substances (eg, MDMA, dextromethorphan, amphetamines)

Clinical
features
  • Mental status changes (eg, anxiety, agitation, delirium)
  • Autonomic dysregulation (eg, diaphoresis, hypertension, tachycardia, hyperthermia, vomiting, diarrhea)
  • Neuromuscular hyperactivity (eg, tremor, myoclonus, hyperreflexia)

Management
  • Discontinuation of all serotonergic medications
  • Supportive care, sedation with benzodiazepines
  • Serotonin antagonist (cyproheptadine) if supportive measures fail
  • Immediate sedation, paralysis & tracheal intubation if temperature >41.1 C (106 F)

MAOI = monoamine oxidase inhibitor; MDMA = 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine; SNRI = serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor; SSRI = selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor; TCA = tricyclic antidepressant.

Anticholinergic toxicity

Symptom

Mechanism

"Hot as a hare"
â Body temperature
  • â Sweating leads to â heat dissipation

"Dry as a bone"
â Secretions (eg, mucous membranes, sweat glands)
  • â Glandular secretion & smooth muscle contraction

"Red as a beet"
Flushed skin
  • Superficial vasodilation from â body heat

"Blind as a bat"
Cycloplegia, mydriasis
  • Paralysis of ciliary muscle & iris sphincter

"Mad as a hatter"
Altered mental status
  • Permeates blood-brain barrier & affects CNS pathways

"Full as a flask"
Constipation,
urinary retention
  • â Intestinal smooth muscle contraction
  • â Detrusor contraction & â internal urethral sphincter relaxation

"Fast as a fiddle"

Tachycardia
  • â Vagal tone at the sinoatrial node

Intoxication syndromes in drugs of abuse

Drug

Clinical features

NMDA antagonists
(eg, PCP, ketamine)
  • Violent behavior
  • Dissociation
  • Hallucinations
  • Amnesia
  • Nystagmus (horizontal or vertical)
  • Ataxia

MDMA (ecstasy)
  • Euphoria
  • Tachycardia/hypertension
  • Hyperthermia
  • Serotonin syndrome
  • Hyponatremia
  • Seizures
  • Mydriasis

Benzodiazepines
  • CNS depression
  • Normal vital signs
  • Slurred speech
  • Ataxia
  • Coma

Opioid narcotics
(eg, oxycodone)
  • Euphoria
  • Depressed mental status
  • Respiratory depression
  • Miosis
  • Constipation

MDMA = 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine;
NMDA = N-methyl-D-aspartate; PCP = phencyclidine.

title: Diverticulitis

noteText:
Intussusception

Pathogenesis &
epidemiology
  • Telescoping of one bowel segment into adjacent segment (most often ileocecal)
  • Bowel edema â ischemia & necrosis
  • Age 6 months to 3 years most common

Risk factors
  • Hypertrophy of intestinal Peyer patches (eg, recent viral illness)

presentation
  • Sudden, intermittent abdominal pain & vomiting
  • Sausage-shaped mass in right abdomen
  • Currant jelly stools
  • Lethargy or altered mental status

Diagnosis &
management
  • Ultrasonography: target sign 
  • Air (pneumatic) or saline enema
  • Surgical intervention for failed enema reduction or signs of peritonitis

HSP = Henoch-SchÃ¶nlein purpura.

title: Sigmoid volvulus
noteText:
Sigmoid volvulus

Risk factors
  • Sigmoid colon redundancy (eg, dilation/elongation from chronic constipation)
  • Colonic dysmotility (eg, underlying neurologic disorder)

Presentation
  • Slowly progressive abdominal discomfort/distension Â± obstructive symptoms (eg, nausea, emesis, obstipation)
  • Abdomen distended & tympanitic to percussion

Imaging
  • X-ray: dilated, inverted, U-shaped loop of colon (coffee bean sign)
  • CT scan: dilated sigmoid colon, mesenteric twisting (whirl sign)

Management
  • Endoscopic detorsion (eg, flexible sigmoidoscopy) & elective sigmoid colectomy
  • Emergency sigmoid colectomy if perforation/peritonitis present

title: Radiation proctitis
noteText:
Radiation proctitis
 

Acute radiation proctitis

Chronic radiation proctitis

Postradiation onset
  • â¤8 weeks
  • >3 months to years

Pathogenesis
  • Direct mucosal damage
  • Obliterative endarteritis & chronic mucosal ischemia
  • Submucosal fibrosis

Manifestations
  • Diarrhea, mucus discharge, tenesmus
  • Minimal bleeding
  • Severe bleeding
  • Â± Strictures with constipation & rectal pain

Endoscopic appearance
  • Severe erythema
  • Edema, ulcerations
  • Multiple telangiectasias

title: Risk factor for colon cancer
noteText:
Risk factors for colon cancer

Lifestyle factors
  • Frequent consumption of red/processed meat
  • Tobacco, alcohol use

Medical/family history
  • Personal/family history of adenomatous polyps or colon cancer
  • Inherited colon cancer syndromes (eg, familial adenomatous polyposis, Lynch syndrome)
  • Ulcerative colitis
  • Diabetes/obesity
  • Prior abdominopelvic radiation

Protective factors
  • High-fiber diet
  • Aspirin/NSAID use

NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug.

title: Ectoic pregnancy
Disssociative disorder
noteText:
Dissociative disorders

Depersonalization/ derealization disorder
  • Persistent or recurrent experiences of 1 or both:
    • Depersonalization (feelings of detachment from, or being an outside observer of, oneself)
    • Derealization (experiencing surroundings as unreal)
  • Intact reality testing

Dissociative amnesia
  • Inability to recall important personal information, usually of a traumatic or stressful nature
  • Not explained by another disorder (eg, substance use, posttraumatic stress)

Dissociative identity disorder
  • Marked discontinuity in identity & loss of personal agency with fragmentation into â¥2 distinct personality states
  • Associated with severe trauma/abuse

title: Incisional hernia
noteText:
Incisional hernia

Pathogenesis
  • Breakdown of prior fascial closure

Risk factors
  • Obesity
  • Tobacco smoking
  • Poor wound healing (eg, immunosuppression, malnutrition)
  • Vertical or midline incision
  • Surgical site infection

Clinical features
  • Abdominal mass that enlarges with Valsalva
  • Palpable fascial edges in nonobese patients
  • Possible delayed presentation (months-years)

Diagnosis
  • Clinical
  • CT scan of abdomen

title: Hirschsprung disease
noteText:
Hirschsprung disease (congenital aganglionic megacolon)

Pathology

  • Failed neural crest cell migration to distal colon

Symptoms

  • Neonates: Delayed passage of meconium, bilious vomiting, Â± enterocolitis
  • Children/adolescents: Chronic constipation, failure to thrive

Physical examination

  • Distended abdomen
  • Tight anal sphincter
  • Absence of stool in rectal vault
  • Forceful stool expulsion on rectal examination

Diagnosis

  • Rectal suction biopsy (gold standard)
  • Anorectal manometry, contrast enema (adjuncts)

Management

  • Surgical resection of aganglionic segment

title: Pilonidal disease
Colonic ischemia
noteText:
Colonic ischemia

Pathophysiology
  • Usually nonocclusive, âwatershedâ ischemia
  • Underlying atherosclerotic disease
  • State of low blood flow (eg, hypovolemia)

Clinical features
  • Moderate abdominal pain & tenderness
  • Hematochezia, diarrhea
  • Leukocytosis, lactic acidosis

Diagnosis
  • CT scan: Colonic wall thickening, fat stranding
  • Endoscopy: Edematous & friable mucosa 

Management
  • Intravenous fluids & bowel rest
  • Antibiotics with enteric coverage
  • Colonic resection if necrosis develops

title: Opioid prescribing best practices
noteText:
Opioid prescribing best practices

Prior to
initiation
  • Screen for risk factors for misuse
  • Perform urine drug screening
  • Query PDMP database
  • Sign controlled substance agreement (eg, 1 prescriber, 1 pharmacy)

During
therapy
  • Follow up every 1-3 months
  • Query PDMP database before each refill
  • Perform random urine drug screenings

PDMP = prescription drug monitoring program.

title: Acute appendicitis
noteText:
Acute appendicitis

Clinical presentation
  • Nausea, vomiting, anorexia
  • Initially: diffuse abdominal pain (visceral pain)
  • Later: localized RLQ pain (somatic pain)
  • Mild leukocytosis

Examination
  • McBurney point tenderness
  • Psoas sign: pain with right hip extension
  • Obturator sign: pain with right hip internal rotation
  • Rovsing sign: RLQ pain with LLQ palpation

Diagnosis
  • Clinical presentation
  • CT scan or ultrasound

Treatment
  • Surgical appendectomy

LLQ = left lower quadrant; RLQ = right lower quadrant.

title: Inflammatory diarrhoea
noteText:
Inflammatory diarrhea

Etiologies
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (eg, Crohn disease, ulcerative colitis)
  • Invasive infections (eg, Clostridioides difficile, Entamoeba histolytica, CMV)
  • Ischemic colitis, radiation colitis

Clinical characteristics
  • Bloody stool (occult or gross)
  • Peripheral leukocytosis & reactive thrombocytosis
  • Â± Anemia of chronic disease
  • Â­ Inflammatory markers (eg, CRP, ESR, fecal calprotectin or lactoferrin)

CMV = cytomegalovirus; CRP = C-reactive protein; ESR = erythrocyte sedimentation rate.

title: Defense mechanisms
noteText:
Key defense mechanisms

Immature

  • Acting out: Expressing unacceptable feelings through actions
  • Denial: Behaving as if an aspect of reality does not exist
  • Displacement: Transferring feelings to less threatening object/person
  • Intellectualization: Focusing on nonemotional aspects to avoid distressing feelings
  • Passive aggression: Avoiding conflict by expressing hostility covertly
  • Projection: Attributing oneâs own feelings to others
  • Rationalization: Justifying behavior to avoid difficult truths
  • Reaction formation: Transforming unacceptable feelings/impulses into the opposite
  • Regression: Reverting to earlier developmental stage
  • Splitting: Experiencing a person/situation as either all positive or all negative

Mature
  • Sublimation: Channeling impulses into socially acceptable behaviors
  • Suppression: Putting unwanted feelings aside to cope with reality

title: Colovesical fistula
noteText:
Clinical features of colovesical fistula

Etiology
  • Diverticular disease (sigmoid most common)
  • Crohn disease
  • Malignancy (colon, bladder, pelvic organs)

Clinical presentation
  • Pneumaturia (air in urine)
  • Fecaluria (stool in urine)
  • Recurrent urinary tract infections (mixed flora)

Diagnosis
  • CT scan of the abdomen with oral or rectal (not intravenous) contrast
  • Colonoscopy to exclude colonic malignancy

title: Parent management training
noteText:
Parent management training

Focus

Parent interventions

Antecedents

(communication
leading to
wanted/unwanted
behaviors)
  • Use (promote wanted behavior):
    • clear instructions
    • calm tones & supportive gestures
    • alternative choices
  • Avoid (promote unwanted behavior):
    • nagging
    • threats
    • harsh comments
    • physical intimidation

Behaviors

(practicing effective
parent-child
interactions)
  • Shaping:
    • small behavioral goals adding to bigger changes
  • Role-play wanted behaviors:
    • artificial situations first
    • build to realistic scenarios

Consequences

(for wanted/
unwanted
behaviors)
  • Reinforce wanted behaviors:
    • praise (verbal, nonverbal)
    • token/point system rewards
  • Manage unwanted behaviors:
    • extinction (eg, ignore, walk away)
    • mild punishment (eg, privilege loss)

title: Catatonia
noteText:
Catatonia

Clinical features
  • Immobility or excessive purposeless activity 
  • Mutism, stupor (decreased alertness & response to stimuli)
  • Negativism (resistance to instructions & movement)
  • Posturing (assuming positions against gravity)
  • Waxy flexibility (initial resistance, then maintenance of new posture)
  • Echolalia, echopraxia (mimicking speech & movements)

Management
  • Benzodiazepines (lorazepam)
  • Electroconvulsive therapy

title: Neonatal abstinence syndrome
noteText:
Neonatal abstinence syndrome

Pathophysiology
  • In utero exposure to maternal substances (primarily opioids)

Clinical
manifestations
  • CNS: irritability, hypertonia, tremor, shortened sleep-wake cycles, uncoordinated swallowing
  • Autonomic nervous system: diaphoresis, sneezing, yawning
  • Gastrointestinal: feeding difficulty, vomiting, diarrhea

Diagnosis
  • Primarily clinical
  • Confirm: umbilical cord blood, urine, or meconium drug testing

Treatment
  • Mild withdrawal: nonpharmacologic
    • Minimize environmental stimuli, swaddling, frequent small feeds
  • Moderate to severe withdrawal: pharmacologic
    • Morphine, methadone

title: Intellectual disability causes
noteText:
Common causes of intellectual disability

Syndrome

Dysmorphic features

Comorbid conditions

Down syndrome
  • Upslanting palpebral fissures
  • Flat nasal bridge
  • Epicanthal folds
  • Single palmar crease
  • Heart disease (eg, AV canal defect)
  • Short stature, obesity
  • Hearing loss

Fragile X syndrome
  • Long face with prominent chin & forehead
  • Large, protruding ears
  • Macroorchidism
  • Macrocephaly
  • Self-injurious behavior (eg, hand biting)
  • Anxiety, autistic behaviors
  • Tall stature

Fetal alcohol syndrome
  • Smooth philtrum
  • Thin vermillion border
  • Small palpebral fissures
  • Seizures
  • Growth restriction

AV = atrioventricular.

title: Alcohol use disorder
noteText:
Alcohol use disorder

Clinical features
  • Drinking in larger amounts, inability to cut down, cravings
  • Drinking in hazardous situations, failure to fulfill role obligations, continued drinking despite health/psychological/interpersonal problems
  • Evidence of tolerance & withdrawal

Psychosocial treatment
  • Motivational interviewing
  • Cognitive-behavioral therapy
  • Residential treatment/rehabilitation
  • Mutual help groups (eg, Alcoholics Anonymous)

Pharmacotherapy
  • Naltrexone
  • Acamprosate (preferred in patients with liver disease or opioid use)
  • Disulfiram is second-line therapy in highly motivated patients

title: Congenital hypothyroidism
noteText:
Congenital hypothyroidism

Pathophysiology
  • Thyroid dysgenesis most common (eg, agenesis, hypoplasia, ectopy)

Clinical
manifestations
  • Asymptomatic at birth*
  • Symptomatic weeks to months after birth (as maternal T4 wanes)
    • Hypometabolism: â HR & temperature, lethargy/poor feeding, hypotonia, constipation, jaundice
    • Mucopolysaccharide accumulation: macroglossia, umbilical hernia
    • Delayed bone maturation: enlarged fontanelles

Diagnosis
  • Newborn screening
  • â TSH & â T4

Treatment
  • Levothyroxine

Prognosis
  • No deficits if treatment started in neonatal period
  • Untreated disease leads to intellectual disability, developmental delay & poor growth

*Can rarely present with delayed passage of meconium.

HR = heart rate.

title: Rectal prolapse
noteText:
Rectal prolapse

Risk factors
  • Women age >40 with history of vaginal deliveries/multiparity
  • Prior pelvic surgery
  • Chronic constipation, diarrhea, or straining
  • Stroke, dementia
  • Pelvic floor dysfunction or anatomic defects

Clinical
presentation
  • Abdominal discomfort
  • Straining or incomplete bowel evacuation, fecal incontinence
  • Digital maneuvers possibly required for defecation
  • Erythematous mass extending through anus with concentric rings (full-thickness prolapse) or radial invaginations (nonâfull-thickness prolapse)

Management
  • Medical
    • Considered for nonâfull-thickness prolapse
    • Adequate fiber & fluid intake, pelvic floor muscle exercises
    • Possible biofeedback therapy for fecal incontinence
  • Surgical
    • Preferred for full-thickness or debilitating symptoms (eg, fecal incontinence, constipation, sensation of mass)

title: Clostridium difficile coitis
noteText:

  • Recent antibiotic use or hospitalization

  • Chemotherapy

presentation
  • Profuse watery diarrhea
  • Leukocytosis (~15,000/mm3)
  • Fulminant colitis or toxic megacolon

Diagnosis
  • Stool PCR for C difficile genes*
  • Stool EIA for C difficile toxin & glutamate dehydrogenase antigen

Infection
control
  • Hand hygiene with soap & water
  • Contact isolation
  • Sporicidal disinfectants (eg, bleach)

*Genes specific to toxigenic strains are assessed.

EIA = enzyme immunoassay; H2 = histamine-2 receptor; PPI = proton pump inhibitor.

title: Microscopic colitis
noteText:
Microscopic colitis

Clinical findings
  • Chronic watery, nonbloody diarrhea
  • Fecal urgency & incontinence
  • Variable abdominal pain, weight loss

Risk factors
  • Smoking
  • Medications (eg, NSAIDs, PPIs, SSRIs)
  • Female age â¥45

Diagnosis
  • Colonoscopic biopsy: mononuclear infiltrate in lamina propria
    • Collagenous: thickened subepithelial collagen band
    • Lymphocytic: high concentration of intraepithelial lymphocytes

Management
  • Withdrawal of trigger medications; smoking cessation
  • Antidiarrheal medications & oral budesonide

NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; PPIs = proton pump inhibitors; SSRIs =  selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors.

title: Giardiasis
noteText:
Giardiasis

Risk factors
  • Contaminated food or water
  • Fecal incontinence & crowding (eg, day care, nursing home)
  • Immunodeficiency (eg, CVID, IgA deficiency, CF, HIV)

Pathogenesis
  • Villous blunting, disruption of epithelial tight junctions, loss of brush border enzymes â malabsorption

Clinical features
  • Subacute (<4 weeks) or chronic (months)
  • Loose, oily, nonbloody stools
  • Bloating, flatulence
  • Weight loss, decreased linear velocity (children), vitamin deficiencies

Diagnosis
  • Stool antigen or PCR testing (â sensitivity)
  • Stool microscopy (â sensitivity)

Treatment
  • First-line: tinidazole or nitazoxanide
  • Alternate: metronidazole
  • Pregnancy (first trimester): paromomycin
  • Refractory/recurrent symptoms: evaluation for immunodeficiency

CF = cystic fibrosis; CVID = common variable immunodeficiency.

title: Small bowel obstruction
noteText:
Small bowel obstruction

Clinical presentation

  • Colicky abdominal pain, vomiting
  • Inability to pass flatus or stool if complete (no obstipation if partial)
  • Hyperactive â absent bowel sounds
  • Distended & tympanitic abdomen

Diagnosis

  • Dilated loops of bowel with air-fluid levels on plain film or CT scan
  • Partial: air in colon
  • Complete: transition point (abrupt cutoff), no air in colon

Complications

  • Ischemia/necrosis (strangulation)
  • Bowel perforation

Management

  • Bowel rest, nasogastric tube suction, intravenous fluids
  • Surgical exploration for signs of complications

title: Evaluation of suspected IBD
Necrotizing enterocolitis
noteText:
Management of necrotizing enterocolitis

Immediate
interventions
  • Discontinuation of enteral feeds
  • Nasogastric decompression
  • Blood cultures & empiric antibiotics
  • Intravenous fluid repletion

Monitoring
  • Serial complete blood count & electrolytes
  • Serial abdominal examinations & imaging

Indications
for surgery
  • Bowel perforation (pneumoperitoneum)
  • Clinical deterioration despite medical management (suggestive of bowel necrosis)

title: Internal vs external validity
noteText:
Internal validity

External validity

Characteristics

Describes causality (ie, if change in independent variable causes change in dependent variable)

Describes generalizability (ie, if observed relationship applies to situations or people outside study)

â As study becomes more tightly controlled

â As study becomes more tightly controlled

â As study becomes more like the real world

â As study becomes more like the real world

Threats to validity

Bias due to:

  • Confounding
  • History
  • Maturation
  • Measurement
  • Regression toward the mean
  • Repeated testing
  • Selection

Bias due to:

  • Artificial research environment
  • Measurement effects
  • Nonrepresentative sample

title: Controlling confounding
Confidence interval
Study design
noteText:
Types of studies in the health sciences

Experimental

Randomized controlled trial
  • Random allocation into treatment & placebo groups
  • Can determine efficacy of the intervention

Nonrandomized design
  • Nonrandom allocation into treatment & placebo groups
  • Can determine efficacy of the intervention

Observational

Cohort
  • Data gathered from the same individuals over time (longitudinal)
  • Can assess risk factors or outcomes

Cross-sectional
  • Data gathered at one point in time
  • Can determine prevalence of an outcome in a population

Case-control
  • Data gathered from individuals with the condition of interest (cases) & compared to individuals without the condition (controls)

Case
  • Detailed information gathered about one individual (or a small group of individuals)

Review

Meta-analysis
  • Data from multiple studies are statistically combined & analyzed

title: Confounding vs effect modification
Performance measures for diagnostic test
noteText:
Common performance measures for diagnostic tests

Parameter

Definition

Calculation

Sensitivity

The probability of an individual testing positive given the presence of disease

Sensitivity = true positives / (true positives + false negatives)

Specificity

The probability of an individual testing negative given the absence of disease

Specificity = true negatives / (true negatives + false positives)

Positive predictive value (PPV)

The probability that an individual who tests positive actually has the disease

PPV = true positives / (true positives + false positives)

Negative predictive value (NPV)

The probability that an individual who tests negative actually does not have the disease

NPV = true negatives / (true negatives + false negatives)

Positive likelihood ratio (LR+)

The probability of an individual with the disease testing positive divided by the probability of an individual without the disease testing positive

LR+ = sensitivity / (1 â specificity)

Negative likelihood ratio (LRâ)

The probability of an individual with the disease testing negative divided by the probability of an individual without the disease testing negative

LRâ = (1 â sensitivity) / specificity

title: Colon cancer screening
noteText:
Colon cancer screening

Patients at
average risk
  • Start at age 45:
    • Colonoscopy every 10 years
    • gFOBT or FIT every year
    • FIT-DNA every 1-3 years
    • CT colonography every 5 years
  • Flexible sigmoidoscopy every 5 years (or every 10 years with annual FIT)

Patients with FDR with CRC or high-risk adenomatous polyp*
  • Colonoscopy at age 40 (or 10 years prior to age of diagnosis in FDR, whichever comes first)
  • Repeat every 5 years (every 10 years if FDR diagnosed at age >60)

Patients with ulcerative colitis
  • Start screening 8-10 years after diagnosis
  • Colonoscopy every 1-3 years

*Adenomatous polyp â¥10 mm, high-grade dysplasia, villous elements (for example).

CRC = colorectal cancer; FDR = first-degree relative; FIT = fecal immunochemical test; FIT-DNA = multitarget stool DNA test; gFOBT = guaiac-based fecal occult blood test.

title: IBD
noteText:
Inflammatory bowel disease subtype characteristics
 

Crohn disease

Ulcerative colitis

Involvement
  • Anywhere mouth to anus (mostly ileum & colon)
  • Perianal disease with rectal sparing
  • Skip lesions
  • Rectum (always) & colon
  • Continuous lesions

Microscopy
  • Noncaseating granulomas
  • No granulomas

Gross
findings
  • Transmural inflammation
  • Linear mucosal ulcerations
  • Cobblestoning, creeping fat
  • Mucosal & submucosal inflammation
  • Pseudopolyps

Clinical
manifestations
  • Abdominal pain (often RLQ)
  • Watery diarrhea (bloody if colitis)
  • Abdominal pain (varying locations)
  • Bloody diarrhea

Intestinal
complications
  • Fistulae, abscesses
  • Strictures (bowel obstruction)
  • Toxic megacolon

RLQ = right lower quadrant.

title: Hemorrhoids
noteText:
Internal vs external hemorrhoids*
 

Internal

External

Presentation
  • Above dentate line (seen on anoscopy)
  • BRBPR, pruritus
  • Typically painless or vague symptoms (visceral innervation)
  • Complications: prolapse (causing fecal incontinence), thrombosis (can cause pain)
  • Below dentate line (seen on examination)
  • BRBPR, pruritus
  • Typically painful (somatic innervation)
  • Complications: thrombosis (severe pain)

Management
  • Conservative management (eg, fiber supplementation, topical glucocorticoid)
  • Office-based treatment (eg, rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy)
  • Hemorrhoidectomy for severe prolapse or thrombosis
  • Conservative management
  • Hemorrhoidectomy for severely painful thrombosis
  • Office-based procedures are contraindicated

*Risk factors: pregnancy, constipation, older age.

BRBPR = bright red blood per rectum.

title: Erythema nodosum
noteText:
Erythema nodosum

Clinical features
  • Tender, indurated, erythematous nodules
  • Most common on anterior legs

Pathogenesis
  • Delayed hypersensitivity reaction
  • Septal panniculitis without vasculitis

Associated conditions
  • Infections (eg, Streptococcus)
  • Inflammatory disorders (eg, IBD, sarcoidosis)
  • Medications (eg, antibiotics, oral contraceptive pills)
  • Pregnancy

Management
  • Evaluation (as appropriate): CBC, ESR, streptococcal testing, chest radiograph, tuberculin skin test
  • Symptomatic treatment: NSAIDs, KI, corticosteroids if symptoms are refractory

CBC = complete blood count; ESR = erythrocyte sedimentation rate; IBD = inflammatory bowel disease; KI = potassium iodide; NSAID = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug.

title: Chronic mesenteric ischemia
noteText:
Chronic mesenteric ischemia

Etiology
  • Atherosclerosis (smoking, dyslipidemia)

Clinical features
  • Crampy, postprandial epigastric pain
  • Food aversion & weight loss

Diagnosis
  • Signs of malnutrition, abdominal bruit
  • CT angiography (preferred), Doppler ultrasonography

Management
  • Risk reduction (eg, tobacco reduction), nutritional support
  • Endovascular or open surgical revascularization

title: PSC
noteText:
Primary sclerosing cholangitis

Clinical features
  • Asymptomatic initially; fatigue & pruritus with progressive disease
  • Associated with IBD, particularly ulcerative colitis

Laboratory & imaging results
  • Cholestasis (â ALP, GGT, bilirubin)
  • Multifocal strictures/dilation of bile ducts on MRCP

Complications
  • Cholangitis, cholangiocarcinoma, colon cancer
  • Fat-soluble vitamin deficiencies

ALP = alkaline phosphatase; GGT = Î³-glutamyl transferase; IBD = inflammatory bowel disease; MRCP = MR cholangiopancreatography.

title: Diagnostic approach to abnormal LFT
noteText:
Diagnostic approach to abnormal liver function test results

History
  • Detailed alcohol intake assessment (frequency, quantity)
  • Hepatitis risk factor assessment (eg, sexual history)
  • Medication review (eg, acetaminophen, supplement use)
  • Family history (eg, autoimmune disease)

Physical examination
  • Assess for:
    • Stigmata of cirrhosis (eg, palmar erythema, spider angiomas)
    • Signs of malignancy (eg, lymph node enlargement)
    • Volume overload (eg, elevated jugular venous pressure)
    • Visceral obesity (eg, truncal obesity)

Diagnostic testing
  • Selective laboratory testing based on risk factors
  • Hepatocellular pattern: viral serologies, antinuclear antibody, iron studies
  • Cholestatic pattern: Î³-glutamyltransferase, pancreatic enzymes, liver ultrasonography

title: Systematic errors in statistical studies
Cirrhosis Mx
noteText:
Overview of cirrhosis management

Treat underlying
liver disease
  • HCV, HBV: antiviral therapy
  • NASH: weight loss

Provide
preventive care
  • Avoid alcohol & hepatotoxic medications
  • Vaccinate for HAV & HBV (unless already immune)

Manage
complications
  • Screen for esophageal varices (endoscopy)
  • Screen for HCC: ultrasound Â± serum AFP every 6-12 months
  • Frequent clinical assessment for ascites and encephalopathy (prophylactic treatment not recommended)

AFP = alpha fetoprotein; HAV = hepatitis A virus; HBV = hepatitis B virus; HCC = hepatocellular carcinoma; HCV = hepatitis C virus; NASH = nonalcoholic steatohepatitis.

Management of ascites in cirrhosis

Initial evaluation
  • Imaging for confirmation (eg, abdominal ultrasound)
  • Diagnostic paracentesis to confirm etiology & rule out infection
    • SAAG, cell count & differential, total protein

Medical therapy
  • Spironolactone with furosemide
  • Alcohol abstinence, sodium restriction
  • Avoid ACE inhibitors, angiotensin receptor blockers, NSAIDs

Refractory ascites
  • Large-volume paracentesis
  • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt

NSAIDs = nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs; SAAG = serum-ascites albumin gradient.

title: Criteria of casuality
noteText:
Basic criterion to
establish causality

Explanation

Analogy

Similar associations known

Biological gradient

Dose-response relationship between cause & effect

Biological plausibility

Probable given established knowledge

Coherence

Association should not conflict with known facts

Consistency

Cause widely associated with effect

Experimental evidence

Effect evidenced by experimental designs

Specificity

Cause uniquely associated with effect

Strength of association

Cause associated with a substantive effect

Temporality

Cause precedes effect

title: Wilsons disease
noteText:
Wilson disease

Pathogenesis
  • Autosomal recessive mutation of ATP7B â hepatic copper accumulation â leak from damaged hepatocytes â deposits in tissues (eg, basal ganglia, cornea)

findings
  • Hepatic (acute liver failure, chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis)
  • Neurologic (parkinsonism, gait disturbance, dysarthria)

  • â Ceruloplasmin & â urinary copper excretion

Treatment
  • Chelators (eg, D-penicillamine, trientine)
  • Zinc (interferes with copper absorption)

title: Hepatic adenoma
noteText:
Hepatic adenoma

Epidemiology
  • Benign epithelial liver tumor
  • Primarily young women on oral contraception

Manifestations
  • Often asymptomatic (incidentally found)
  • Episodic right upper quadrant pain

Imaging
  • Solitary, solid lesion in right lobe of liver
  • Multiple lesions occasionally occur

Treatment
  • Asymptomatic & <5 cm - stop oral contraception
  • Symptomatic or >5 cm - surgical resection

Complications
  • Malignant transformation (~10%)
  • Rupture & hemorrhagic shock (~30%)

Solid liver masses

Focal nodular hyperplasia
  • Associated with anomalous arteries
  • Arterial flow & central scar on imaging

Hepatic adenoma
  • Women on long-term oral contraceptives
  • Possible hemorrhage or malignant transformation

Regenerative nodules
  • Acute or chronic liver injury (eg, cirrhosis)

Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Systemic symptoms
  • Chronic hepatitis or cirrhosis
  • Elevated É fetoprotein

Liver metastasis
  • Single/multiple lesions
  • Known extrahepatic malignancy

title: Alcoholic hepatitis
noteText:
Clinical features of alcoholic hepatitis

Clinical presentation
  • Jaundice, anorexia, fever
  • Right upper quadrant &/or epigastric pain
  • Abdominal distension due to ascites
  • Proximal muscle weakness from muscle wasting if malnourished
  • Possible hepatic encephalopathy

Laboratory & imaging studies
  • Elevated AST & ALT, usually <300 U/L
  • AST/ALT ratio â¥2
  • Elevated GGT, bilirubin &/or INR
  • Leukocytosis, predominantly neutrophils
  • Decreased albumin if malnourished
  • Abdominal imaging may show fatty liver

ALT = alanine aminotransferase; AST = aspartate aminotransferase; GGT = gamma-glutamyltransferase.

title: Normal aging vs dementia
noteText:
Normal aging

Dementia (major cognitive disorder)

Memory loss
  • Can provide details about incidents of forgetfulness
  • Patient is concerned about memory loss
  • Recent memory for important events & conversations is intact
  • Cannot remember specific instances of forgetfulness
  • Family is more concerned than patient
  • Has notable decline in memory for recent important events & conversations

Word-finding difficulty
  • Occasional (expressive aphasia)
  • No receptive aphasia
  • Frequent, with substitutions
  • Some receptive aphasia

Independence & functioning
  • Maintains independence in ADLs
  • Is able to operate common appliances
  • Maintains interpersonal social skills
  • Does not get lost in familiar territory (may have to pause briefly to reorient)
  • Becomes dependent on others for ADLs
  • Is unable to operate common appliances
  • Loses interest in social activities
  • Can get lost for hours in familiar territory while driving or walking

ADL = activities of daily living.

title: Acute liver failure
noteText:
Acute liver failure

Etiology
  • Viral hepatitis (eg, HSV; CMV; hepatitis A, B, D, E)
  • Drug toxicity (eg, acetaminophen overdose, idiosyncratic)
  • Ischemia (eg, shock liver, Budd-Chiari syndrome)
  • Autoimmune hepatitis
  • Wilson disease
  • Malignant infiltration

Clinical presentation
  • Generalized symptoms (eg, fatigue, lethargy, anorexia, nausea)
  • Right upper quadrant abdominal pain
  • Pruritus & jaundice due to hyperbilirubinemia
  • Renal insufficiency
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Hypoglycemia

Diagnostic requirements
  • Severe acute liver injury (ALT & AST often >1,000 U/L)
  • Signs of hepatic encephalopathy (eg, confusion, asterixis)
  • Synthetic liver dysfunction (INR â¥1.5)

ALT = alanine aminotransferase; AST = aspartate aminotransferase; CMV = cytomegalovirus; HSV = herpes simplex virus; INR = international normalized ratio.

title: ADHD vs ODD vs CD
Hepatitis A

Hepatitis A

Transmission
& risk factors
  • Fecal-oral transmission
  • Poor sanitation/hygiene, travel to endemic areas
  • Contaminated food & water

Clinical
presentation
  • Fever, nausea, right upper quadrant pain
  • Jaundice, hepatomegaly

Diagnostic
testing
  • Elevated liver transaminases (>1,000 U/L)
  • Antiâhepatitis A serology

Management
  • Supportive/expectant
  • Spontaneous recovery in most patients

Parent interventions

Antecedents

(communication
leading to
wanted/unwanted
behaviors)

    • calm tones & supportive gestures

  • Avoid (promote unwanted behavior):

(practicing effective

interactions)

Consequences

(for wanted/
unwanted
behaviors)

  • Manage unwanted behaviors:
    • extinction (eg, ignore, walk away)
    • mild punishment (eg, privilege loss)

The first management priority is to reduce or discontinue any nonessential medications with psychoactive properties that may be contributing to psychosis (eg, anticholinergics, anxiolytics, tricyclic antidepressants).  However, unlike tricyclics, selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors have low anticholinergic activity and are less likely to induce psychosis; increasing or reducing this patient's sertraline dose is unlikely to improve his psychotic symptoms

noteText:
Autism spectrum disorder

  • Social deficits with onset in early development

    • Lack of nonverbal communication (eg, eye contact)

    • Insistence on sameness/routines
    • Intense, fixated interests
    • Adverse responses to sensory input (eg, foods, textures)
  • Â± Language delays & cognitive impairment

  • Comprehensive clinical evaluation
  • Genetic testing (eg, chromosomal microarray, fragile X gene analysis)
  • Â± Brain MRI (eg, macrocephaly, neurologic deficits)
   Management 
  • Behavioral, speech, occupational therapies

Hereditary hemochromatosis

Autoimmune hepatitis

    • Fatigue, anorexia, nausea, jaundice
    • Can progress to fulminant liver failure &/or cirrhosis
  • Often associated with other autoimmune disorders (eg, vitiligo, autoimmune thyroiditis, celiac disease)

Laboratory
findings

    • Antiâsmooth muscle
    • Antiâliver/kidney microsomal type 1

Treatment

ALT = alanine aminotransferase; AST = aspartate aminotransferase.

title: Liver structure
Hepatic encephalopathy
noteText:
Hepatic encephalopathy

Precipitating factors
  • Drugs (eg, sedatives, narcotics)
  • Hypovolemia (eg, diarrhea)
  • Electrolyte changes (eg, hypokalemia)
  • â Nitrogen load (eg, GI bleeding)
  • Infection (eg, pneumonia, UTI, SBP)
  • Portosystemic shunting (eg, TIPS)

Clinical presentation
  • Sleep pattern changes
  • Altered mental status
  • Ataxia
  • Asterixis

Treatment
  • Correct precipitating causes (eg, fluids, antibiotics)
  • â Blood ammonia concentration (eg, lactulose, rifaximin)

GI = gastrointestinal; SBP = spontaneous bacterial peritonitis; TIPS = transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt; UTI = urinary tract infection.
Nonabsorbable disaccharides (eg, lactulose, lactitol) are preferred for lowering serum ammonia.  Colonic bacteria metabolize lactulose to short-chain fatty acids (eg, lactic acid, acetic acid).  This acidifies the colon to stimulate conversion of the absorbable ammonia to the nonabsorbable ammonium (an ammonia trap) and causes bowel movements (which facilitates fecal nitrogen excretion).  The medication is titrated to produce 2 or 3 semiformed stools daily.

title: Benzodiazepine
noteText:
Duration of action of common benzodiazepines

Short
(half-life <6 hr)

Triazolam, midazolam

Intermediate
(half-life 6-50 hr)

Oxazepam, alprazolam, lorazepam, clonazepam

Long
(half-life >50 hr)

Diazepam, chlordiazepoxide, flurazepam

title: ADHD Rx
noteText:
Pharmacotherapy for attention deficit hyperactivity disorder

Category

Medication

Adverse effects

Stimulant

Methylphenidate

Weight loss, decreased appetite, insomnia, abdominal pain, tachycardia, hypertension, tics (rare), addiction potential

Amphetamine salts

title: Cholestasis of pregnancy
noteText:
Intrahepatic cholestasis of pregnancy

Clinical features
  • Development in 3rd trimester
  • Generalized pruritus
  • Pruritus worse on hands & feet
  • No associated rash
  • Right upper quadrant pain

Laboratory abnormalities
  • â Total bile acids (â¥10 Âµmol/L)
  • â Liver transaminases (typically <2Ã normal, rarely >1,000 U/L)
  • Â± â Total & direct bilirubin

Obstetric risks
  • Intrauterine fetal demise
  • Preterm delivery
  • Meconium-stained amniotic fluid
  • Neonatal respiratory distress syndrome

Management
  • Ursodeoxycholic acid
  • Antihistamines
  • Delivery at 37 weeks gestation

Acute fatty liver of pregnancy

Clinical features
  • Nausea, vomiting
  • Right upper quadrant/epigastric pain
  • Fulminant liver failure

Laboratory findings
  • Profound hypoglycemia
  • â Aminotransferases (2-3Ã normal)
  • â Bilirubin
  • Thrombocytopenia
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulopathy

Management
  • Immediate delivery

title: Liver laceration
Stigmata of CLD
Reye syndrome
noteText:
Reye syndrome

Pathophysiology
  • Aspirin use in children during viral infection (eg, influenza, varicella)
  • Microvesicular fat deposits in the liver
  • Cerebral edema

Clinical features
  • Acute liver failure
    • Hepatomegaly without jaundice
  • Rapidly progressive encephalopathy
    • Vomiting, lethargy, seizure, coma

Laboratory findings
  • â AST, ALT, ammonia
  • â PT, INR, PTT
  • â Glucose
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Normal bilirubin

Treatment
  • Supportive

ALT = alanine aminotransferase (SGPT); AST = aspartate aminotransferase (SGOT).

Toxic-metabolic encephalopathy* & cerebral edema

Diagnosis

Precipitating factors

Hypoxic-ischemic
encephalopathy
  • Near-drowning event
  • Choking episode

Diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus

Hyponatremia
  • SIADH
  • Rapid correction of hypernatremia

Liver failure
  • Viral or autoimmune hepatitis
  • Hepatotoxic drugs (eg, acetaminophen)

Reye syndrome
  • Aspirin administration for viral illness in children

*Acute cerebral dysfunction/mental status changes in the absence of primary CNS pathology.

SIADH = syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion.

title: NAFLD
noteText:
Nonalcoholic fatty liver disease

Definition
  • Hepatic steatosis on imaging or biopsy
  • Exclusion of other etiologies (eg, alcohol, hepatitis C,
    glucocorticoids)

Clinical
features
  • Mostly asymptomatic
  • Metabolic syndrome
  • AST/ALT ratio <1
  • Hyperechoic texture on ultrasound examination

Treatment
  • Weight loss (eg, diet modification, exercise)
  • Consider bariatric surgery if BMI â¥35 kg/m2

Prognosis
  • Hepatic fibrosis associated with increased risk
    for cirrhosis & liver-related death

ALT = alanine aminotransferase; AST = aspartate aminotransferase.

title: Gilbert syndrome
